Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:603B-YSP1-JBFB-H011-00000-00Trump's Order Ignites Overdue Debate On Big Tech Protections2020-06-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisAMERICAN-RENEWALdaily-caller-news-foundationTrump's Order Ignites Overdue Debate On Big Tech ProtectionsRachel BovardContributorrb@dcnf.org

Link to Image

President Donald Trump took the fight directly to the social media giants when he signed an executive order regarding Section 230 - the part of the law that gives tech companies the ability to remove or block content on their platforms without being held liable for it.

The “Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship” directs federal agencies to re-examine the protections of Sec. 230 to ensure they are not being abused by “platforms that - far from acting in 'good faith' to remove objectionable content - instead engage in deceptive or pretextual actions (often contrary to their stated terms of service) to stifle viewpoints with which they disagree.”

Trump's action immediately drew condemnation on the right from conservatives and libertarians, who said it was government overreach,   regulating a private company and   burning down free speech on the internet.

There is a lot of hyperbole and straw man arguments surrounding this debate, as well as legitimate concerns about free speech online. Here are a few things to consider.

First, since the passage of Sec. 230 in 1996, the government has been well entangled with the tech industry. In fact, the provision of law is central to their business model. The Sec. 230 debate generates so much light and heat not only because it governs speech online; it is the billion-dollar provision of law that has grown these companies from basement start-ups to industry giants. As one pro-Sec. 230 law professor put it, it amounts to an “implicit financial subsidy” to internet companies. (RELATED: Twitter Censors White House Account For Quoting Trump's Flagged 'THUGS' Tweet)

These are private companies, yes, but their success or failure is built on the back of specific treatment by the government.

Second, that treatment is in some ways necessary. The immunity provided by Sec. 230 prevents these companies from being sued into oblivion for taking down smutty content, child pornography or other content the law defines as “obscene, lewd, lascivious” and so on. It applies broadly not just to tech companies (though those are its most famous beneficiaries), but to the comments sections of online newspapers and sites across the web.

As described by former Republican California Rep. Chris Cox, one of the provision's authors, the provision was intended to “help clean up the internet” by protecting companies who wanted to engage in good-faith removal of the nastiness that can flourish online.

But the modern application of Sec. 230 today is not what it was in 1996. Over the past 24 years, aggressive litigation has contorted the statute, broadening the immunity well beyond efforts to “clean up the internet.” For example, thanks to Sec. 230, the 2nd Circuit Court of Appealsdid not hold the dating app Grindr liable for failing to respond to repeated requests to remove fake posts that resulted in the   harassment and harm of a user.

Sec. 230 also gives social media companies tremendous power to remove, block and filter user content based on their own policies - including, as we recently saw, tweets from both the White House and the president of the United States.

This gets to the crux of the issue: the power of private tech companies to control speech in the public square - not to mention their tremendous power over your data, privacy, behavior and elections.

The text, reach and application of Trump's executive order is less about the technical merits of Sec. 230 than it is a proxy for that question. The arrogance of tech companies in blatantly imposing political viewpoints, crushing small business, serially violating user privacy and acknowledging their   power over election outcomes has come home to roost.

Seventy-two percent of the public thinks it's likely that social media platforms actively censor political views that those companies find objectionable.   Seventy-seven percent of Americans think big tech has too much power.

Sec. 230 expert Jeff Kossof recently remarked that the tech companies have “proceeded for years basically treating Section 230 like it's a right that's enshrined in the Constitution ... and now what you're seeing is a backlash to that arrogance.”

The amount of Sec. 230 reform proposals proliferating in Congress demonstrates that it's not just Trump who thinks the law might need some updates. As recently as 2018, Congress amended Sec. 230 to remove liability protections for sites that knowingly assisted in sex trafficking. (Some tech groups even   fought that law on the basis of its potential harm to free speech.)

Ultimately, it is Congress that has the power to change the law, though it will be up to the courts to decide if Trump can interpret its application, as the executive order attempts to do. (RELATED: ORTNER: The First Amendment Will Be The Only Casualty In Trump's War With Twitter)

Everyone wants to ensure free speech online - indeed, much of the frustration from the president and his allies comes from a belief that free speech is being curtailed. Sec. 230 presents both opportunities and hazards to that end, and is just one of a handful of policy options lawmakers are considering, in addition to robust antitrust enforcement and privacy legislation.

As much as the tech industry and its advocates might not think this debate should happen, it's clear that both lawmakers and a plurality of Americans do. Trump's executive order is a clear sign that this debate is only just beginning.

Rachel Bovard is the senior director of policy for the Conservative Partnership Institute.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XGX-3GD1-JB20-G3BJ-00000-00Trump Sounding Off; Trump on China Trade Talks; Trump Slamming the Fed; Impeachment Battle Heating Up; Strength of the U.S. Economy; Hong Kong Chaos; Turkey White House Visit Controversy; The Deep Freeze; State of Senior-Housing2019-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJames Freeman, Ryan Payne, Mitch Roschelle, Grant Cardone, Scott LawlorNEWSFinancial111301cb.231Trump Sounding Off; Trump on China Trade Talks; Trump Slamming the Fed; Impeachment Battle Heating Up; Strength of the U.S. Economy; Hong Kong Chaos; Turkey White House Visit Controversy; The Deep Freeze; State of Senior-HousingMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Daniel Hoffman, Janice Dean

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: President Trump says phase one of the deal could happen soon but threatens tariff hikes if no deal is reached.

The strength of the U.S. economy. The president touting job creation, record gains on Wall Street, deregulation, saying that the economy has exceeded expectations.

Concern over a China trade deal putting futures, though, under pressure this morning. Take a look at where we stand. The Dow Industrials down 106 points. Investors are waiting on Fed Chairman Jay Powell today. He will testify on Capitol Hill. Looking for any hints at where rates could be headed in the future.

As you see, futures are down 12 point on the S&P and the Nasdaq futures lower by 40 points.

The push for impeachment goes on. Public hears will kick off today. We are taking a look at what to expect and what it could mean for trade deals that are still waiting for approval, like USMCA.

Plus, chaos continuing this morning in Hong Kong. Violent protests once again cripple (INAUDIBLE) to the financial hub. Now school is canceled tomorrow.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

And we've got a big show this morning. Joining the conversation, Payne Capital Management President Ryan Payne is with us this morning. PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle, and "The Wall Street Journal's Assistant Editorial Page Editor James Freeman.

Great to see everybody this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here. Thanks.

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

So we've got a market that is once again following the bouncing ball of China.

President Trump, of course, addressed the economic club yesterday, an event that I attended. Futures are down this morning, but the president was talking about the China trade negotiations. He was talking about the strong economy. Here's a bit of that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Unemployment has recently achieved the lowest rate in 51 year. African-American unemployment, Hispanic-American unemployment and Asian-American unemployment have all reached the lowest rates in history.

Nearly 7 million people have been lifted off very importantly food stamps. Seven million people off of food stamps.

Since my election, the S&P 500 is up over 45 percent. The Dow Jones is up over 50 percent. And the Nasdaq is up 60 percent.

Their supply chains are cracking very badly. And they are dying to make a deal. We're the ones that are deciding whether or not we want to make a deal. We're close. A significant phase one trade deal with China could happen. Could happen soon.

If we don't make a deal, we're going to substantially raise those tariffs. They're going to be raised very substantially.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So tariffs, obviously, the major sticking point. The Chinese want the tariffs off. This is going back and forth between Washington and Beijing.

"The Journal" this morning is reporting that the disagreement center around whether the United States will remove existing tariffs or simply cancel the ones set to take effect December 15th.

And, you know, the December 15th tariffs I think is what keeps going back and forth between China and the U.S. How important is that for markets?

PAYNE: I think it's pretty important that we see something happen, right, because at this point we're hearing we have a deal and then, guess what, the rug -- you know, the rug gets pulled beneath us saying we don't have a deal now. So I think some sort of clarity around tariffs is pretty important. I think that's what's going to drive the market here for sure.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, I markets follow anything -- any develop on this.

I can't imagine how a deal gets done, James, without the big ticket items, like intellectual property theft.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think the Chinese are willing to at least make a commitment to that, whether they follow through in future years remain to be seen. But the president can always punish behavior that crops up in the future, right, if he gets that -- that change he wants in terms of stop stealing American intervention, don't force U.S. companies to have a local partner, I don't see why the tariffs shouldn't come down.

BARTIROMO: But I can't see this president taking off all the tariffs because that's what China wants and it just feels like then China wins.

FREEMAN: But we all win if we get --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, I know and --

FREEMAN: If we get zero tariffs and we get rule of law and fair play in China, then it -- then it's good for everybody.

I -- I hope he doesn't look at that as -- as losing if he makes it cheaper for us to buy goods.

BARTIROMO: Right.

FREEMAN: We want to buy their goods if they're not stealing ours.

BARTIROMO: If they're not steal ours.

FREEMAN: Right.

BARTIROMO: But so far they've been unwilling, Mitch, to actually agree to an enforcement action within this deal.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Yes, and there are rumors that they're talking about it, so it may or may not be in phase one. It's allegedly in one of those chapters. But what we absolutely don't know is what the enforcement mechanism is, to James' point. So you could have all the words you want in the agreement about what you're supposed to do and what you're not supposed to do, but if there's no mechanism for enforcement, then forget about it.

And the only thing we have for leverage is tariffs themselves.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So I'm assuming that one of the enforcement mechanisms will just be the reintroduction of tariff.

BARTIROMO: What's the -- what's priced into the market already, Ryan? I mean do you think that the markets are expecting tariffs to stay in place or are they expecting that they won't go in place in December?

PAYNE: I think we're learning towards tariff won't be there in December because I think at this point --

BARTIROMO: The Dow increase.

PAYNE: Yes, I think the market's going up -- yes, the market's gone up a lot because we think we have some clarity around tariffs. And that's what we really need. I think the tariffs themselves aren't terrible. It's the fact we have no clarity and that's where capital expenditure, you know, really has been halted right now for companies. They need to have clarity around that. If they do, that's just huge for the markets and the economy.

ROSCHELLE: But, remember, the last 100 billion or so of goods that hasn't been subject to tariffs that got kicked to December 15th is this stuff, right?

PAYNE: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So it's all of the --

BARTIROMO: That's what I'm saying.

PAYNE: Yes, it's all the --

BARTIROMO: That's what I'm saying, what's priced in --

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Because there you have ten days before the Christmas holiday. You know, you've got shopping going on in December. That's going to mean higher prices for like --

ROSCHELLE: Right, and --

BARTIROMO: Which is bothering you as well.

ROSCHELLE: And maybe not for the holiday season, but certainly we buy this stuff all year round.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So I think it's going to be a big issue.

FREEMAN: I think no more tariffs is the market expectation generally. But if you could get rids of what's been imposed, this is -- this is rocket fuel, even more than for the stock market, for the economy. The president reasonably noting all of the achievement so far, but this quarter is looking pretty soft. Yes, we got a very good October jobs report, but the estimates for growth this quarter are not great.

So -- so if he wants that -- that boom heading into his re-election, it would be great to get a deal now that gets rid of all the tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Yes, no, that's -- that's a great point.

The president was very confident yesterday. You know, he went on about the accomplishments that this administration has had, but he's also -- he also basically said this impeachment is a scam and he feels going into this public hearings, today, and the rest of the week and next week, he feels that they're not going to do anything in term of changing people minds. We'll see about that.

Then there's the Federal Reserve. Jay Powell is testifying before the Congress' Joint Economic Committee later today. This is his first speech since signaling a pause in cutting interest rates about two weeks ago. The president weighed in on the Fed yesterday as well.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We are actively competing with nations who openly cut interest rates, so that now many are actually getting paid when they pay off their loan, known as negative interest. Who ever heard of such a thing? Give me some of that. Give me some of that money. I want some of that money. Our Federal Reserve doesn't let us do to.

We are competing against these other countries, nonetheless, and the Federal Reserve doesn't let us play at that game. It puts us at a competitive disadvantage to other countries.

BARTIROMO: Well, what do you think, Mitch? Any reaction (ph)?

ROSCHELLE: I've said -- I've said before, a real estate person wants to lowest interest rates possible.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So I'm not surprised by that.

But just think about our economy. And so -- so Germany is in recession. It's had two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth. So it's not a surprise that the central bank in the European Union is trying to stimulate that economy as much as they possibly can.

We had, to James' point, 1.9 percent growth. Maybe not the greatest number, but that's still a good sign.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So I don't think our economy can be compared to economies around the world. But what the president's trying to say is, if their interest rates are low and we're trying to be competitive, then maybe our interest rates should be low too.

BARTIROMO: But isn't there an expectation, though, that Europe can't generate any growth and yet the U.S., we're bottoming out here in terms of growth? I mean earnings were supposed to have the worst quarter this quarter, but get better in fourth quarter, get better in 2020.

Is that what the markets expected?

FREEMAN: Yes, and I'm -- I'm not sure what the president was really saying there because he seem to understand negative interest rates are insanity --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes. Yes.

FREEMAN: And it hasn't worked in Europe and it hasn't given them the growth and the job creation that they were hoping for.

BARTIROMO: And yet --

FREEMAN: And yet he's calling it a competitive advantage. Oh, why don't we punish savers and distorts our investment decisions just like they do?

Fortunately, there is less negative yielding debt around the world now than there was maybe six months ago. I hope we're on this path. I think people are starting to rule out in term of investor expectations that we will end up with negative rates in the United States. I hope not. That's a fundamental sign of weakness. I think people are getting more confident we're not going there. The economy's still in pretty good shape. But this is no competitive advantage for Europe over us.

ROSCHELLE: And our capital markets depend upon capital coming here in search of yield.

FREEMAN: Right.

PAYNE: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So --

FREEMAN: This is the magnet.

PAYNE: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

PAYNE: Investment wreaking havoc on the dollar too, and I think that's what he's focused on --

BARTIROMO: Goo point, yes.

PAYNE: Is that -- that -- you know, the dollar's been really, really strong here, which it's actually starting to come down, and I think that's because, to your point, Maria, I think that we're starting to see a trough in economies, not just the U.S. but around the world also. So --

BARTIROMO: And then there's the impeachment battle heating up this morning. The House will hold its first public hearings today. Acting ambassador to the Ukraine, Bill Taylor, and senior State Department official, George Kent, testifying together before the House Intel Committee.

James, your piece today in "The Journal," best of the web anonymity gains are those great really has so much been demanded of so many by so few unidentified sources.

FREEMAN: It's kind of amazing here where we have a -- an anonymous federal employee trying to overturn the results of an election where 120 million Americans who identify themselves voted to elect this president. So I'm hoping we get some transparency.

But specifically on George Kent interview today, he said internally at the State Department in 2015 or 2016 that he saw a problem with Hunter Biden's deal with Burisma, the Ukrainian national gas company. I'm hoping we get some questioning and Adam Schiff allows some questioning to dig into that, who else was concerned in the government, what else did they know about Hunter Biden's activities in that country.

BARTIROMO: I also thought it was interesting that you brought up this complaint filed last week that they're doing this GoFundMe page as well.

FREEMAN: Yes, this is the -- this is a Fox News scoop about a -- we now have a whistleblower on the whistleblower. So the second whistleblower is blowing the whistleblower and they're both anonymous, saying that his GoFundMe page for his legal expenses may have a problem because some donors may be anonymous.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Speaking of anonymous, there are also anonymous people telling Hillary Clinton, putting enormous pressure on her apparently to run. So we've got to get into that today. She said many, many, many, many people are telling her she should run in 2020.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So we're going get to that.

We're going to talk a short break.

When we come back, we're just getting started this morning. On deck this morning, former CIA station chief and Fox News contributor Daniel Hoffman is here on the Hong Kong violence. Arizona Congressman, House Judiciary Committee member Andy Biggs is joining us on the impeachment inquiry, and former White House press secretary, Fox News contributor, Sarah Sanders here talking about impeachment, plus the founder of CEO of Activate Michael Wolf is here giving us his update on the Disney Plus streaming rollout. We want to see what his take is. Don't miss a moment of it.

Meanwhile, let's slip in a short break. Then Google is under pressure once again. The federal government now looking into the technology giant after "The Wall Street Journal" broke the story that it secretly gained access to private health records across the country. We're going to tell you about that one.

Then Disney Plus downer. The new streaming service plagued with error message and long waits, apparently. We're going to take a look at that rollout which happened yesterday.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We talked to you about this story yesterday. Google's gathering of health record data. That is catching the eye of lawmakers now.

Cheryl Casone with the details here.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well, here you go, Maria, concerns over Google gathering detailed health information on Americans has led to a federal inquiry. This according to a report in "The Journal." Google's Project Nightingale is a deal with Ascension Health, which is meant to improve patient care, but the data gathering and the cloud storage is raising privacy and safety concern.

Well, the world's largest contract electronics maker posted about $1 billion in revenue for the third quarter. Foxconn saw profit rise 23.3 percent despite its biggest customer Apple seeing declining iPhone sales. The Taiwan-based company relies on Apple for about half of its revenue.

Then there is this, President Trump and Apple's CEO Tim Cook are expected to tour facilities in Texas where Apple products are made. This visit could happen as soon as next week and reportedly showcase companies that, well, keep jobs in America. The trip coming as Cook seek further relief from U.S. tariffs on imports from China. Back to that iPhone story. Apple stock in the pre-market down about half a percent.

And then there was this, a rocky technical start anyway for Disney's streaming service debut. So many folks were looking for a whole new role to content, at little joke, on Disney Plus, but they were hit with long waits and error messages. That was high demand, though. In fact, demand was so high, servers couldn't even keep up. So some would-be customers were prevented from signing up for the service yesterday. People, of course, went on social media, Maria, and they complain about it. But the criticism died down as Disney addressed all of the issues. Disney, of course, is down almost half a percent in the pre-market, Maria. Let's hope, you know, not really bad news, kind of good news, people were all over this thing yesterday.

BARTIROMO: And not unexpected.

CASONE: No.

BARTIROMO: It's a new service. You're always going to see, well, I don't know.

CASONE: Some new "Star Wars" shows apparently, which I'm getting ready to tune into, but I haven't been able to sign up yet (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: The content is incredible for Disney. I mean Netflix is going to have to pay, what, did it say $15 billion every year or certainly $15 billion next year after $13 billion this year to keep up with all the content.

FREEMAN: Yes, I would think execution issues are about only thing that can stop Disney --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: Because you look at the library, it's phenomenal.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it really is.

Al right, we'll take a break.

When we come back, wicked weather. It is freezing out. Icy conditions causing a 50 car pile-up in Ohio. The deep freeze is just beginning. We've got your full forecast when we come right back.

And then focus on the Federal Reserve. Jay Powell will testify today in Washington for the first time since putting his paws on interest rate cuts. We're taking a look at what to expect.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are looking at the U.S. economy this morning. President Trump speaking at the Economic Club of New York yesterday criticizing the policies of Democratic lawmakers.

Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Washington's Democrats and their radical agenda of socialism would demolish our economy reinstate the avalanche of regulations that have already ended, decimate the middle class and totally bankrupt our nation. As long as I'm president, America will never be a socialist country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce is slamming 2020 candidate Elizabeth Warren's plan to dramatically change rules for private equity firms, calling it a catalyst for grave economic consequences.

Joining us right now to talk about all of that is Cardone Capital fund manager, 10X movement founder, and "The 10X Rule" author Grant Cardone.

Grant, great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

GRANT CARDONE, FUND MANAGER, CARDONE CAPITAL: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: In a second I want you to explain the 10X rule. But let's talk capitalism versus socialism for a second because it look like this is what's sort of gearing up for the 2020 election.

CARDONE: You know, I moved out of California because they -- the socialist influence there, and taking my taxes from 10 percent to 13. Everybody's like, oh, it's only 3 point. It was a 30 percent increase. Moved all of our companies to Miami, where I knew no one, and we grew the company 50 time because we saved 13 percent.

So I think the people missed the idea or the concept that when I get a savings, I actually, as a business person, want to reinvest. I don't to just keep the money.

BARTIROMO: And that enables you to create job.

CARDONE: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Increase wages.

CARDONE: And this is what the entrepreneur does, they take money and time and they risk it in order to get more time and money.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

So there's an editorial in "The Wall Street Journal" this morning that we wanted to highlight, and it is critical of this new tax proposals by Democratic politicians. As the president suggested yesterday, like the recently unveiled millionaire sir tax, that would put an extra 10 percent tax on any individual income above $1 million, $2 million for married couple.

But it's not just ordinary income. It will also tax capital gains, for example. And the article goes on to say all the other things that the Democrats are proposing. Listen to this. Democrats are also proposing raising the regular income tax rate, the corporate tax rate, the capital gains tax rate, the dividend tax rates, the death tax, the payroll tax rates, creating a new wealth tax and a new financial transactions tax, a new carbon tax, a new pharmaceutical tax, even as they would repeal 100 percent business expensing and 20 percent income exclusion for so-called pass through firms.

You couldn't do anything that you were doing in terms of creating jobs (INAUDIBLE) --

CARDONE: I would move out of the country.

BARTIROMO: What, you would move out of the country?

CARDONE: I've already moved once, I'll move again. I told my wife when we moved to Miami, I said, this might not be our last move. So that is the freedom of living in this country, is that I'm free to move wherever I want.

BARTIROMO: And money is mobile, James.

FREEMAN: It is.

You know, I'm glad you brought up that point about what happens when there's more money into business.

CARDONE: Yes.

FREEMAN: And I think it's important because so often this is presented as, billionaires, they have so much. We need to take some of it. And whatever you think of sort of philosophically how much someone ought to pay, the question is, do you want that next dollar spent by the Washington bureaucracy or by this investor and vender, entrepreneur? And where -- where is America going to get the best return? You look at the job creation, the invention that happens in the private economy versus government, it's really no contest.

CARDONE: Absolutely. Like, what we pay in property taxes in Florida, Texas, these are both zero state tax -- income tax. But property taxes on $1.5 billion is about $30 million a year in property taxes. So while I might not be paying income taxes in those states, I am still contributing, I'm adding jobs, I'm adding to payroll.

If these -- some of these things that Maria just went over happened, I would not be hiring. I wouldn't go from 50 employees to 185 employee.

BARTIROMO: You couldn't.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

And when you weaponnize profits in the rhetoric, you don't realize that company like Amazon create -- have 750,000 employee, right?

CARDONE: Yes. Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So what do you think's happening? You know, they're creating something and they're creating livelihoods for hundreds of thousands of people.

CARDONE: I think that list could go on and on, you know.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, right.

Real quick before you go, Grant, the ten times rule, what does it mean?

CARDONE: The 10X rule is a multiplier. It's about the -- it's a conversation to the middle class that they have to learn how to scale. They learn how to save money. They learn how to make money. They know how to work hard, but they haven't learned how to scale their money and multiply money so that they can actually have freedom.

BARTIROMO: How do you do it?

CARDONE: And this is what Jamie Dimon was saying a couple of days ago about this is the best economy and forever, but the middle class is not feeling that because they're -- the middle class is still buying homes, trying to save money. Saving money today is not what it was 20 years ago. People should not be saving money, they should be burning cash, investing in their business, investing in their brands, advertising, rather than leaving it at the bank. They have to learn how to scale money.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's a rock bottom interest rates, so you're not really making anything on your money.

CARDONE: You're losing money.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're losing money in some corner certainly.

Grant, congrats. Thanks so much.

CARDONE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to have you this morning. Grant Cardone joining us there.

Coming up, the chaos in Hong Kong continued overnight. Schools are now closing for the first time since the protests begun. More violent demonstrations breaking out in the city. We are going to take you there when we come back.

And then the deep freeze back in the U.S. A 50 cars pileup in Ohio causing an icy traffic nightmare as the majority of the country is seeing the mercury take a nose dive this week. We will have the full forecast when we come right back.

Stay with us.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back.

Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Good morning to you, I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, November 13th.

Your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

There is some new China trade uncertainty this morning. President Trump says phase one of a deal could happen soon, but also threatens tariff hikes if no deal is actually reached.

The push for impeachment goes on. The public hearings will kick off today. It's a big week in Washington. We are taking a look at what to expect from these hearings this morning and what it could mean for trade deals that are still waiting on approval.

The future of the U.S. economy. Investors are waiting on Fed Chair Jay Powell today. His testimony happen on Capitol Hill this morning. We are looking for any hints at where rates could be headed next.

Markets this morning are under pressure going into all of that. Take a look. Futures down 111 point right now on the Dow. S&P futures down 12 and the Nasdaq futures lower by 41. The Nasdaq closed at a record high yesterday. Meanwhile, we are still in historic, uncharted territory. The S&P 500 hit an historic intra-day high yesterday. It closed 1.25 points shy of a new all-time high. The Dow unchanged, first time that's happened since April of 2014.

Global market this morning look like this. Take a look at European indices. And we are seeing selling there as well. The FT 100 down 35, CAC quarante in Paris down 27. DAX index in Germany town 99.

In Hong Kong, continued protesting overnight. Concerns that the U.S. could be imposing more tariffs on Chinese goods, pushing markets lower in Asia across the board. Worst performer, Hong Kong, down almost 2 percent.

And then there's this. The big chill. Most of America waking up to a very cold day today. The forecast coming your way, coming up.

But first, our top story this half an hour, the chaos in Hong Kong. Anti- government protests ranging in the city center for the third straight day, prompting the government to close down public schools tomorrow.

Joining us right now is Fox News contributor, former CIA station chief, who served in Moscow, Iraq and Pakistan, Daniel Hoffman.

Daniel, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

DANIEL HOFFMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: You too. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the Hong Kong protests. What strikes you most here? Is it what it's done to Hong Kong, how the world perceives Hong Kong? China's authoritarian rule or something else? I mean what do you take away from this?

HOFFMAN: What strikes me is their staying power. These protests have been ongoing since March. It's a clash of civilization between this brutally repressive communist Chinese dictatorship and brave Hong Kongers who were protesting to try to preserve some of their basic human rights.

BARTIROMO: You know it's interesting that even though they put the extradition bill aside, that the Hong Kongers don't trust the Chinese are going to let up, even though Carrie Lam says that the extradition bill is not actually happening.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Right. And they -- obviously they want investigation on police brutality. They want the promises of 1997 to be fulfilled in terms of the traditional freedoms that the people of Hong Kong have long enjoyed.

And, Daniel, I'm wondering, related to that, how you think this ends? It -- I see Carrie Lam has lost confidence on basically all sides, the chief executive of Hong Kong, but how does this get resolved if it can be resolved?

HOFFMAN: I'm not sure that it can. I think Hong Kong is a real existential threat to China because of their focus on preserving what little democracy they still retain. Remember, Carrie Lam was China's hand-picked leader of Hong Kong back in 2017 and one of the demands from the protesters is that she resign, as well as a number of other demands, including permanently withdrawing that extradition bill which cause so much concern.

There's a lot of financial pain that Hong Kong is facing in the financial market. And that, I don't think, is going to be enough to induce China to back down. They're concerned about the impact on mainland Chinese who see democracy uprising in Hong Kong.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

You know -- you know, Mitch, how much pain will China take? I mean what -- Daniel makes a good point in terms of the stock market in Hong Kong, but it's also the perception of Hong Kong. I've said this many times, I always thought of Hong Kong as an international hub that could go right head-to- head compete with London, compete with New York. I don't see it that way anymore.

As a business guy, the both of you, I mean do you see it that way?

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: It used to be, if you want to take a company public and you didn't want to do it in the United States, you would do it in Hong Kong.

BARTIROMO: Right. That's right.

ROSCHELLE: If you want to declare transaction, you do it through a bank in Hong Kong.

Right now businesspeople are not going there. And the thing that strike me, and I'm curious about this, Daniel, is the protesters are the young. So they're looking at their future and saying, we don't want the future the way we project that it may happen. And it's hard to change their views. So this may be -- it's a permanent thing there that they just don't believe in the -- the prospects of ever being really independent.

HOFFMAN: They also have a keen sense of history. This year, August 23rd, they held a human chain, hundreds of thousands of Hong Kongers holding hands to protest and to try to preserve their democracy. They chose that date because it was the date of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact of 1939. There was the famous Baltic human chain in 1989 commemorating the 60 years of that secret pact which divided eastern Europe between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union.

I do believe they've got great staying power and they're looking to the United States for support, frankly.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOFFMAN: And I think that's a key element for them.

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Daniel do you see Beijing placating them here, actually making some compromises, real compromises? Is that realistic at this point?

HOFFMAN: I think one of the challenges -- listen, Hong Kong has a long history of protest going back in 2003, the most famous of which arguably the umbrella movement in 2014. This one is spiraling, increasing violence, increasing concern that China will intervene militarily. They've got a lot of troops stationed in the mainland overlooking Hong Kong.

I just think that the longer this goes on, the higher the risk is that this could get even bloodier. And, again, I think it's an existential threat for China.

And, you know, China doesn't -- knows there would be great risk in bringing violence to Hong Kong, greater than we've seen so far.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOFFMAN: But, at the same time, the concern is they may be forced to do so, and that would be obviously just extraordinarily tragic for the people there and have its impact on financial market.

BARTIROMO: Daniel, I want to move on to Turkey in a second, but let me just tell you what a friend of mine who's in Hong Kong right now -- actually he's in China -- and he said, in terms of the Hong Kong story, there's a common belief amongst the Chinese that it's the U.S. intel agency behind and supporting this unrest. This -- what do they call it, the quiet hand of the United States.

Do you think that that's what the Chinese leadership thinks, that the U.S. is somehow behind this?

HOFFMAN: No, I don't -- I don't think they believe that, but I think what they're trying to do is taint the protest movement by associating it with the United States intelligence wars (ph).

BARTIROMO: I see.

HOFFMAN: In fact, an indigenous movement striving for democracy. And then that's what scares China the most, democracy.

BARTIROMO: Real quick on Turkey. The president of Turkey, Erdogan, visiting the White House today amid a lot of controversy there. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting that U.S. drones appear to show Turkish back forces in Syria targeting civilians after the U.S. forces took a step back from fighting in region.

Your reaction to what take place at the White House today when Erdogan visits the president?

HOFFMAN: That's certainly a key area of concern that Turks are using their proxy forces. The Syrian National Army, made up of Sunni Arab fighters to ethnically displace the Kurds and carry on the fight against Assad.

The concern for the United States is that lost in that is the need to fight ISIS. And I think the Turks are more focused on is ethnic displacement of the Kurds and that safe zone and less focused on -- on the -- on the ongoing threat from those ISIS terrorists.

BARTIROMO: All right, Daniel, we'll leave it there. Great to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

HOFFMAN: You too.

BARTIROMO: Daniel Hoffman.

Be sure to tune into Fox Business, 3:00 p.m. this afternoon for President Trump's live news conference with Erdogan. We will take that live, so do join us later on today at 3.

Meanwhile, we go to the extreme weather now. White-out conditions causing an unimaginative 50 car pileup on an Ohio highway yesterday. Take a look at this. Freezing temperatures stretching across the United States this morning. It is just getting started, apparently.

Fox News senior meteorologist Janice Dean with a full forecast right now.

Janice.

JANICE DEAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR METEOROLOGIST: Maria, the big story across the country is the cold air, record setting cold, 70 percent of the country right now below freezing. There are your current temperatures right now, 12 in Chicago, 25 in Dallas, 31 in Houston, Texas. We actually saw snow as far south as Texas yesterday. That's the wind chill. That's what it feels like out there. Single digit, teens here in New York City, it feels like 11 degrees. Temperatures reminiscent of January.

We have freeze advisories stretching across the Gulf Coast in towards the southeast, that's how cold it is. Twenty-four-hour temperature change. Look at what it was this time yesterday. Over 30 degrees warmer here in New York City.

The good news is, it's short-lived. The bad news is, we're still steeling (ph) the potential for snow across the Great Lakes and the upper Midwest, places that saw over two feet of snow. So lake effect snow is going to be ongoing throughout the next couple of day, but we will see some relief in terms of temperatures. Starting this weekend into early next week, much of the country will be above average.

So there's your silver lining. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Janice, thank you. We like that silver lining. Janice Dean.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Cheryl Casone with the details there.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: This is something else, Maria. Mayor Pete Buttigieg taking a slight lead in Iowa according to a new poll. The Mammoth University survey shows that Buttigieg at 22 percent along likely Democratic caucus goers in Iowa. Former Vice President Joe Biden stands at 19 percent there. Senator Warren taking 18 percent. Senator Bernie Sanders at 13 percent. Buttigieg's 3 percentage point advantage over Biden is within the poll's margin of error, but represents a remarkable surge over the last few months for him, about (ph) 16 points since August actually.

Well, so much coffee. The world's largest Starbucks is opening in Chicago. The company making another big belt on the consumer with the four-story complex. Fox Business' Jeff Fox spoke exclusively with CEO Kevin Johnson about the economy and the American consumer.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN JOHNSON, CEO, STARBUCKS: So thus far, in the U.S. anyway, I think we're seeing very healthy consumer sentiment.

JEFF FOX, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: You don't have worries about the future? I mean I'm sure you're always concerned, but --

JOHNSON: Well, look, we -- you know, we've been in business 49 years. We've had to navigate a wide range of macroeconomic and geopolitical situations. And we will in the future. But right now I think what we're seeing is a healthy consumer.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Johnson also said he hasn't seen any backlash from the ongoing trade dispute with China at the 4,100 Starbucks stores that are located in China.

And there is there, Colin Kaepernick getting another shot at the NFL. According to a memo obtained by ESPN, he's holding a private workout to evaluate his readiness and interest in reviving his stalled career. Now, Kaepernick has been on the sidelines since 2016 after sparking lead wide national anthem protests.

I should point out, guys, when he was with the 49ers in 2016, he played in 12 games, he started 11 of those, and, guys, his team won one game. The workout scheduled for this Saturday, we'll see who shows up. I'm just pointing that out.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Thanks, Cheryl.

What do you guys think?

FREEMAN: Yes, he had some good years and then some not good year and so you wonder what's the upside here. Does he add that much to your team as probably a backup quarterback for the baggage that he bring. And you're thinking about, what is an NFL city where people don't like cops and don't like the flag and the anthem. That's hard to think of one.

PAYNE: Yes.

I think -- I mean you've got to give him credit. I think he's great at promotion. You know, at the end of the day, I think this seems a little bit like a promotional type of cause for himself. But, I mean, that's kind of what he's very good at.

BARTIROMO: For himself, not for the NFL. Remember what happened during that whole NFL controversy over kneeling. Ratings went down. People were done with it. They didn't want to have this controversy on the football field.

ROSCHELLE: And there are a couple of upstart league that are trying to get off the ground and I don't know that they're going to want that kind of attention. But some say there's no such thing as bad publicity, so we never know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PAYNE: I would agree with that, actually.

BARTIROMO: We'll see.

We're looking at market and looking ahead to a lot happening in Washington today.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are zeroing in on real estate this morning. Senior housing developers added more than 21,000 new units in 2018. That doubled the number added in 2014 according to the National Investment Center for Seniors Housing and Care. Now developers are facing a new challenge, baby boomers are ditching senior housing, preferring to stay in their homes.

Join us right now is Waypoint Real Estate Investments CEO Scott Lawlor.

And, Scott, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

SCOTT LAWLOR, CEO, WAYPOINT REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We want to zero in on seniors but also on your focus of rental housing.

But, first, tell us what's going on with seniors right now.

LAWLOR: So, you know, senior housing has attracted a lot of capital because everyone understands the long-term demographic story, which is very, very compelling. I fear that some of the capitalist showed up a little early. I think there's maybe a lack of understanding of the fact that the real demographic bulge, if you will, is about 10 years out. But the --

BARTIROMO: That's when the baby boomers will start retiring --

LAWLOR: Correct.

BARTIROMO: And wanting these senior housing facilities.

LAWLOR: Yes. Well, they might still start retiring sooner than that, but they're not going to seriously think about assisted living, independent living, this kind of thing. Typically into the early 80s, and the boomers are maybe mid-70s right now with the oldest.

BARTIROMO: I gotcha.

LAWLOR: So there's a ways to go before that demographic bulge really, really hits. And what's happened is a lot of capital showed up ahead of that.

That's OK, you know, so there will be some pockets of softness in the short run, but in the long run I think it's a very, very compelling story. So are seniors wanting to stay at home, like my parents do, or are they wanting these senior facilities?

LAWLOR: So there's a lot of discussion about whether there will be less demand for senior facilities for that reason. But the fact is, I think there will be different preference for different people. And, you know, sadly, it depends, to some degree, on your personal circumstance. Some seniors, as you get into your 80s, whether it's family, spouse, friends whathaver -- what have you, will be seeking more communal environment and some who have the ability financially, and from a personal perspective to stay in the home will choose to do that, but there will be plenty of demand for the product we're talking about.

BARTIROMO: Mitch.

ROSCHELLE: One of the things that we've talked about on the show is how the baby boomers have this tremendous amount of wealth that they've accumulated and they're, at some point, going to transfer it to their children. But if they have all that wealth, is much of that tied up in their homes? Is that the reality of the wealth of the baby bomber generation?

BARTIROMO: This is such an important -- I love this story. "Forbes" first reported it, that there's going to be this massive transfer of wealth from baby boomers to their kids, millennials and a little older, of $68 trillion in the next ten years. That's the story you're talking about.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. And if it's tied up in their homes, are they going to monetize that or are they just going to sort of live off of it with reverse mortgages and all of that sort of stuff?

LAWLOR: I think a lot will monetize it.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

LAWLOR: I mean as you get to a stage where you're make a living decision, I think the living -- you know, the living decision will prevail over whether or not to monetize the home. In other words, if what you're saying is, are they going to hang on just to hang on, I mean, you don't need to hang on to your home to transfer wealth, right?

ROSCHELLE: Right. Yes. Fair enough.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PAYNE: Well, just look on other side of that too, like millennials now are getting to a stage where they're looking to buy homes. Do you see that really driving the overall real estate market moving forward because now they have a -- you have a shortage there for starter homes and things like that on the other side.

LAWLOR: Yes, that's another place we're undersupplied is starter level home.

PAYNE: Yes.

LAWLOR: The millennial story is a big one and it's an interesting one because some millennials are getting to the, you know, the stage where you typically think about get married, have kids, move to the suburbs and so on. I don't know that there's as strong a view about owning though, OK, because the millennials are the first generation in several that witnessed, you know, the opposite direction in home values.

PAYNE: Yes.

LAWLOR: We have 70 years in a role where home value only went one way. So it's sort of a law of the universe of the United States, the best thing you can do with your dough is buy a home. The millennials, right, saw it, whether they were in high school or college during the crash, saw their parents suffer tremendous wealth destruction because of home value. Not to say a lot of them won't want to own a home --

PAYNE: Yes, I rent.

LAWLOR: But it's not -- it's not as prevalent as it used to be. So, for instance, one strategy we're looking at is ground up development of single family homes for rent, because we think that might be a solution. You might want the backyard and all, but not want to --

PAYNE: Rent to own or just to rent?

LAWLOR: Just to rent. Just to rent. You might want the living experience but not the financial drain.

BARTIROMO: What about the college story. Some parents apparently putting money that they'd spend on a college room and board into local real estate. They're, instead, putting their kids in an apartment. Your firm has properties in college towns in America. What's the trend there?

LAWLOR: Yes, so we're -- have been very active in the student housing business the last few year and I've heard a bit about what you're describing where, you know, rather than rent an apartment for your son or daughter, you'll buy them a condo unit say. I don't know if it's as big a trend as some of the, you know, the headlines might suggest. It's not really driving the market per se.

BARTIROMO: OK.

LAWLOR: The student housing business has experienced a little patchiness the last couple year as well. There's been a lot of new supply there too. Capital has just been looking for something to do in the rental housing space, frankly. But we're also long-term believers. There's a whole host of reasons we like this space. You know, most importantly, students taste preferences and, in fact, maybe demands have changed dramatically. And most existing stock does not comport with current preferences.

ROSCHELLE: I'm looking at the map. I see you have a Michigan. If you have a place in Ann Arbor, we'll talk after the --

LAWLOR: (INAUDIBLE).

FREEMAN: Oh, I was just going to ask if investing in home renovations in suburban New Jersey is a good idea. Because I'm sure a lot of viewers (INAUDIBLE).

PAYNE: Only appreciates.

LAWLOR: Absolutely. A new kitchen.

FREEMAN: All right, well, I lost that argument.

BARTIROMO: Scott, great to have you. Thanks so much.

LAWLOR: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great insight from you. Scott Lawlor joining us there.
