urn:contentItem:5JXB-C931-JBHT-D1X5-00000-00Trump Speaks about Donations to Veterans Charities; Trump Speaks about Media and Party Leaders; Democratic California Primary Next Week;2016-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisTrump Speaks about Donations to Veterans Charities; Trump Speaks about Media and Party Leaders; Democratic California Primary Next Week;LanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Press should be ashamed of themselves. And on behalf of the vets, the press should be ashamed of themselves. They are calling me and they are furious because I sent people checks of a lot of money.

And we're going to give you the names right now which is what you want, and instead of being like thank you very much, Mr. Trump or Trump did a good job, everyone said, who got it, who got it, who got it? And you make me look very bad. I have never received such bad publicity for doing such a good job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: Donald Trump speaking from Trump tower about his donations to veteran's charities.

This is Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

Donald Trump says he raised close to $6 million for veterans organizations and named ones that received money. He says that if he is president he will hit back at the press if they write false stories just as he will hit back at party leaders that don't support him.

With me now, Katrina Pierson, Trump campaign spokesperson. Katrina, welcome back. Glad to see you.

KATRINA PIERSON, DONALD TRUMP NATIONAL SPOKESPERSON: Great to be here. Thank you.

BOLTON: So, Trump supporters admire his fighting spirit. Rush Limbaugh started his radio show this morning with this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, CONSERVATIVE RADIO HOST: People have been begging for all republican to just once take on the media the way Trump did.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Katrina, how much feedback on that 40-minute press conference are you getting?

PIERSON: Tons of feedback. You know, my inbox is so full right now from so many people across the country saying finally, this is one of those situations where, when Mr. Trump held this, when he held this fund-raiser, this was a spontaneous fund-raiser put it together within 24 hours.

We had been saying it will take a little bit of time to vet some of these organizations to bring in the money that was pledged by the way, not on hand. And for weeks, and almost every day we heard about the veterans fund- raisers and where is the money.

Mr. Trump is not politician. Mr. Trump has been doing things for people his whole life. So, this idea that somehow there was some animus reason that Mr. Trump did this, I mean, it really showed today in the media is now covering of the actual fund-raiser really goes to show, and people are so fed up and frustrated with the hypocrisy on the way republicans are covered versus the way democrats are covered or lack there off.

BOLTON: So you feel like there is clearly a bias, but speaking of democrats, Hillary Clinton's campaigns is planning series of events to take on Trump's record on vet's issues.

So, her campaign apparently is going to have speakers who are all vets, I should state in Virginia, Pennsylvania, and New Hampshire, Florida, Colorado, so all battleground states. Are you planning to counter that counter?

PIERSON: Well, I'm sure we will. I mean, this is one of those -- one of those issues that Mr. Trump has been extremely strong on. And, you know, there are two groups of people that I've seen personally Mr. Trump get a little emotional about.

And that is veterans who have been treated completely unfairly. When you have illegal aliens that are getting treatment faster than veterans that's absurd. And this is a Hillary Clinton policy by the way, someone that's been in office, someone that has been in public life, the first lady being a senator and Secretary of State and has done what for veterans?

Absolutely nothing. This is something close to Mr. Trump's heart. And over the campaign trail when he saw an opportunity to do something for veterans, he did it. He took action. And that's the kind of leader that we need.

BOLTON: Now speaking of fighting, so he's obviously fighting Hillary Clinton and it looks like that is going to be the match up in November, although TBD on the democratic side but he is still fighting within the party.

I mean, he tweeted out his response to Bill Kristol calling for a strong independent third party candidate. He says, "The Republican Party has to be smart and strong if it wants win in November. Can't allow lightweight," so everyone assumes the reference to Kristol, "to set up a spoiler in the candidate."

And then he also tweeted, "If dummy Bill Kristol actually does get as spoiler to run as independent, say good-bye to the Supreme Court." But aside from Bill Kristol, aside from Mitt Romney and we are pretty sure that Bill Kristol has Mitt Romney in mind, how is the unification plan going from your point of view?

PIERSON: Well, the way you pose the question is exactly what's happening. The party is with Mr. Trump. He has broken a record in GOP primary turnout. And there is just handful of republicans, establishment republicans who want status quo. They want to keep things the same. And they know we'll have that with Hillary Clinton.

But for the most part Mr. Trump is unifying the party. Reince Priebus, chairman of the RNC said it's time to get behind the front-runner. We have so many people with the RNC and in the states, we now have state chairman coming on board.

So, this unification process is moving along, particularly now that we've now several endorsements on the Hill, whether congressional chairman or just other members in the party. Those who don't want to get on board are those who want to keep the things the same way.

And those who have been rejected twice now by the people, Mr. Trump transcends party even though he's unifying Republican Party, he is unifying the American people with a pro-America message.

BOLTON: OK. But one thing I wanted to ask when you talk about pro-America and unification, there are some who say he unfairly went after New Mexico Governor Susanna Martinez, and it relates to what I want to ask you about.

Because he is going after the judge who is ordering the release of the Trump University documents, bringing up the judge's Mexican heritage. Here is the comment. I just want to circle back with you after.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I have a judge who is a hater of Donald Trump, a hater. He is a hater.

(CROWD BOOING)

His name is, Gonzalo Curiel, the judge who happened to be, we believe Mexican which is great. I think that's fine. You know what he what? I think the Mexicans are going to end up loving Donald Trump when I give all these jobs, OK?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, on one hand should the judge recuse himself and on the other hand, how do you see Donald Trump's outreach to the Latino population?

PIERSON: Well, look, this judge is a problem. He does not like Mr. Trump. This is activist judge appointed by Barack Obama because Barack Obama wouldn't appoint anyone other than an activist judge.

And there was great article just released today in the American Spectator that gives specific details about this judge. And the simple fact that he is the friend of the lawyer on the opposite side. So, he should absolutely recuse himself.

But it's important that Mr. Trump mention that for a reason because we do see a lot of these anti-Trump protesters who are very much pushing the anti-American message of the way they're behaving at some of the rallies on the outside and waving the Mexican flag. They're holding up La Raza signs.

These are very much important details that the mainstream media is leaving out. So it's going to be up to Mr. Trump to get that word out.

BOLTON: And just to finish the point, what do you make of the relationship with the governor of New Mexico, Martinez?

PIERSON: Look, Governor Martinez was a never Trumper to begin with. I mean, she has said things publicly against Mr. Trump and Mr. Trump is a counterpuncher.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So some people think she would be a great V.P.

PIERSON: Well, not Mr. Trump, obviously. But look, Mr. Trump doesn't see party. He doesn't see race, and he doesn't see gender. He just wants to do what is right for the country. He wants to get back to common sense government. And he is counterpuncher.

She criticized him, he criticized her. And just because she is a woman or just because she is Latino means nothing. Mr. Trump is going to treat everyone the same and it's been that way from the beginning.

BOLTON: It certainly has been. Katrina, thank you. Glad to have you with us.

PIERSON: Great to be here.

BOLTON: Katrina Pierson joining me there, she is a spokesperson for the Donald Trump campaign.

Well, with more on the subject, how Donald Trump handled the media on his donations to veterans, he did turn over the microphone to a vet from New Hampshire. Here are that vet's comments.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL BALDASARO, VETERAN: Stop using veterans as political pawns. You got a guy outside, McCoy, go do a Google search on his Facebook. He is out there, his picture is with the Clintons. They are using veterans as political pawns and it must stop.

Donald Trump is doing this from the heart. You're all focused on the way he is raising money and you're not looking at 22 veterans that are killing each other every day. You're not concerned about the thousands of veterans that are on wait lists.

Look at his plan on his Trump web site. He talks about medical cards. He talks about fixing the V.A. He talks about competition. I think the liberal media and I've been dealing with you a long time and get your head out of your butt and focus on the real issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My political power panel is here. Jillian Melcher, Heat Street political editor, republican strategist, Mercedes Schlapp; and democratic strategist Holly Shulman. Welcome to you all. So, Gillian, in your view how did Trump handle the press conference?

JILLIAN MELCHIOR, HEAT STREET POLITICAL EDITOR: I don't think he handled it wonderfully. I mean, it's great for the Washington Post to follow up on this. He made a commitment to help veterans to support them that was widely viewed...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, I just want to cut you off so everybody else follows.

MELCHIOR; Yes.

BOLTON: So, many people saw this 40-minute press conference as response to a piece written in the Washington Post which was essentially, was not titled, where is the money but that is essentially the point of the piece.

MELCHIOR: Exactly, they could not find a single veteran's organizations that had received one the $1 million that Trump said he'd given. So, there is a lot of speculation, a lot of question. All of sudden Trump produces the check. He says it's supposed to be about scrutiny about vetting the charity...

BOLTON: But he has given out more than three million.

MELCHIOR: Well, he ended up doing it, but he's saying that vetting is the reason for four-month delay.

BOLTON: Right.

MELCHIOR: But he ended up giving it to a guy who runs a charity, who's not only running charity, he works for the SoHo Trump. So, this is somebody within his own corporation. I think the vetting excuse doesn't hold water.

I think he needs to be held accountable for this and it's fair for The Washington Post reporters to ask these questions.

BOLTON: But in fairness, I take all your point, in fairness to Trump, he got out there and pretty much delineated Excel's spreadsheet line, by spreadsheet line, where the money came from, where it's going. Mercedes, what is your take?

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Well, I've got to tell you I'm still waiting to see how much money Hillary Clinton has given to any of the vets. Let's be realistic here.

This is a guy who made a promise that he was going to give millions of dollars to veterans groups. I've never really seen a presidential candidate take such interest in insuring that these veterans get the help that they need.

With that being said, I do believe that he has a special connections with the veterans groups. I think that he is true to his word. I think when you look at Hillary Clinton and the fact that she's made millions of dollars off of these Wall Street speeches, and yet, she is trying to hit Donald Trump on the fact of whether he is giving the money or how much money he has given? Fine.

I think that it's the media's responsibility to, yes, check and make sure that he is delivering on his promise but at the same time, I mean, he is taking an unconventional approach which Hillary Clinton doesn't even know how to respond to.

BOLTON: So, Holly, since you're our democratic voice, what is your take on that, especially in light of the Clinton campaign planning this whole series of counterattacks if we're going to call them that for the next few days to try to reach out to veterans?

HOLLY SHULMAN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: One thing has been clear through this whole process and that's Donald Trump only cares about veterans when it's politically expedient for him. And that's what we've seen today.

Hillary Clinton, despite the political benefits has reached across the aisle, worked with Senator John McCain for $50 million for veterans rehab center in Texas. She's worked with Lindsey Graham to expand health care for reservists, for National Guard.

And she has a career of working on these issues and fighting for veterans. And if he wants to make this an issue in the campaign I would say, bring it on.

BOLTON: All right. We're going to have more to talk about. Jillian, Mercedes, Holly all back with me. In the meantime, we want to let you know Donald Trump dismissing libertarian presidential candidate Gary Johnson as a fringe candidate earlier today.

Mr. Johnson will be Kennedy's guest tonight. Tune in. You do not want to miss the conversation, 8 p.m. Eastern Time.

Looking at the markets averages on mix, the last straight day of the month. The Dow, NASDAQ, and the S&P, all up for May, making the Dow and the S&P 500's longest monthly winning streak in two years. If you look at the leading groups, tech, health care and finance.

Well, next Tuesday the all-important California primary on the democratic side. It is getting too close for comfort. Hillary Clinton canceling a New Jersey event to head out to the Golden State early.

Former republican presidential candidate Tim Pawlenty will tell me if he thinks Senator Sanders can beat Hillary Clinton in California. He is with me next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNIE SANDERS, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: If you promise not to tell Secretary Clinton, she is getting very nervous lately and I don't want, I don't want to add to her anxiety. So if you promise not to tell her, we're going to win here in California on June 7th.

(CROWD CHEERING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: California primary is on Tuesday. Hillary Clinton's campaign wants to avoid an embarrassing loss to Senator Sanders in the golden state.

A new Hoover Foundation poll shows that Clinton with a commanding lead, 51 to 38 percent. But last week another poll showed the democratic candidates in a statistical dead heat.

Clinton is cutting short scheduled New Jersey stops to get to California for a full five days. With me now, former republican presidential candidate, former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty. He is current Trump supporter.

Governor, glad to see you. If Senator Sanders beats Hillary Clinton in California, what does that mean, if anything, for the general election in November?

TIM PAWLENTY, FORMER MINNESOTA GOVERNOR: Well, if you accept the proposition that she is going to be the nominee, and I think that's clear that she will be, he is looking for leverage and the ability to advance some agenda or some position that I presume he is interested in.

But winning California at least gives him a chance to go to those unpledged delegates, the so-called super delegates and what I think is a rigged system by the way, and try to say hey, look, I won the biggest state. This should change your view. I don't think that's going to work.

But, you know, he is now starting to talk about what he perhaps get out of the convention and it gives him leverage, basically.

BOLTON: So, it seems as if he wants, to your point, some sort of role, whether it's influencing policy or perhaps having a bigger say than he normally would have in a V.P. pick?

PAWLENTY: Well, there is some speculation that he may want to be the V.P. pick. I don't know that Hillary Clinton would select him. But I doubt that he is interested in just having a, you know, outsized voice on the platform committee or on a few issues in the context of a convention.

I suggest he is going to be looking for more specific, more concrete commitments from Secretary Clinton than that.

BOLTON: So, Governor, let me ask you, since we're speaking about Hillary Clinton and her candidacy, there is a new Rasmussen poll, which shows 50 percent of all voters think she should continue to run even if she is indicted in connection to the e-mail investigation. Does that surprise you at all?

PAWLENTY: It does surprise me, although the country is so polarized and large chunk of the population have become so -- in their political silos that the fact that they won't abandon her even if she is indicted, it tells you a lot about how polarized the country, but yes, that is surprising. You'd think more people would bail on her if she gets indicted.

BOLTON: Yes. That seems like a pretty strong, a pretty strong black eye.

PAWLENTY: Right.

BOLTON: But Clinton campaign chairman, John Podesta, he is actually acknowledged that the private e-mail system was a mistake, but separately he says she has taken responsibility for it. Has she?

PAWLENTY: Well, here's the -- her defense, Deirdre, for always had been on public relations level, they weren't labeled as secured, you know, sensitive information at the time.

But the fact of the matter is, given her position and her experience and her seasoning she should have known that these were classified documents. So, they didn't need to be labeled for her to know.

And if you recklessly stored them or knowingly transmitted to somebody without the right security clearance that's a violation. And I think the FBI is going to be in very difficult spot. Because I think there was a violation. I'm not sure they are going to want to indict her on the eve of election when she is a leading candidate for president.

BOLTON: But it certainly at least hurting her credibility even among democratic voters who were looking for a strong candidate which may end up being to Trump's benefit?

PAWLENTY: No question.

BOLTON: Thank you. Governor Tim Pawlenty joining me there. Glad to have you with me.

PAWLENTY: Thank you.

BOLTON: Media bias alert, one writer crying foul after he says liberal web site Huffington Post pulled his anti-Hillary headline. We'll tell what you it was and what Huffpo is saying about the decision.

Also, Katie Couric produce an anti-gun violence documentary. We invited one of the pro-gun participants on to talk about what he says were bias edit. After he spoke on the show to me, Katie Couric is apologizing. Her comments are next.

PHILIP VAN CLEEVE, GUN ADVOCATE INTERVIEWED BY COURIC: Once I saw what she did, after I put the teeth back in my head, that she had the temerity to do something like that, I decided that we need to let the world know because that's unacceptable.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: The online publication Huffington Post published and then removed a blog post about Hillary Clinton. So, the article was about the FBI's plans to pursue an indictment against her on federal racketeering charges.

The writer, who is freelance, told Breitbart News that he is baffled as to why his blog was deleted and he is waiting for an explanation from the publication.

My power panel is back. Jillian, Mercedes and Holly. Jillian, what does this say to you? Does it just proof that the bias is out there? Supposedly this freelance writer supports Senator Sanders. I don't know if that's true or false but that's the contextual point.

MELCHIOR: Well, there is lot we don't know. And it's funny we're talking about this. So, I was at brunch pop up on my Twitter feed. And we're all going like do we re-tweet it. Who knows if it's right or not?

But I think the bottom line is that any publications prerogative to make editorial choices about what they publish or don't publish. We don't know if the story is true. But time will tell whether the story is true. And either be Huffington Post editors going who we shut that down or they are going to miss a heck of the scoop.

BOLTON: So, Mercedes, speaking on what Jillian said, I mean, it was a blog post which also implies a certain informality, right, versus actual printed word. What is your take?

SCHLAPP: Sure. Well, I mean, I think you need to understand where the Huffington Post is coming from. When you look at founder, Arianna Huffington, she made it very clear, in fact, she has an editor's disclaimer talking about the fact that Donald Trump is a serial liar or rapist and xenophobe.

Plus, we know that on MSNBC Arianna came out and said that this connection with Clinton Foundation, really that whole issue quote, unquote, "doesn't matter." So, there is clearly a bias from the top down. And I think that's very reflective on how the coverage is in the Huffington Post.

BOLTON: Yes, it is indeed. I want to ask you about another controversy. This one surrounds a documentary, and this is about gun violence. So, news anchor Katie Couric, did the interviews in the piece. She is also the executive producer, essentially meaning she picked up the bulk of the price of production.

She and her producer faced criticism for heavy editing. She has since made a statement, quote, "I take responsibility for a decision that misrepresented an exchange I had with members of the Virginia Citizens Defense League when I was screened an early version of the film with the director, Stephanie Soechtig, I questioned her and the editor about the pause."

"I was told that a beat was added for, as she described it, dramatic effect. I went back, reviewed it and agreed that those eight seconds do not accurately represent their response."

Last week, we had the gun advocate on with us who leaked the documentary's unedited audio. Here is what he told me.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLEEVE: That film intentionally made it look like there was no answer, that we, on the pro-gun side had no answer to that question. And there were plenty of answers to it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Jillian, Mercedes, and Holly back with me now. So, Holly, I'm coming to you, Couric admits the mistake. I mean, eight seconds is not a pause in any editor's language and it does takes away from the credibility of the whole piece. So, does this prove a bias that often goes in your favor as democrat, Holly?

SHULMAN: You know, honestly, I think that the actual answer from the released audio is even worse than the silence. What they said in the answer, was that anyone as long as they're not in jail, so that means perpetrators of domestic violence, that means mental health, people with history of mental health issues, felons, terrorists should have access to a gun.

And so, honestly like...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: I think though in the piece to be fair the idea was that, all those categories are screened in a different way. It was a discussion of which database is tracking sales background checks and all categories that you just mentioned.

SHULMAN: Yes. So, I think that, you know, Katie Couric said that she apologized. I don't think that there was any bad intent here. And she has made that clear. But, you know, I think that the actual answers are things that the American people have to hear because that's what they should be making their judgment on. And I think that those views are pretty far out of the mainstream.

BOLTON: All right. Jillian is shaking her head..

MELCHOIR: Yes. It's a lot easier to hear that if you don't have deceptive eight seconds silence.

SCHLAPP: That's right.

MELCHOIR: I mean, we want both sides represented. Editing in silence that didn't exist before is not the way to have honest discussion about that. And the fact that she thought maybe that would be the way to put that in represented in the documentary, I think that is indicative of fear of an argument.

BOLTON: Well, it seems as well that she probably didn't count on the participants running their own audio copy to be able to show as they say, and not tell exactly what happens. We're grateful that the guests came on.

Thank you all. Thanks for the conversation.

MELCHOIR: Thank you.

BOLTON: Holly, Mercedes, and Jillian, glad you're here.

Former U.S. Attorney General, Eric Holder changing his opinions on Edward Snowden's revelations. Holder now saying that Snowden performed a public service. I will ask Colonel Ralph Peters what he thinks of the change in stance and what it means for the U.S. A.G.'s legacy since Snowden as a reminder has been charged with espionage.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ERIC HOLDER, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: He actually performed a public service by raising the debate that we engaged in and by the changes that we made.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ERIC HOLDER, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: Snowden did what he did, but I think that he actually performed a public service by raising the debate that we engaged in and by the changes that we made. Now I would say doing what he did, and the way he did it, was inappropriate and illegal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: Former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder changing his stance on Edward Snowden. Snowden leaked classified information about the U.S. government the way that it functioned specifically the NSA.

He has been charged with espionage. Snowden reacted on Twitter saying, "The U.S.'s stance on what he did is getting more and more lenient as time goes on." You can read that, it's treason, maybe not, but it was reckless, still technically it was unlawful, it's public continues but, and he continues.

With me now, Fox News strategic analyst retired Lieutenant Colonel Ralph Peters. Colonel, thanks as always for being with me. What do you think about U.S. A.G. Eric Holder making a statement like, it wasn't so bad after all. I mean, Snowden did put some people in danger.

RALPH PETERS, FOX NEWS STRATEGIC ANALYST: No, he killed people. These were scandalous words from a scoundrel. Eric Holder's legacy as attorney general his primary legacy is going to be dead cops.

Remember he's the guy that vilified the police while portraying young thugs, violent thugs almost as heroes. Now he wants to pronounce on Snowden. There was no debate here, there was a shouting match. He was utterly unfair and he left out the fact that Snowden didn't leak this stuff to the New York Times.

Snowden gave it to the Chinese and the Russians and put it out there all around the world. Terrorists. You know, Islamists learned how we were collecting data, they changed their patterns, we made it tougher to locate the terrorists, and knows the terrorists killed people.

The Russians, the Chinese, other enemies of the United States learned about multibillion dollar technical programs that were never, never aimed against American citizens, they were aimed against our enemies.

And by the way, Deirdre, you know, since the Snowden case just broke, I have challenged everyone, left, right, and here abroad, give me the name of one single law-abiding American citizen who was harmed in any way by any NSA program. Over three years now nobody can give me a single name. It was all lies.

BOLTON: That's a great question and a great point. I'm assuming this is because Edward Snowden wants to come back to the U.S. and somehow the Obama administration or U.S. A.G. Eric Holder is trying to lay the groundwork so that becomes possible.

But to your point, Russia didn't really accept them just because they were friendly.

PETERS: Right.

BOLTON: He was given information.

PETERS: You're absolutely right. In a sense what Holder is trying to do now is he's out of office is what President Obama and Valerie Derrick tried to do with Bowe Bergdahl to whitewash somebody who betrayed a fundamental trust.

It just seems that this administration and those affiliated with it don't really have much respect for the genuine heroes but, boy, they've got time for the Bergdahl's and the Snowden's, and it really it's a disgrace but it's also just a sad, sad thing.

BOLTON: Let me ask you on a related matter how to do with tech companies, Facebook, Twitter, Google, and Microsoft, that pledging to tackle online hate speech to combat the use of social media by terrorists.

But is this strong enough? I mean, can these companies make a difference? There are a lot of people who say that the tech companies have done a lot more to prevent other crimes, which is great, but for some reason there is this last wall in somehow protecting people who want to reach out and encourage others to do harm?

PETERS: Well, first these big tech companies, Facebook, Twitter, Google, Microsoft - they're not doing it out of patriotism, they're doing it because the European Union is basically forced them to and they're protecting market share.

Myself, I am, Deirdre, I would love to see true hate speech especially from Islamist terrorists removed from the web. The web is a great recruiting tool, and operational tool for terrorists and other bad guys.

But my concern is who gets to decide what's hate speech. For instance, if on this show I tell you that I believe, as I do, that extremist Islamist terrorists have to be killed, that they can't be reformed, well, in Germany, that might qualify as hate speech.

Does that mean that Google blocks Fox News insider? You know, it just who gets to decide? Thomas Payne incited violence, some of Jefferson's remarks could be banned. Now, again, I'm not arguing against banning Islamic hate speech, I'm just saying that the devil, like the Jihad is in the details.

BOLTON: It makes all the sense in the world. Lieutenant Colonel Ralph Peters, thank you always for your insight.

PETERS: Love being on the show, Deirdre. It's a great show.

BOLTON: We love having you. Thank you.

Coming up, a possible road rage incident caught on tape. A vehicle literally driving over a veteran's motorcycle. My next guest says he may actually have a legal defense.

Police, by the way, investigating the circumstances of the Ohio gorilla's death. Find out from a legal standpoint which party is reliable. The zoo or the boy's parents? Our legal eagles are going to weigh in next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

THANE MAYNARD, CINCINNATI ZOO DIRECTOR: We did not take the shooting of Harambe lightly. But the child's life was in danger. And people who question that who are Monday morning quarterbacks, or second-guessers don't understand that you can't take a risk with a silver back.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: The Cincinnati Zoo director is defending its decision to shoot and kill a 400-pound rare gorilla, after a four-year-old boy fell 15 feet into the enclosure on Saturday.

Meanwhile, animal rights activists are upset with the decision, they have created an online petition in memory of the gorilla. It calls for the child's parents to be investigated and held liable for negligence. The petition has gathered more than 100,000 signatures.

Attorneys Diana Aizman and Harleigh Tensen with me now. Welcome to you both. I'm glad you're here because that was frightening video for starters.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Absolutely.

BOLTON: And this is a really interesting case. So, again, just from a legal perspective, Diana, who is more liable, the zoo? The parents? Neither?

DIANA AIZMAN, ATTORBEY: So, at this point, it looks like the zoo did everything they were supposed to do as far as the barrier, how the barrier was set up. It was in line with the regulations that surround that.

And it seems that they made a decision that was aided by a team that made the assessment. They decided that they need to end the gorilla's life in order to save the life of the small child. So, it seems like they did what they were supposed to do.

BOLTON: Can, I'm just saying, rightly or wrongly, and I heard the director, for one thing he made the right call. That matters. But what about this animal rights activists are they able to bring a lawsuit against the zoo?

HARLEIGH TENSEN, ATTORNEY: They are not because they don't have standing. The zoo is property -- I'm sorry, the gorilla is property.

BOLTON: OK.

TENSEN: So, loss of property.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Well, let me take care.

TENSEN: Exactly. And it's troubling and upsetting but they won't -- they do not have standing to sue.

BOLTON: So, what about these animal rights activists who are also petitioning that the parents basically be charged with negligence. Is that going to stand up?

AIZMAN: You know it's hard to say. At this point it's too early to put that kind of label on this. I think that it is appropriate for them to go in and investigate the situation, make a determination whether or not this was an isolated incident of negligence or if this was sort of a pattern of behavior where this mother is losing track of her child.

BOLTON: Because that happens essentially to all parents at some moment you lose track of your child.

AIZMAN: Yes.

BOLTON: However, this enclosure looks pretty set up to keep people and animals apart.

TENSEN: Which is why I think it took more than three seconds for this boy to find a way through the enclosure and through the barricade. I understand you turn your head, accidents happen. But I think he really had to be searching around for a way to get into the enclosure.

BOLTON: OK.

TENSEN: We're with the parent then.

BOLTON: All right. Speaking of this topic, celebrity zoo keeper Jack Hanna is defending the Cincinnati Zoo's decision to kill the gorilla. He is going to be with me shortly to talk about it.

But I want to ask you to another legal question. Because look at this video, it's a hit-and-run in Florida, it shows the vehicle driving over a veteran's motorcycle in a suspected road rage incident.

So, the driver arrested on aggravated battery with a deadly weapon charge, driving without a valid driver's license. But is there anyway, I mean, when you look at this, it's horrifying. But does the driver is some lawyer going to take the case of the driver and argue successfully on his behalf?

TENSEN: Absolutely. I think they could. There is so much we don't know. Is the video horrifying? It is. But we don't know if there was a steering malfunction. We don't know if the driver was provoked.

BOLTON: We are assuming it's road rage, but that's a great point. That could be an assumption.

AIZMAN: OK. So you know what's really, really difficulty when you're a criminal defense attorney is when you have an actual videotape of your client committing a crime. That makes defending somebody incredible challenging.

BOLTON: Yes. Because you see that and you're like, oh, my God.

AIZMAN: Yes. That mean it looks from what I'm watching, it looks like a guy behind the wheel who drove his vehicle on purpose over a motorcycle that had someone on it.

TENSEN: How can you say that was on purpose just based on the video? You can't say that that was on purpose. The intent isn't there based on the video alone

AIZMAN: Right. And if he kept driving forward, I'd say maybe there were some issue with his health or maybe he was having some sort of a medical episode and he lost track of the vehicle, but that doesn't appear to be what's happening here. He then drove off. He corrects the course and then drives off.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, but, Harleigh, I hear what you're saying, there's defense for anything. What if the motive -- I don't know. What if there was some road tension, meaning like the motorcycle is too close, who knows, was too close to the car, aggravating them. It still doesn't give the rights for the car driver to hit him on purpose.

TENSEN: Of course not.

BOLTON: Even if he provoked it.

TENSEN: Of course not. But we still don't know if it was intentional.

BOLTON: OK.

TENSEN: He drove away, people get in accidents, they get scared, and they drive away. That doesn't mean he intentionally brand it.

BOLTON: All right. Would you want to represent him?

TENSEN: I would absolutely represent him.

BOLTON: You would?

TENSEN: Yes.

BOLTON: All right. Diana?

AIZMAN: I would represent him. Absolutely. I mean, everybody in this country is entitled to a fair criminal defense.

BOLTON: All right. There we go. Two pros legal eagles. Diana and Harleigh, thank you so much. Glad to have you.

TENSEN: Thank you.

BOLTON: Major automakers racing to get the first driverless car to market. A new report says a rush will make them more hackable than ever. We're going to bring you details, next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Here we go, start moving, sending brake command. Stops.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Here we go, starting our slow five-mile-an-hour cruise. Sending the command. And we brake.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Driverless cars may provide more opportunity for hackers. Some are proving there are ways to control brakes, engines and other components remotely.

My next guest says that security risk isn't the only one. MIT tech reviews San Francisco bureau chief, Tom Simonite is with me now. Welcome, Tom. Why are driverless cars more of a security risk than human driven ones?

TOM SIMONITE, MIT TECH REVIEWS CHIEF: Hi, nice to be here. If you speak to anyone who works in security, they would tell you that adding more computers to something makes it more hackable. There are just more things that can go wrong.

When things are hooked up to the internet, of course that provides a way in for an attacker. And it's clear to make cars drive themselves, you need to add a lot of computers to these vehicles, you know, as well as all the equipment to control different components.

BOLTON: OK, but you're saying that in addition to those potential breaches, there are other issues. I know you're out in California, I assume you have visited some of the places that are testing these driverless cars. What are you seeing? What are you hearing?

SIMONITE: Yes, that's right. I mean, if you're here in the Bay Area, you just need to visit the right stretch of the 101 freeway and you can see Google's cars out and testing on public roads. This is a very exciting technology.

I think a lot of us are ready to give up driving and lean back and relax. There are a lot of safety benefits. Some of like 30,000 people die on U.S. roads every year, maybe we can cut that.

This is moving fast. You know, Google just announced that it's opening a new testing facility outside of Detroit where it work with Chrysler on some self-driving minivans and Toyota and some of the comment they say they want to have autonomous cars by 2020.

So, there's a lot of optimism in the industry but there are questions about how exactly we're going to get there to the state where you know, you and I can safely text in our car and not have to pay attention to where we're going.

BOLTON: So, when you speak with the experts, what are they telling you? What are their biggest challenges right now?

SIMONITE: So, the biggest challenges are around the complicated urban driving that we do which often involves a lot of thinking and so much like a social act. If you're in an urban environment, you might be making eye contact with other drivers. You might be in situations where a road is closed and there were cops standing out in the road telling you where you need to go.

Computers and, you know, robotic equipment is great when it comes to making quick reactions to, say, somebody is in front of the car, but computers aren't there with the commonsense that is needed to decode some of this difficult urban situations.

BOLTON: Right. So, human brain are still for the moment slightly stronger than machine ones, which is good to be sure of from time to time even though I know that humans are the ones programming all the artificial intelligence tools.

We take the point, nonetheless. Thank you, Tom.

SIMONITE: Thank you.

BOLTON: Tom Simonite with me there from MIT tech review.

Well, Fox News is now confirming that conservative writer Bill Kristol is eyeing conservative lawyer Weekly Standard editor David French for an independent presidential run, third party, against Donald Trump.

Kristol is part of the hash tag never Trump campaign, and he previously was pushing for Mitt Romney.

When we come back, animal rights activists are crying foul. They're holding a vigil for the slain gorilla at the Cincinnati Zoo that was shot to protect the boy.

Celebrity zoo keeper Jack Hanna disagrees saying the caretaker's decision to save the boy's life was the right one.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Mommy's right here!

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh, my God!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: A 4-year-old boy fell into a rare gorilla's enclosure at the Cincinnati Zoo. The zoo's director made the decision to shoot the gorilla to save the child. Some animal activists disagree and are crying.

Columbus Zoo director and TV host, Jack Hanna says the zoo director made the right call. Jack, we are so glad to speak with you. Thanks for the time. As a director of a zoo also in Ohio, this hits super close to home. What is your take on the situation?

JACK HANNA, COLUMBUS ZOO DIRECTOR EMERITUS: Well, at the Columbus Zoo the first gorilla in the world that they were boarding here because we only have 20 gorillas boarding here to survive. The oldest living gorilla in the world lives here too.

So, you can see how we've worked with gorillas for over 30-something year. I have a home in Rwanda that which is only two miles from mountain gorillas since for the last 20 years. So, I'm not an expert in any means. But I can tell you this.

I've witnessed gorillas both in the zoo and the wild, I can tell you also when I first saw this on TV, when the child is there, all of a sudden he jerks the child, he goes through there, you heard the noise in my ear just now, but the people are screaming and stuff, you got a gorilla there silverback by the way.

They now had this human in there and all of a sudden they do the alarm call. All this family the women or the girl gorillas go in the building. He was out; he was there in the building something sit in the moat, people screaming.

All of a sudden he drags that child. That's a dead giveaway for me. And I always says this because I witnessed it in the wild. I witnessed it in the zoological parks. I'm telling you that child would not be here today if they waited.

BOLTON: So, Jack, you know obviously a lot more about these animals. Are saying by the fact that female gorillas went in, people were screaming, that the silverback his whole job is to protect his tribe so you're saying wuth that in mind he would have killed the child.

HANNA: Yes. I'm telling you that right now when he did that actually, now I saw that face on the animal that is a face you don't want to see and especially a silverback. Then a female maybe little sit on that situation.

But right now this animal is confused. He's upset. Now somebody would say, well, why don't you tranquilize the animal by the way. That's a whole different world, everybody. How about you getting in that moat there, let's say that kid starting fighting that gorilla after a few minutes. Everybody that want to wait.

You cannot wait in a situation like this. I have seen a gorilla -- a gorilla definitely like you saw there take a green coconut that you can't bust it with a hatchet and go like it and squeeze it.

What I'm saying is all you had to don't, it'd actually with like this start screaming fight again, what do you think he would have done that child. You don't want to watch...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: he would consider it an attack or a threat what you're saying here what he did.

HANNA: Of course. Yes. And you might know you have a human being in here. And by the way, everyone says how they love the gorillas. It's very simple. Why do they love the gorillas? Because they have seen them in zoos, they haven't seen them in the wild. You know, many people if you get to see a gorilla in the wild you can't count them probably, you know, it's a hard thing to do. It's very expensive thing to do.

I've been very blessed to be able to film these for 30-some years. And I'm just saying that you have human life and animal life. You know, we have something here which are not...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: I agree with your point.

HANNA: It's just a no-win situation for anybody.

BOLTON: Jack, we thank you so much. Thank you for sharing your insights.

HANNA: Thank you. All right.

BOLTON: Jack Hanna with me there. Thank you for joining us here on Risk & Reward. Making Money with Charles Payne starts now.

END

urn:contentItem:5JX3-W651-JB20-G0R6-00000-00Trump Speaks about Donations to Veterans Charities; Trump Speaks about Media and Party Leaders; Democratic California Primary Next Week; Eric Holder Changes Stance on Edward Snowden; Road Rage Incident Caught on Tape; 4-Year-Old Boy Falls into Zoo Gorilla Cage; Race to Get Driverless Car to Market2016-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTKatrina Pierson, Jillian Melcher, Mercedes Schlapp, Holly Shulman, Tim Pawlenty, Ralph Peters, Diana Aizman, Harleigh Tensen, Tom Simonite, Jack HannaNEWSFinancial053101cb.233Trump Speaks about Donations to Veterans Charities; Trump Speaks about Media and Party Leaders; Democratic California Primary Next Week; Eric Holder Changes Stance on Edward Snowden; Road Rage Incident Caught on Tape; 4-Year-Old Boy Falls into Zoo Gorilla Cage; Race to Get Driverless Car to MarketDeirdre Bolton

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Press should be ashamed of themselves. And on behalf of the vets, the press should be ashamed of themselves. They are calling me and they are furious because I sent people checks of a lot of money.

And we're going to give you the names right now which is what you want, and instead of being like thank you very much, Mr. Trump or Trump did a good job, everyone said, who got it, who got it, who got it? And you make me look very bad. I have never received such bad publicity for doing such a good job.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: Donald Trump speaking from Trump tower about his donations to veteran's charities.

This is Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

Donald Trump says he raised close to $6 million for veterans organizations and named ones that received money. He says that if he is president he will hit back at the press if they write false stories just as he will hit back at party leaders that don't support him.

With me now, Katrina Pierson, Trump campaign spokesperson. Katrina, welcome back. Glad to see you.

KATRINA PIERSON, DONALD TRUMP NATIONAL SPOKESPERSON: Great to be here. Thank you.

BOLTON: So, Trump supporters admire his fighting spirit. Rush Limbaugh started his radio show this morning with this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, CONSERVATIVE RADIO HOST: People have been begging for all republican to just once take on the media the way Trump did.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Katrina, how much feedback on that 40-minute press conference are you getting?

PIERSON: Tons of feedback. You know, my inbox is so full right now from so many people across the country saying finally, this is one of those situations where, when Mr. Trump held this, when he held this fund-raiser, this was a spontaneous fund-raiser put it together within 24 hours.

We had been saying it will take a little bit of time to vet some of these organizations to bring in the money that was pledged by the way, not on hand. And for weeks, and almost every day we heard about the veterans fund- raisers and where is the money.

Mr. Trump is not politician. Mr. Trump has been doing things for people his whole life. So, this idea that somehow there was some animus reason that Mr. Trump did this, I mean, it really showed today in the media is now covering of the actual fund-raiser really goes to show, and people are so fed up and frustrated with the hypocrisy on the way republicans are covered versus the way democrats are covered or lack there off.

BOLTON: So you feel like there is clearly a bias, but speaking of democrats, Hillary Clinton's campaigns is planning series of events to take on Trump's record on vet's issues.

So, her campaign apparently is going to have speakers who are all vets, I should state in Virginia, Pennsylvania, and New Hampshire, Florida, Colorado, so all battleground states. Are you planning to counter that counter?

PIERSON: Well, I'm sure we will. I mean, this is one of those -- one of those issues that Mr. Trump has been extremely strong on. And, you know, there are two groups of people that I've seen personally Mr. Trump get a little emotional about.

And that is veterans who have been treated completely unfairly. When you have illegal aliens that are getting treatment faster than veterans that's absurd. And this is a Hillary Clinton policy by the way, someone that's been in office, someone that has been in public life, the first lady being a senator and Secretary of State and has done what for veterans?

Absolutely nothing. This is something close to Mr. Trump's heart. And over the campaign trail when he saw an opportunity to do something for veterans, he did it. He took action. And that's the kind of leader that we need.

BOLTON: Now speaking of fighting, so he's obviously fighting Hillary Clinton and it looks like that is going to be the match up in November, although TBD on the democratic side but he is still fighting within the party.

I mean, he tweeted out his response to Bill Kristol calling for a strong independent third party candidate. He says, "The Republican Party has to be smart and strong if it wants win in November. Can't allow lightweight," so everyone assumes the reference to Kristol, "to set up a spoiler in the candidate."

And then he also tweeted, "If dummy Bill Kristol actually does get as spoiler to run as independent, say good-bye to the Supreme Court." But aside from Bill Kristol, aside from Mitt Romney and we are pretty sure that Bill Kristol has Mitt Romney in mind, how is the unification plan going from your point of view?

PIERSON: Well, the way you pose the question is exactly what's happening. The party is with Mr. Trump. He has broken a record in GOP primary turnout. And there is just handful of republicans, establishment republicans who want status quo. They want to keep things the same. And they know we'll have that with Hillary Clinton.

But for the most part Mr. Trump is unifying the party. Reince Priebus, chairman of the RNC said it's time to get behind the front-runner. We have so many people with the RNC and in the states, we now have state chairman coming on board.

So, this unification process is moving along, particularly now that we've now several endorsements on the Hill, whether congressional chairman or just other members in the party. Those who don't want to get on board are those who want to keep the things the same way.

And those who have been rejected twice now by the people, Mr. Trump transcends party even though he's unifying Republican Party, he is unifying the American people with a pro-America message.

BOLTON: OK. But one thing I wanted to ask when you talk about pro-America and unification, there are some who say he unfairly went after New Mexico Governor Susanna Martinez, and it relates to what I want to ask you about.

Because he is going after the judge who is ordering the release of the Trump University documents, bringing up the judge's Mexican heritage. Here is the comment. I just want to circle back with you after.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I have a judge who is a hater of Donald Trump, a hater. He is a hater.

(CROWD BOOING)

His name is, Gonzalo Curiel, the judge who happened to be, we believe Mexican which is great. I think that's fine. You know what he what? I think the Mexicans are going to end up loving Donald Trump when I give all these jobs, OK?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, on one hand should the judge recuse himself and on the other hand, how do you see Donald Trump's outreach to the Latino population?

PIERSON: Well, look, this judge is a problem. He does not like Mr. Trump. This is activist judge appointed by Barack Obama because Barack Obama wouldn't appoint anyone other than an activist judge.

And there was great article just released today in the American Spectator that gives specific details about this judge. And the simple fact that he is the friend of the lawyer on the opposite side. So, he should absolutely recuse himself.

But it's important that Mr. Trump mention that for a reason because we do see a lot of these anti-Trump protesters who are very much pushing the anti-American message of the way they're behaving at some of the rallies on the outside and waving the Mexican flag. They're holding up La Raza signs.

These are very much important details that the mainstream media is leaving out. So it's going to be up to Mr. Trump to get that word out.

BOLTON: And just to finish the point, what do you make of the relationship with the governor of New Mexico, Martinez?

PIERSON: Look, Governor Martinez was a never Trumper to begin with. I mean, she has said things publicly against Mr. Trump and Mr. Trump is a counterpuncher.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So some people think she would be a great V.P.

PIERSON: Well, not Mr. Trump, obviously. But look, Mr. Trump doesn't see party. He doesn't see race, and he doesn't see gender. He just wants to do what is right for the country. He wants to get back to common sense government. And he is counterpuncher.

She criticized him, he criticized her. And just because she is a woman or just because she is Latino means nothing. Mr. Trump is going to treat everyone the same and it's been that way from the beginning.

BOLTON: It certainly has been. Katrina, thank you. Glad to have you with us.

PIERSON: Great to be here.

BOLTON: Katrina Pierson joining me there, she is a spokesperson for the Donald Trump campaign.

Well, with more on the subject, how Donald Trump handled the media on his donations to veterans, he did turn over the microphone to a vet from New Hampshire. Here are that vet's comments.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AL BALDASARO, VETERAN: Stop using veterans as political pawns. You got a guy outside, McCoy, go do a Google search on his Facebook. He is out there, his picture is with the Clintons. They are using veterans as political pawns and it must stop.

Donald Trump is doing this from the heart. You're all focused on the way he is raising money and you're not looking at 22 veterans that are killing each other every day. You're not concerned about the thousands of veterans that are on wait lists.

Look at his plan on his Trump web site. He talks about medical cards. He talks about fixing the V.A. He talks about competition. I think the liberal media and I've been dealing with you a long time and get your head out of your butt and focus on the real issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My political power panel is here. Jillian Melcher, Heat Street political editor, republican strategist, Mercedes Schlapp; and democratic strategist Holly Shulman. Welcome to you all. So, Gillian, in your view how did Trump handle the press conference?

JILLIAN MELCHIOR, HEAT STREET POLITICAL EDITOR: I don't think he handled it wonderfully. I mean, it's great for the Washington Post to follow up on this. He made a commitment to help veterans to support them that was widely viewed...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, I just want to cut you off so everybody else follows.

MELCHIOR; Yes.

BOLTON: So, many people saw this 40-minute press conference as response to a piece written in the Washington Post which was essentially, was not titled, where is the money but that is essentially the point of the piece.

MELCHIOR: Exactly, they could not find a single veteran's organizations that had received one the $1 million that Trump said he'd given. So, there is a lot of speculation, a lot of question. All of sudden Trump produces the check. He says it's supposed to be about scrutiny about vetting the charity...

BOLTON: But he has given out more than three million.

MELCHIOR: Well, he ended up doing it, but he's saying that vetting is the reason for four-month delay.

BOLTON: Right.

MELCHIOR: But he ended up giving it to a guy who runs a charity, who's not only running charity, he works for the SoHo Trump. So, this is somebody within his own corporation. I think the vetting excuse doesn't hold water.

I think he needs to be held accountable for this and it's fair for The Washington Post reporters to ask these questions.

BOLTON: But in fairness, I take all your point, in fairness to Trump, he got out there and pretty much delineated Excel's spreadsheet line, by spreadsheet line, where the money came from, where it's going. Mercedes, what is your take?

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Well, I've got to tell you I'm still waiting to see how much money Hillary Clinton has given to any of the vets. Let's be realistic here.

This is a guy who made a promise that he was going to give millions of dollars to veterans groups. I've never really seen a presidential candidate take such interest in insuring that these veterans get the help that they need.

With that being said, I do believe that he has a special connections with the veterans groups. I think that he is true to his word. I think when you look at Hillary Clinton and the fact that she's made millions of dollars off of these Wall Street speeches, and yet, she is trying to hit Donald Trump on the fact of whether he is giving the money or how much money he has given? Fine.

I think that it's the media's responsibility to, yes, check and make sure that he is delivering on his promise but at the same time, I mean, he is taking an unconventional approach which Hillary Clinton doesn't even know how to respond to.

BOLTON: So, Holly, since you're our democratic voice, what is your take on that, especially in light of the Clinton campaign planning this whole series of counterattacks if we're going to call them that for the next few days to try to reach out to veterans?

HOLLY SHULMAN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: One thing has been clear through this whole process and that's Donald Trump only cares about veterans when it's politically expedient for him. And that's what we've seen today.

Hillary Clinton, despite the political benefits has reached across the aisle, worked with Senator John McCain for $50 million for veterans rehab center in Texas. She's worked with Lindsey Graham to expand health care for reservists, for National Guard.

And she has a career of working on these issues and fighting for veterans. And if he wants to make this an issue in the campaign I would say, bring it on.

BOLTON: All right. We're going to have more to talk about. Jillian, Mercedes, Holly all back with me. In the meantime, we want to let you know Donald Trump dismissing libertarian presidential candidate Gary Johnson as a fringe candidate earlier today.

HANNA: Thank you. All right.

BOLTON: Jack Hanna with me there. Thank you for joining us here on Risk & Reward. Making Money with Charles Payne starts now.
