Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W89-1211-DXH2-63S8-00000-00Trump Speaks At Buckingham Palace During U.K. State Visit; Strzok- Page E-Mails Reveal Special Treatment To Clinton; Supreme Court Rejects Trump Admin Request To Fast Track DACA Case; Report: British National Security Official Shared Info On Christopher Steele's Credibility; China's Huawei To Sell Undersea Cable Business; U.K. Royal Family Hosts State Dinner With President Donald Trump And His Family; U.K. Royal Family Hosts State Dinner With Trump And His Family; Big Tech Sell-Off; DOJ Gears Up For Antitrust Battles With Big Tech2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTKelsey Bolar, Tom Fitton, John Solomon, Dr. Michael Pillsbury, John LonskiNEWSFinancial060301cb.229Trump Speaks At Buckingham Palace During U.K. State Visit; Strzok- Page E-Mails Reveal Special Treatment To Clinton; Supreme Court Rejects Trump Admin Request To Fast Track DACA Case; Report: British National Security Official Shared Info On Christopher Steele's Credibility; China's Huawei To Sell Undersea Cable Business; U.K. Royal Family Hosts State Dinner With President Donald Trump And His Family; U.K. Royal Family Hosts State Dinner With Trump And His Family; Big Tech Sell-Off; DOJ Gears Up For Antitrust Battles With Big TechLou Dobbs, Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin, Edward Lawrence

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Kelsey Bolar, thank you so much for joining us. We really appreciate it. And thank you for having us in your homes. Thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right on the Fox Business Network. Have a good evening.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. President Trump in London tonight but that means little to the national left-wing media. The radical Dimms or even his own communications department at the White House. The media focusing in on, well, inane stories with little purpose other than to embarrass the President. The Dimms summoning a Watergate figure to testify as part of their own approximation of a witch-hunt.

The White House Communications Department playing some sort of games, we'll explore here tonight what they are. We take all that up tonight with Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin, Tom Fitton, John Solomon among our guest. And big tech selling off today as the Justice Department prepares for anti- trust investigation into Google, sending concern throughout Silicon Valley.

We talk the up the latest from Wall Street, Moody's chief economist, John Lonski. And China and Mexico desperate now to talk trade with the Trump administration after the President has made it clear he will demand fair, reciprocal, responsible trading relationships with both countries. China trying to take shots at the President's America First agenda, yet saying they are willing to negotiate with the Trump administration. Now isn't that nice of them?

Mexican officials are already in Washington to talk about the President's proposed tariffs on Mexican goods so long as they don't fight illegal immigration and secure their half of the U.S.-Mexico border. The President not holding back about the years of Mexican abuses of the American immigration system.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They have to stop the illegal flow, the flow of drugs, of immigrants, illegal immigrants, people that have not gone through the process. And if the Democrats would wise up and give us the proper laws, the proper immigration laws, we could solve the problem in one day. What Mexico's been doing to this country for so many years, like 25 to 30 years worth of drugs and human trafficking and illegals all pouring through Mexico, no good. And caravans. No good.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Those among the last comments from the President before heading for London. We talk about the latest in the President's ballots over so-called free trade that has cost this country trillions of dollars and millions of jobs and the deadly drug trade across our border with Mexico. We begin tonight with the President's visit to the United Kingdom, there to establish a deeper trust with a longtime ally.

At home his communications department playing some rather peculiar games. We'll tell you about that. A number of administration officials appeared on major networks today including Ben Carson, Sonny Perdue, Kevin Hassett. We had booked White House National Trade Council President Peter Navarro here on the show but the White House tells us that they did not want to detract from the President's visit to the Buckingham Palace tonight.

And so they actually retracted Navarro from our guest list. And as the White House denies guests, it also allows the national left-wing media to focus on stories like the President's hair, the fake news that he a called Meghan Markle nasty without response from the White House. Those stories dominating the headlines overshadowing Judicial Watch's discovery of new e- mails between Peter Strzok and Lisa Page.

Those e-mails showing special treat for Hillary Clinton's attorney during the FBI investigation of Clinton's e-mail server scandal. A lot to go through tonight, and joining us to kick it all up, Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton. Tom, great to have you here. Another revelation courtesy of Judicial Watch and the freedom of information system. Tell us what this means that her attorney was given special access, special treatment with -- by the FBI.

TOM FITTON, PRESIDENT, JUDICIAL WATCH: Yes. Her attorney, David Kendall, who represents her personally, was -- according to the new e-mails that were covered by a lawsuit, they weren't voluntarily disclosed by the Justice Department, these are Page-Strzok e-mails. The top lawyer for the FBI, James Baker is talking to David Kendall on how to get records to Hillary Clinton about the e-mail investigation.

And he tells Kendall -- advises Kendall file a FOIA request, file a privacy act request, Kendall according to e-mail traffic once quickly on behalf of Hillary Clinton, so this isn't like your dealing with Hillary Clinton, her 302 which is the narrative report created by the FBI of that sham interview she underwent. And sure enough, the e-mail showed a top lawyer at the FBI, rushed this through the process in order to get the 302 before the election.

DOBBS: To get the 302 the before the election and how irregular is this? Put this in some context for us.

FITTON: Well, I've been at Judicial Watch 21 years, we've never talked to general counsel of the FBI about any FOIA requests, nor have we ever received any such solicitation or help or facilitation for any freedom of information act request. This is extraordinary, special treatment for a presidential candidate, someone they presume is going to be president and recall at the same time they were breaking the law arguably to target her opposition then-candidate Trump.

DOBBS: And it goes on and on. There is without -- just what Judicial Watch has managed to deter your lawsuits through FOIA request, through the information that you have pride from the hands of the deep state and a reticent Federal government is remarkable. But we are not seeing -- we're not seeing any sign right now of prosecution. Where is the inspector general report?

Where -- it's been long promised and now we're in June, just for the record, and no prospect whatsoever as far as I can determine that we will see an inspector general report. Do you have new information for us?

FITTON: I don't. I hope the Inspector General report comes out, but he can't prosecute if anyone. The best he can do is refer questions for prosecution. We don't know what's going to happen there. We've learned from Attorney General Barr that the Special Counsel appointed by Jeff Sessions hasn't done much of anything at all and has deferred to independent -- or the Inspector General.

DOBBS: We're referring to John Huber, is that right?

FITTON: Yes. John Huber, the U.S. Attorney out in Utah. He's been AWOL on all these issues --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Can you explain that? I mean, have you got any idea what he's been doing all this time or what he --

(CROSSTALK)

FITTON: Well, I mean, he was hired specifically by Jeff Sessions because there was pressure for a special counsel. Huber was the answer to that, and he was tasked with investigating whether to investigate. It's no surprise to me as a result nothing much has been done.

DOBBS: You -- it's a trite expression, so I won't use it but I have to say it's just stunning to see what the top officials of the Justice Department and the FBI have gotten away with. They have successfully, I believe, successfully run out the clock. I will be absolutely stunned, Tom, if indeed we see any kind of productive investigation of some of the people who are -- just based on the information that we see in the texts, all of them.

It looks as if they're all going -- including the people who have already been dismissed, looks like they're all going to go free without account.

FITTON: Well, Attorney General Barr needs to accelerate any investigations that are going on and move as quickly as possible. It's pretty clear he understands the corruption but needs to move the agency ahead --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: But the process becomes corruption itself, does it not, tom? When it takes years? I mean, I'm still waiting for the report on Benghazi, for crying out lord. One thing we've learned from the Justice Department over the years under the Obama administration is that the FBI and the Justice Department are where investigatory efforts go to kill truth. We have learned precious little as a result of their so-called investigatory powers and prowess.

FITTON: Well, you know, it's not remarkable, but -- it's remarkable and not to tout our own horn but Judicial Watch's work is the only way to get this information out right now. Congress is asleep at the switch or trying to suppress information by targeting Attorney General Barr with a fraudulent contempt move and without Judicial Watch, this material wouldn't be released. It's great for Judicial Watch, but distressing because the other agency --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Yes. It makes me mad as hell that we have to rely, frankly, on Judicial Watch instead of our own elected officials and appointed officials of the Federal government. By the way, speaking of outrages, our Supreme Court is an outrage, denying an expedited hearing on the DACA executive order of President Obama and just for what reason? Why? Only millions of people are hanging in the balance here.

The entire American population, apparently, doesn't have any rights as citizens to understand what is going on with an executive order from a previous administration for whom it is -- I mean, it just goes on and on. This is maddening.

FITTON: This is an Obama amnesty granted to the children of illegal aliens, and it's an incentive for the current crisis and the courts have gotten in the way of the President's prerogatives to undo this illegal act by President Obama and that the Supreme Court refuses to rein in its lower courts is really shows that, again, the Justice -- I mean, the courts have been part of the swamp in this country for too long and the anti-Trump judiciary is a major factor in causing the immigration crisis that's now threatening our nation.

DOBBS: The Supreme Court itself is now becoming -- I mean, it's obviously part of the problem now. Because it's hearing how many cases a year, maybe 100 out of the thousands and thousands in the Federal system? It takes years and years to hear a Federal case, a civil case it takes years and years to watch a criminal case. This is an archaic anachronism, our Federal court system right now and it is pathetic and pitiful disservice to the American people and our ideas -- our once ideals of American justice.

Tom Fitton and Judicial Watch doing their best to make sure that that does not continue. We appreciate it, Tom, as always. Tom Fitton.

FITTON: You're welcome.

DOBBS: Still ahead, John Solomon joins us next with his latest report detailing the extent to which Hillary Clinton went to undermine the Trump presidency. Also a sign of how radical the Democratic Party really is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN HICKENLOOPER, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: One of the worst years for Democrats in a quarter century. I was --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: You know, when you tell some audiences that you not a socialist or that socialism is a really bad idea, that's the result, you know, that's the result. We'll be telling you why they're booing so many of those 2020 candidates -- well, at least one or two, right after these quick messages. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Leading Dimm radical and radical Dimm House Majority Whip James Clyburn says he and the rest of his delusion so-called party have already begun the process of impeachment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR: You think that the President will be impeached or at least proceedings will begin in the House at some point but just not right now?

REP. JAMES CLYBURN (D-SC): Yes, that's exactly what I feel. I think we've already begun it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: That is one of the doggondest questions I've ever heard a man has. Do you think that the point by possibility that it could happen at a point sometime future, blah, blah, blah, blah. I mean, and that asked for a question. Clyburn telling Fox tonight he hasn't heard from Nancy Pelosi about his comments. Apparently, he will. That's the implication there, isn't it? And the radical Dimms' disarray on full display over the weekend, particularly in California.

Just listen to what happened to former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper and former Maryland Congressman John Delaney after they warned about socialism.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HICKENLOOPER: If we want to beat Donald Trump and achieve big, progressive goals, socialism is not the answer. I was reelected --

JOHN DELANEY PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Medicare for all may sound good but it's actually not good policy nor is it good politics. I'm telling you. I'm telling you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: You know, he could say he's telling them I guess three or four telling him. That mean that was emphatic boo fest right there. Joining us tonight former Reagan White House Political Director, Fox Business Political Analyst, the savant himself, Ed Rollins. New York Post Columnist, Pulitzer Prize winning columnist and Fox Business Contributor, Michael Goodwin. Great to have you both here.

ED ROLLINS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you. Thank you.

DOBBS: There's a lesson there, Michael, I think for those Democrats had better get on the socialism train, don't you think?

MICHAEL GOODWIN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Yes. I guess that was at the California State Party Convention, right?

DOBBS: Yes. You would have -- you would have expected something a little liberal I think.

GOODWIN: It is bizarre because if they really go down this road, I just don't see --

(CROSSTALK)

GOODWIN: -- well, but I mean, guys like that, Hickenlooper and the other one trying --

DOBBS: The country is going to be poor for their nonparticipation.

GOODWIN: Yes. They're trying to stop the train but just they're ignoring all the, you know, yellow flags and just racing right to the doom, it seems to me.

DOBBS: Well, it's -- what do you make of it, Ed? I mean, we are watching quite a --

ROLLINS: This is -- this is one of the hot shot (INAUDIBLE) governor of Colorado. They're been talking about -- talking about --

DOBBS: Hickenlooper is a hot shot governor?

ROLLINS: Among Democrats. They're been talking about him and he stood up there in front of an audience that basically -- that would frighten me to even go near the building of -- I mean, this got the most screaming left- wingers in the world. Basically said socialism isn't the answer, and they booed him for two minutes. I mean, for two minutes --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Well, you got make a point.

ROLLINS: And so if that's -- if that's where they are, you know, this is a state, obviously --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: What does -- what does it say for their candidacies, these two gentlemen, that they couldn't even read that audience well enough to know that you're not going to mess with socialism in 2019?

ROLLINS: Well, a Congressman from Maryland better get back on the -- get back on the ballot in Maryland because he's not going anywhere, they can boo him longer. And the Governor obviously may get reelected. I'm not sure. I'm not sure (INAUDIBLE) again. I think the bottom line is that there's too many candidates in this race that aren't going anywhere, and part of the problem is nobody pays the price anymore.

You can have 23 candidates and used to be that you had to have some substance, you'd move up, enhance yourself. Half these people couldn't move up the next step, let alone run for president.

DOBBS: Well, what do you make of James Clyburn talking about impeachment? He's pretty emphatic about the possibility of the ambiguity of the prospect about possibly doing something about impeachment. I mean, I love that Jake Tapper question. That's a beauty.

GOODWIN: Well, interestingly in that sequence of -- it's a Fox news story today, they have Clyburn saying that, that we have to educate the public. And then Jerry Nadler who runs judiciary says we also, the people don't know the facts and people don't understand yet. So you put these two together --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Nadler actually said we want to impeach, but the public's not ready.

GOODWIN: They don't understand the facts. They don't --

DOBBS: Well, apparently, neither does the conference. They're only -- what are the latest numbers? We're up to what? 50-something, Democrats who are ready to --

(CROSSTALK)

ROLLINS: -- 54 House Democrats in The New York Times, 58 say they won't support it.

DOBBS: Yes.

GOODWIN: Yes.

ROLLINS: 54 or so, 58 and 23 don't want to answer.

DOBBS: There we go.

GOODWIN: But the idea that the public is too --

DOBBS: By the way, I don't know that that we should say the House calls for impeachment and put only 58 members are calling for impeachment. That's what's -- this is a joke, what's going on in the Democrat Party.

ROLLINS: And a bunch of them are not exactly calling for impeachment, what they're basically saying, they're waffling, they're saying , you know, we need to educate the public, we need to do all this and if it leads to an impeachment that would be for impeachment.

GOODWIN: But --

DOBBS: They have -- let's be honest, they haven't got the guts.

ROLLINS: They haven't got the guts.

GOODWIN: Well, by my point is the arrogance saying that if only the public knew what we know and if they understood the truth, they would -- they would vote for impeachment. I mean --

DOBBS: We call that the Schiff conundrum.

GOODWIN: Yes. They --

DOBBS: Just the rest of the world knew what he knew for two years but the evidence of which, the proof of which he could not produce on a million dollar bet.

ROLLINS: I'm waiting for the first charge to be put forward that says the President did something illegal.

DOBBS: Well, Al Green will oblige you, but that's not going to amount much.

ROLLINS: There's no there there. It's just -- it's --

GOODWIN: It's going to be a tough vote for a lot of people to take when it comes to voting in this.

DOBBS: You know what's going to be really tough is to explain to the American people, the folks in California notwithstanding who were booing Hickenlooper and the -- and the Maryland Congressman, it's going to be tough to explain why they've been in power all this time, in 2020 running the Congress and the United States, and haven't done diddly. I mean, nothing. By the way, that's a very good Texas word, diddly if anybody wants to write it down.

GOODWIN: Squat, isn't it?

DOBBS: Squat is -- that's more of a -- that's more of a West Coast word. But a very hip West Coast word in its time. So let's turn to the -- to really where we are with the Republicans. Speaking of not doing much, what's the Senate been doing as we are watching, you know, what's his name, pencil neck as the President refers to him, Schiff. What is he doing? He's just running off at the mouth and still is in charge of the Intel Committee.

ROLLINS: Well, it's astonishing to me, and the truth of the matter is, you know, they're not pushing the judges through anymore. Just there's a lot of confirmation hearings that should be being held and not -- and not doing anything. They say they're stopping all the stuff coming from the House. I don't know what's coming from the House, it's all garbage. So at this point in time, they could all go home and wait until November of 2020, the American public wouldn't miss them.

GOODWIN: Except for the judges and other confirmation. I mean --

DOBBS: Very quickly.

GOODWIN: They did confirm -- they did confirm Bill Barr's second number two in the Justice Department last week, I believe.

DOBBS: That was very good.

GOODWIN: I, look --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: -- and you're telling me what a powerhouse of performance they are.

GOODWIN: It's all they can do, they're doing what they can.

DOBBS: Let's speak about a true powerhouse, and that is the President's position on tariffs on Mexico and poor Lopez Obrador saying that, you know, America First is a fallacy. And this week he's decided maybe he could use those, you know, hundreds of billions of dollars that come from Norte.

ROLLINS: Well, a spotlight goes on and all the jobs in Mexico got making American cars, they cannot w win that battle. The President's clearly won this battle, he's put pressure on them and I think --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Well, we better start -- by the way, Lopez Obrador, the populist president, so-called, Mexico has now decided that he can just tell the President what he's done so far to help him with illegal immigration. He doesn't really have to do anything. I mean, he actually said that, Michael. Absolutely, he misses the point.

GOODWIN: Somehow, the migrants have not gotten the memo because they keep coming in these record numbers.

DOBBS: Yes. Just think what they'd be doing if the Mexican government --

(CROSSTALK)

GOODWIN: Please don't help any more.

DOBBS: -- tough enforcement. Ed Rollins, Michael Goodwin --

ROLLINS: Thank you.

DOBBS: -- thank you both, gentlemen.

ROLLINS: Great. Thanks.

DOBBS: The number of people taking the oath of U.S. citizenship has reached a five-year high despite howls from the radical Dimms and their associates in the left-wing national media, President Trump's immigration policies are producing more naturalized citizens than at any time before. Swearing in almost 757,000 people as new citizens in 2018. The trajectory is higher.

Up next, just how far the Clinton machine went to disrupt the Trump presidency, perhaps overthrow the government.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey, don't move.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Don't move. What made this man jump up off the ground? We'll have that and much, much more right after the break. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Department of Homeland Security Acting Secretary Kevin McAleenan reportedly met with CNN anchor Jake Tapper in an off-the-record meeting in late May. According to one report, an administration official said that McAleenan is quote, more concerned with ingratiating himself with other Never Trumpers who've always advocated for open borders. McAleenan appeared with Tapper this weekend on CNN's State of the Union.

A brand new report tonight from The Hill's John Solomon detailing the Clinton campaign's abuse of the Intelligence Community in an effort to stop President Trump from being elected to the White House. In that article Solomon says Clinton gained dozens of political IOU's from patrons who then donated to the Clinton Foundation. Solomon argues it's now time for the American public to call in their own IOUs on political transparency and to get some answers to 10 questions that he asked in his newest article on The Hill.

Award-winning investigative journalist John Solomon with us tonight. John, great to have you here.

JOHN SOLOMON, OPINION CONTRIBUTOR, THE HILL: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: This is one of the most frustrating questions I think that we any of us have faced and you in the lead journalistically in this story of Spygate is why, why is Hillary Clinton to this very day untouchable?

SOLOMON: It is remarkable, it's been 18 months since we learned that the Clinton campaign and the DNC funded the Steele dossier. So, we now learned that the FBI investigation, the key evidence was funded by the Hillary Clinton campaign. And yet, not a single reporter has asked a question at any venue where Mrs. Clinton has appeared in the last 18 months. And her campaign has not responded in 18 months to the Senate Judiciary Committee's request for documents and answers. And the questions are, what did she know and when did she know it? Her campaign, her apparatus Christopher Steele launched an FBI investigation. Her campaign flooded the FBI with bad Intel and no one's ever asked her the questions.

DOBBS: And I think the essence of this outrage is contained in one paragraph certainly, and if I may share this with the audience, never before in history until 2016, if we could put that up. Had the apparatus of U.S. presidential candidate managed to sic the full weight of the FBI and U.S. intelligence community on his or her rival nominee during an election and by using a foreign Fed, uncorroborated, to be kind, political opposition research document. I mean, that is the essence of the political outrage and what we still don't know much about.

SOLOMON: This was a giant political dirty trick in the FBI and the CIA and other intelligence apparatus were used to carry it out. We now know 2-1/2 years later, there was no collusion but someone created the illusion of collusion for two years. The FBI in the lead and Mrs. Clinton's political opposition research team in the -- in the rear feeding it. It's absolutely remarkable that she hasn't been asked any questions. So, I posited 10 questions and hopefully the public will start to focus on what we need to get her to answer.

DOBBS: And I want to turn to your column on May 29th, because the president is in -- is in London.

SOLOMON: Sure.

DOBBS: And the question is always, you know, it's fundamental but it's even more proximate right now with the president there.

SOLOMON: Right.

DOBBS: And the headline is, did the Brits warned about Steele's credibility before Mueller's probe, your thoughts?

SOLOMON: Yes. So, we are now -- we've interviewed several witnesses and several members of Congress who have gained information just in the last few weeks at the British National Security Adviser rode the incoming Trump administration in January 17, long before Mueller was reported even before the first -- the second FISA was issued warning -- the Brits were warning them that they thought Christopher Steele had no credibility, was lacking in reliability, that his allegations weren't corroborated. It's extraordinary if that happened now. Everybody's looking for this letter, it's been lost or misplaced but there are witnesses who remember it and there's a search underway in Congress to locate it.

It would be an extraordinary document and it would raise a lot of questions, because if they warned the Trump administration as they were coming in 10 days before inauguration, they almost certainly would have also warned the Obama administration before these additional FISAs were sought. It's a remarkable time and I think President Trump has the opportunity while in Britain with Theresa May to perhaps get some answers about what the Brits know now.

DOBBS: Do we know to which of our chambers on Capitol Hill the letter was sent to whom?

SOLOMON: Yes, so the letter was sent from Sir Mark Lyall Grant then the National Security Advisor Great Britain to Mike Flynn the incoming National Security adviser to Donald Trump, and that's a remarkable in it of itself. Flynn, says to his lawyers he doesn't remember that letter but he was questioned about it by Bob Mueller during the briefings that occurred. So, even Bob Mueller's team knew the letter existed. What we're trying to do is locate that letter now and several members of Congress in the House and the Senate are in search of that letter tonight.

DOBBS: That letter, had Mike Flynn remembered it, could have changed history, could it not?

SOLOMON: It really could have. Imagined if we learned in January 2017 that Christopher Steele's reliability, credibility was being questioned not only within the FBI as we now know but by the for -- the government for whom he formerly worked, the British government.

Remember, he's a former MI6 agent that would have -- it almost certainly changed the course of history if it had become public at the time.

DOBBS: John, as always, good to have you here. Thanks so much.

SOLOMON: Thank you, sir.

DOBBS: John Solomon. Up next, new signs China's Huawei is under -- unrelenting pressure from the -- from the president's blacklist.

DOBBS: China's Huawei plans to sell its 51 percent stake in the undersea cable business. Huawei Marine Hengtong Optic-Electric will buy the state for an undisclosed price. That sale will keep critical undersea internet cables in Chinese hands. Huawei Marine recently built or upgraded 90 undersea fiber-optic cables. Get ready for this, that accounts for almost a fourth of all underwater cables in all the world.

Well, joining me now, Dr. Michael Pillsbury, director of the Center for Chinese Strategy at the Hudson Institute, author, trade advisor to the Trump administration. Michael, great to have you here.

DR. MICHAEL PILLSBURY, DIRECTOR, SENATE CENTER FOR CHINESE STRATEGY: Hi, Lou.

DOBBS: First the implications if we may of Chinese dominance and control of undersea cables.

PILLSBURY: Well, so much information flows to those cables, 90 percent far more than satellites that it allows Chinese espionage and eavesdropping just a chance of a lifetime. I think this is all part of the long term technology war that's going on. I don't think this divestiture, if you want to call it that, the sale by Huawei is going to work. The company they want to sell it to as you know, Lou is affiliated with the Chinese Navy.

So, Huawei is closer to the Army, it's just a shift from the Chinese army to the Chinese Navy. It does show how important dominating these fiber- optics cables is to Chinese espionage.

DOBBS: It also demonstrates how just raw the Chinese have become in expressing their contempt for the intelligence and the powerlessness of Western nations who would oppose their dominance, whether it be in satellite or undersea cables or whether it would be in 5G technology, you name it. They're coming right at the United States, at Europe, all of the developed nations of the West.

PILLSBURY: I agree, especially Europe. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was pretty tough in Berlin on Friday about the access to information they will lose if they go ahead with Huawei. I think we can expect something out of tomorrow's meeting with President Trump and Theresa May. And the British still think they cannot sell the core to Huawei, but just peripheral parts of 5G. I think that's not correct, I think the president is right.

DOBBS: Yes, it's stunning that the British have themselves so twisted in conflicting knots here when it should be a straightforward proposition. A matter of national security, a matter of preserving the -- as the president and the Queen toasted, one of the world's most enduring special relationships between the U.K. and the United States. It seems to be going sideways now.

PILLSBURY: I think it began last month when the Italians signed up for the Belt and Road Initiative, that was my first Chinese success. But what Europe does tonight and tomorrow about the June 4th Tiananmen Massacre of 30 years ago will also be important. They're going to be meetings here in Washington, demonstrations in Hong Kong. We can't let this the 30-year anniversary go by in the past European human rights activists have done something about the Tiananmen anniversary. So, we'll see tomorrow what they do.

DOBBS: I will offer one opinion on that when the United States decoupled human rights and its commercial trade interest, it was a tragic mistake for this country and for indeed our allies as well.

Michael Pillsbury, as always, great to have you with us. Thanks so much.

PILLSBURY: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: President Trump in the U.K. tonight. He along with Queen Elizabeth II, reaffirming the special relationship between the United States and Britain. Edward Lawrence in London tonight and has the story.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, Lou, the Queen hosts about two state visits per year. Only three U.S. presidents hold this distinction with Queen Elizabeth. That's President Bush in 2003, President Obama in 2011 and now President Trump. And the Queen tonight toasted to the United States, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH II, QUEEN OF THE UNITED KINGDOM: While the world has changed, we are forever mindful of the original purpose of these structures. Nations working together to safeguard a hard-won peace.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: For the White House, this is a chance to show the United Kingdom that the U.S. will stand with them through Brexit. In fact, the U.S. is negotiating with the U.K. for a trade deal while the White House hopes to announce that deal in the days after Brexit. And the president during his toasts referenced how the Queen of England helped during World War II as a mechanic helping some vehicles as the war was coming to an end. She's saying that the two countries have enduring bonds.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: On behalf of all Americans, I offer a toast to the eternal friendship of our people, the vitality of our nations and to the long cherished and truly remarkable reign of Her Majesty the Queen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And tomorrow, the President will be meeting with some business leaders in a roundtable with British Prime Minister Theresa May. Then the two world leaders will have a joint news conference. A spokesman for the British government says the Prime Minister will talk to the President about climate change. The White House says that the president wants to talk about trade and the possible security risk that Huawei could be.

Now, we haven't seen any large protests here in the United Kingdom today. However, there are larger protests scheduled for tomorrow. We'll have to see what happens. Lou, back to you.

DOBBS: And thank you very much. Of course, that hasn't stopped the national left-wing media in this country from talking all about protests, a day of pomp and protest declared one headline. Ed Lawrence from London, thanks so much.

Body camera video capturing a Tennessee sheriff's deputy saving two people from a rattlesnake.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Hey, don't move. There's a rattlesnake right next to you. Don't move.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK, OK.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Go toward me. Go toward me. Come here. Don't run away. Come here. Don't run away. Come here. Go toward me. That's a rattlesnake.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: This is in Columbia, Tennessee, south of Nashville. The deputy had been called to the scene after a complaint about the couple laying on a dirt road. Neither snake -- neither the snake nor the couple were injured. We do not have any idea what the couple were doing in the middle of the road. We do know what the rattlesnake was doing of course, but didn't do much harm after all.

Up next, the federal government threatening big tech with well, with maybe a big break up. We'll have that and much more right after this break. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Joining us tonight John Lonski. He's Chief Economist, Managing Director at Moody's. And we've got a lot for you to sort through. Let's start with over 100 point fall and the Nasdaq. Big tech looks to be in big trouble because they have been too big, too powerful, and acting anti- competitively at least in the minds of some, but particularly the Trump Justice Department. What is going on and what do you expect to happen from here?

JOHN LONSKI, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MOODY'S: Well, that creates a lot of uncertainty, doesn't it, for what big techs are going to be able to do in the future, the Tech Titans. I think it may adversely affect technology overall in a way. Let's not forget that a lot of these startups, money pours in on the expectation that the startup eventually gets sold to one of the tech Titans, and that's how you reap the big gains.

I don't think the weakness in this area is over. I'd like to add something though. If we take out big tech today, I think the overall market did pretty good. You know, these lower bond yields as an index of housing secretary share prices. That was up by more than one percent.

DOBBS: Right. The overall index is relatively modest, though, I think you would agree whether you know, it is the S&P or whether it's the Dow. So we've got a lot -- certainly not as bad as the Nasdaq, not anywhere near as bad, but it's clearly a signal that Silicon Valley has got real, real trouble on its hands.

LONSKI: The game is changing thanks to Washington. You know, the regulator is taking a closer look at the possibility, anti-competitive behavior.

DOBBS: You know what's funny is the House Judiciary Committee tonight has launched its own investigation, antitrust investigation trying to piggyback on the backs of Donald Trump, the man they spend all of their time harassing and annoying. But meanwhile the Justice Department has taken jurisdiction, the FTC has taken jurisdiction. They're in charge and the House, I don't know what they think they're doing.

LONSKI: Well, you know, for the longest period of time, Congress has sort of been a lagging indicator of what's going on politically, and that is -- that's a big problem for this country. I think the fact that Congress doesn't want to go ahead and assert its powers when it comes through immigration.

DOBBS: Powers of what?

LONSKI: Well, I mean --

DOBBS: These people are so impotent, so bereft of any idea, any energy. To watch on Nadler, a Schiff, which one of these geniuses do you want setting policy for the United States? I thank you very much, John Lonski, but I don't want them near policy.

LONSKI: Well, you're not always going to have a Donald Trump in the presidency. And we had a problem again with Obama, with the EPA going ahead and making regulation.

DOBBS: I know all the problems with Obama, what's the problem with Donald Trump?

LONSKI: Well, you know, some of the markets aren't exactly happy with the fact that Trump out of the blue imposes these tariffs special in the case of Mexico.

DOBBS: Wait a minute. Wait a minute, which part of the market is -- which part of the market, John Lonski is so happy with the $5 trillion on economic growth that we have sacrificed through trade deficits and oh yes, let's take up the trillions of dollars that the Chinese have stolen from us in intellectual property and technology over the past 20 years. Which part of the market is so thrilled with all that because we need to line them up?

LONSKI: Well, you know, we're still -- you know, we're still up under both Obama and Trump. We haven't -- the markets still doing well. It's taking higher profitability is growing.

DOBBS: Well, just take it -- let's keep it very simple.

LONSKI: I don't think there's --

DOBBS: Keep it simple.

LONSKI: I think they see that there is --

DOBBS: Let's keep it simple. Take it from an election day 2016 to now and how much are the equity markets up.

LONSKI: Put it this way. I think there was some problem that the market has with the fact that these proposed tariffs on Mexico came out of blue to deal with an issue --

DOBBS: OK, well, let me ask you this. Which part of the market is upset about 70,000 opiate deaths from -- as a result of the fentanyl, the opioids in one form another being smuggled across that border, the $50 billion the cartels are taking home? Which part of the market is upset by the other $30 to $50 billion in remittances that are being shipped across, and not to mention all of the money they make -- the cartels are making from smuggling illegals across that border.

LONSKI: Well, you're saying it's OK. The equity market is not the final measure of all things.

DOBBS: I'm telling you that -- I think it's not a final measure but I think that we're not even looking at all the measures that are there. And those are the measures we need to look at because that's where the greatest devastation is occurring. John Lonski, great to see you my friend.

LONSKI: Same here.

DOBBS: Thanks so much. Up next, new e-mail show special treatment of Hillary Clinton by the FBI. You knew that back in 2016. Wasn't that erased? And a great outcome. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Judicial Watch uncovering new Strzok-Page e-mails that show the FBI gave special treatment to Hillary Clinton's demands. Tom Fitton of Judicial Watch joining us to talk about Judicial Watch's significant findings.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TOM FITTON, PRESIDENT, JUDICIAL WATCH: This is extraordinary, special treatment for a presidential candidate, someone they presumed was going to be president, and recalled at the same they were breaking the law arguably to target her opposition then-Candidate Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And President Trump in London tomorrow will meet with British Prime Minister Theresa May. And later in the day, he'll be holding a joint press conference. That should be interesting. That's it for us tonight. We thank you for being with us tonight.

National security expert Christian Whiton, attorneys Harmeet Dhillon and Emily Compagno among our guest here tomorrow as -- you know, we're going to bring you right up to date on the latest on the deep state and the Radical DIMMs. A reminder to follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs. We thank you for joining us. See you tomorrow. Good night from New York.

urn:contentItem:5T9W-FN31-JB20-G0MN-00000-00Trump Speaks in Vegas; Trump Defends His Supreme Court Pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh; Google Bias Concern; Trump Best Economic History; Dow, S&P Hit All-Times High; WH Official: Hopeful a Deal with Canada will be Reached by Sept. 30; Sky Auction Starts Today2018-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisINTELLIGENCE REPORT2:00 PM ESTNed Ryun, James Freeman, John Lonski, Heather ZumarragaNEWSFinancial092101cb.232Trump Speaks in Vegas; Trump Defends His Supreme Court Pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh; Google Bias Concern; Trump Best Economic History; Dow, S&P Hit All-Times High; WH Official: Hopeful a Deal with Canada will be Reached by Sept. 30; Sky Auction Starts TodayAshley Webster, Edward Lawrence, Jehmu Greene, Hillary Vaughn, Scott Martin, Blake Burman

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes, see you my friend.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I'll take it from here Mr. Cavuto and Mr. President.

CAVUTO: All right.

WEBSTER: In fact breaking right now President Trump will be speaking any minute from now at Veterans Affairs Hospital in Las Vegas. There is the scene. We are waiting for the President. He's speech comes just hours after that huge rally for Republican Senator Dean Heller where the President defended Judge Brett Kavanaugh and touted the strength of our economy and of course the stock market which is doing well again today.

Speaking of that market, we are looking at another record day on Wall Street, the Dow, S&P, hitting all-time highs again today. It could be 101st record for the Dow since election day. And it's up another 83 points. The S&P also up, look at the NASDAQ just slightly lower, but overall another strong day.

And good afternoon, everybody, I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. And welcome, everyone, to "The Intelligence Report."

And as we wait for the President to take that stage in Las Vegas, I want to get to our other top story, President Trump defending his Supreme Court pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh as he calls on the accuser to come forward with evidence so that we can learn more about the alleged sexual assault.

Meanwhile, Dr. Christine Ford, the woman at the center of it the controversy says she is willing to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee but only under her terms. All for the latest on this, let's bring in our Edward Lawrence on Capitol Hill.

And Edward, where do we stand on the issue of Dr. Ford testifying? When and if is that -- when is that going to happen?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, yes. Ashley, all I can say there was 10:00 deadline today and Senator Chuck Grassley set to say if she is going to testify or not. That came and went. The negotiations are ongoing.

Now, Senator Chuck Grassley still talking to committee members at this hour. Also key players like Senator Susan Collins related to how they want to go forward with this. And Ford's attorney has then negotiating with the committee and she said Ford does wants to testify but under certain conditions.

First, she wants to make sure that no lawyers asking questions, only the members of the committee. And Judge Brett Kavanaugh can't be in the room. She also wants Kavanaugh to testify first.

The Senator Chuck Grassley has said that Kavanaugh testifying first is a non-starter. In fact, legal experts say that it is very unusual to have the accused testify before the accuser puts the accusations on -- under oath.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, AMERICAN LAWYER: That is the most absurd, anti-due process, anti-American concept. You testify without having been formally accused under oath?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And President Donald Trump venting his frustration on Twitter saying that this is political stunt by Senator Dianne Feinstein saying she held on to the letter to the very last minute to try and delay the Kavanaugh confirmation. President Trump adding that Democrats don't really want answers to this, they just want to delay this confirmation. Then he tweeted, "If the attack was as bad as she said, charges would have been filed immediately with local law enforcement by her either or her loving parents."

The Democrats for their part or Republicans for their part are sticking with Kavanaugh as their candidate or nominee for the Supreme Court. Democrats saying that a full investigation needs to happen including testimony under oath.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS COONS (D), DELAWARE SENATOR: I do hope that she testifies but I deeply respect her hesitation, given the ways in which her life and her family's life have already been disrupted by attacks, by disrespect, by death threats.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And officially the meeting or a hearing on Monday has not been canceled. Brett Kavanaugh has said that he wants to testify under oath to clear his name. Again he could testify Monday. We'll just have to see how the negotiations end up.

Ashley.

WEBSTER: All right. Edward Lawrence, thank you so much, Edward.

And as we wait for the President I'm joined by assistant editor for "Wall Street Journal" Editorial Page, James Freeman and American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun.

Ned, let me begin with you. I was looking at your notes on this. You said, we really have devolved into the theater of the absurd here. What part of this is the most absurd in your opinion?

NED RYUN, AMERICAN MAJORITY CEO: Where to start. I mean, honestly, Dr. Ford and her lawyers have been given every opportunity to bring forward her accusations. Even, Ashley they offered to send staff out to California to have an interview with her.

And I think it's time we probably hit a stop button on this. We got to the point, now Democrats seem to think that the FBI is their personal investigation arm. And I know they got that impression when Comey was the head of the FBI but that's not how it works. The FBI does not have jurisdiction. Kavanaugh has already been through six background checks.

Ashley, I've been through a background check by the FBI for top security clearance at the Pentagon. They are extremely thorough. They go anywhere and everywhere and they dig into everything and then they ripple out start asking as many people as possible.

I have to tell you if you've been through six background checks by the FBI, somewhere, someone at some time would have said something about this and not one peep until now. And the second thing, as Edward was just saying this is utterly absurd and flipped everything, including common sense on its head to say Kavanaugh has to actually testify first before his accuser. That's insane.

And, I have to tell you, for this lawyer to try and put up list of demands and hold the Senate hostage with her demands is insane. And I think what Chuck Grassley and Republicans need to do is say, "We gave you 10:00 a.m. deadline."

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: "We are going to continue with our meeting -- the hearing on Monday and if you don't show up that's fine. We will have a vote and move forward with the people's business."

WEBSTER: James, is the judge being treated fairly here?

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think so. I mean, quite an odd spectacle.

WEBSTER: I'm sorry to interrupt. Let me follow that up, a lot of leading Democrats in my mind have already convicted him. Comments likes he committed --

FREEMAN: Right.

WEBSTER: -- attempted rape but GOP happy to put him on the court. You can't say that thing. The guy -- it's all alleged. Where does he get his reputation back? It's the question.

FREEMAN: He has been slammed in the media absolutely. And we should point out it's not just the President tweeting bout the way this was handled by Senator Feinstein, sitting on --

WEBSTER: Right.

FREEMAN: -- the accusation for months, not including it in more than 1000 questions that went to Judge Kavanaugh, not mentioning it during the lengthy hearings on his nomination. This is also caused a lot of what we might call the liberal media to criticize him as well. Senator Feinstein's hometown paper in San Francisco, the chronicle.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: A lot of commentary in the "Los Angeles Times," "The New York Times." So this strategy of delaying and then springing this information has really not served anyone. I think Chairman Grassley and the Judiciary Committee made a reasonable response to say, "OK. We will reopen this process, even though Senator Feinstein you sat on the information for so long. We're going to have a hearing Monday."

Finally the professor has a chance to tell this story and, this spectacle - -

WEBSTER: But under what conditions, you know. You know, how can the accused to go first when he doesn't really understand what the exact accusations are? He should be responding to them.

FREEMAN: And why are her lawyers trying so hard to delay the moment when she can share what she knows?

WEBSTER: Right. Right. I don't know.

MARTIN: I'll try. See you, man.

WEBSTER: In Chicago, Scott, thank you and we'll be right back.

WEBSTER: Breaking today, the White House says it is very hopeful that trade deal deal with Canada could be reach by the end of the month.

For the very latest lets go to our very own Blake Burman, at the White House trying to keeping track of all this.

Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Ashley. We've got debrief from a White House official as it relates to pretty much the two main trade discussions going on right now with the United States, as they're trying to rework trade deals, Canada and China. The United States, The Trump administration at this point, much more optimistic with the way forward on Canada than as it relates to China.

Canada, a deal has to, when you weave through all the legal wrangling of this, essentially be worked out by the end of the month. And this White House official who gave us the debrief said, they are optimistic that something will get done.

The main sticking point, though, here is dairy. And here is what this White House official told us, "It really is on Canada to decide speaking about a deal. We got a great deal and I think they should be very happy with a lot of the things with the deal with Mexico and they've got to decide, are they going to kill this deal with them because of their dairy program?"

As you know, President Trump has long complained about the tariff situation with Canada, and dairy. That is the main sticking point going forward with Canada. But the administration feels that something could potentially be worked out with Canada by the end of the month.

As it relates to China though there is a much more long-term view that the administration is taking with the Chinese as there are no official scheduled talks right now, between the United States and China. Though this White House official tells us there is communication, constantly between the two.

Here's what this White House official, though, told us, "I don't know when China will finally commit to make the changes it needs to make. Obviously the I.P.," meaning I.P. theft, "is a big one."

"We're also talking to them about agricultural things. And we're talking to them about real structural changes and I hope it will be soon. I hope it's soon, but these agreements take time."

As for phase three of potential tariffs with China, Ashley, the $267 billion that President Trump has threatened against China, this White House official not assigning a certain date as to when that could potentially come. And I asked that White House official is there anything down the pipeline as it relates to after the 267 billion potentially? This White House official says they do not want to go there just yet.

WEBSTER: No.

BURMAN: Ashley.

WEBSTER: I'm just talking about phase three is a bit kind of disappointing as well. But Blake Burman at the White House, Blake, thank you very much.

BURMAN: Thanks.

WEBSTER: Appreciate that.

Let's take a look at markets for you, on the upside on the Dow again up 66 points, the S&P also just on the up side, the NASDAQ slightly lower. Have more on the markets when we come back.

WEBSTER: The takeover battle for British broadcaster Sky will be decided this weekend. British regulators say Comcast and 21st Century Fox, our parent company, will settle their takeover battle for Sky through an auction starting today.

And our Susan Li is here, she's been following this story. Isn't this an unusual way to kind of close out this deal?

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: It's rare.

WEBSTER: Rare.

LI: Rare. Yes. It's only happened three times since 2007 in the U.K. that they've used this auction process --

WEBSTER: Right.

LI: -- to settle any assets. This is the biggest prize ever in the auction process.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: Thirty-five billion dollars and today was the deadline. So here the latest new is, today was the deadline for either Comcast or Fox to withdraw any of their cash bids. No one was going --

WEBSTER: No one has done that. No.

LI: So, Saturday is this going to be three rounds, first round, Fox bids. Second round, Comcast counter-bids.

WEBSTER: It's the way to --

LI: Then third round -- wait, wait, this is important because then you have --

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: -- a seals envelope high drama bid and this is where game theory comes in, right? Because you don't know what the other side is bidding so you don't want to bid too much but you don't want to bid too low, where you don't win the actual auction.

WEBSTER: And then at the end you open the envelop and the Oscar goes to?

LI: Right. And that will be announced on Saturday evening by U.K. regulators and then shareholders of Sky have three weeks to decide who they want to choose. Obviously the higher bid will most likely get the better choice.

WEBSTER: And to confuse all of this so just a little bit more, Disney is buying a large number of assets of 21st Century Fox. So, do they inherently then go on and assume Sky?

LI: OK. So this is what happens --

WEBSTER: If Fox wins the bid.

LI: Its -- yes. So, it's very complicated because of that whole who owns who stays (ph) for who.

WEBSTER: Yes. Right. Right. Right.

LI: As we know, Disney of course winning the bid for Fox assets --

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: -- Fox owns 39 percent of Sky. And then, so, lets say, you know, Comcast wins the bid --

WEBSTER: Right.

LI: --Disney still kind of wins because --

WEBSTER: They have to --

LI: -- they own 39 percent. And if that goes up to a high premium there, you know, if they decide to offload some of those Sky assets which no one says that they will at this point, they actually also get a higher pricing for the assets they already own. Does that make sense?

WEBSTER: It makes sense to me, it's a bit in the weeds, but this is a complicated process. So, where's the highest bid stand right now? Is it Comcast, of what?

LI: Comcast at nine --

WEBSTER: Thirty-five percent?

LI: So, I converted to U.S. dollars for --

WEBSTER: OK.

LI: -- our U.S. audience.

WEBSTER: Very good.

LI: It's at $19, its 14 pounds 75 cents --

WEBSTER: OK.

LI: -- something in that category. That's higher than the $18 and change the Fox has bid, but slightly higher. But we should point out where actual Sky is trading that $21.

So, what that tells you is that the market is anticipating obviously a very competitive bidding process and that price could go much, much higher. But it depends at the end of the day what you think Sky is worth. And from the actions that we've seen, you know, Fox has made several attempts to buy Sky. And the rest of Sky doesn't (INAUDIBLE) own.

WEBSTER: Is it that prized an asset?

LI: It is.

WEBSTER: Consider the price --

LI: Twenty-three million subscribers, right?

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: We talk about this in the UK.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: I mean sports, is probably the crown jewel at --

WEBSTER: From Italy.

LI: -- Sky broadcasting.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: Yet they also have a news division as well.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: This is an opportunity for both Disney and Comcast to increase their international footprint which is something they want to do, especially Comcast, which has such a domestic focused business, right?

WEBSTER: So, by Saturday night we should know.

LI: We should know what the bids are.

WEBSTER: What the bids are.

LI: And then the Sky shareholders vote.

WEBSTER: Good job. Complicated story but you made it clear.

LI: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Susan Li thank you so much.

As we head towards the end of this hour we can say the Dow up another 60 points. What a week it's been for the markets, money continuing to come into Wall Street, the Dow at 26,717. Not bad. Can we hang on for the next hour to finish in the green?

And I don't think it's any surprise the Cleveland Browns win their first game in what nearly 639 days. They've gone 19 games out a win. They win and guess what?

Liz Claman isn't in today. Maybe celebrating a bit too much last night, Lauren Simonetti?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Dilly-dilly.

WEBSTER: Dilly-dilly, yes.

SIMONETTI: Ashley Webster. Have a good weekend sir.

WEBSTER: You too.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TBJ-3N01-JBHT-D31B-00000-00Trump Speaks in Vegas; Trump Defends His Supreme Court Pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh; Google Bias Concern; Trump Best Economic History; Dow, S&P Hit All-Times High; WH Official: Hopeful a Deal with Canada will be Reached by Sept. 30; Sky Auction Starts Today2018-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisTrump Speaks in Vegas; Trump Defends His Supreme Court Pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh; Google Bias Concern; Trump Best Economic History; Dow, S&P Hit All-Times High; WH Official: Hopeful a Deal with Canada will be Reached by Sept. 30; Sky Auction Starts TodayLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes, see you my friend.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I'll take it from here Mr. Cavuto and Mr. President.

CAVUTO: All right.

WEBSTER: In fact breaking right now President Trump will be speaking any minute from now at Veterans Affairs Hospital in Las Vegas. There is the scene. We are waiting for the President. He's speech comes just hours after that huge rally for Republican Senator Dean Heller where the President defended Judge Brett Kavanaugh and touted the strength of our economy and of course the stock market which is doing well again today.

Speaking of that market, we are looking at another record day on Wall Street, the Dow, S&P, hitting all-time highs again today. It could be 101st record for the Dow since election day. And it's up another 83 points. The S&P also up, look at the NASDAQ just slightly lower, but overall another strong day.

And good afternoon, everybody, I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. And welcome, everyone, to "The Intelligence Report."

And as we wait for the President to take that stage in Las Vegas, I want to get to our other top story, President Trump defending his Supreme Court pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh as he calls on the accuser to come forward with evidence so that we can learn more about the alleged sexual assault.

Meanwhile, Dr. Christine Ford, the woman at the center of it the controversy says she is willing to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee but only under her terms. All for the latest on this, let's bring in our Edward Lawrence on Capitol Hill.

And Edward, where do we stand on the issue of Dr. Ford testifying? When and if is that -- when is that going to happen?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, yes. Ashley, all I can say there was 10:00 deadline today and Senator Chuck Grassley set to say if she is going to testify or not. That came and went. The negotiations are ongoing.

Now, Senator Chuck Grassley still talking to committee members at this hour. Also key players like Senator Susan Collins related to how they want to go forward with this. And Ford's attorney has then negotiating with the committee and she said Ford does wants to testify but under certain conditions.

First, she wants to make sure that no lawyers asking questions, only the members of the committee. And Judge Brett Kavanaugh can't be in the room. She also wants Kavanaugh to testify first.

The Senator Chuck Grassley has said that Kavanaugh testifying first is a non-starter. In fact, legal experts say that it is very unusual to have the accused testify before the accuser puts the accusations on -- under oath.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, AMERICAN LAWYER: That is the most absurd, anti-due process, anti-American concept. You testify without having been formally accused under oath?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And President Donald Trump venting his frustration on Twitter saying that this is political stunt by Senator Dianne Feinstein saying she held on to the letter to the very last minute to try and delay the Kavanaugh confirmation. President Trump adding that Democrats don't really want answers to this, they just want to delay this confirmation. Then he tweeted, "If the attack was as bad as she said, charges would have been filed immediately with local law enforcement by her either or her loving parents."

The Democrats for their part or Republicans for their part are sticking with Kavanaugh as their candidate or nominee for the Supreme Court. Democrats saying that a full investigation needs to happen including testimony under oath.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS COONS (D), DELAWARE SENATOR: I do hope that she testifies but I deeply respect her hesitation, given the ways in which her life and her family's life have already been disrupted by attacks, by disrespect, by death threats.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And officially the meeting or a hearing on Monday has not been canceled. Brett Kavanaugh has said that he wants to testify under oath to clear his name. Again he could testify Monday. We'll just have to see how the negotiations end up.

Ashley.

WEBSTER: All right. Edward Lawrence, thank you so much, Edward.

And as we wait for the President I'm joined by assistant editor for "Wall Street Journal" Editorial Page, James Freeman and American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun.

Ned, let me begin with you. I was looking at your notes on this. You said, we really have devolved into the theater of the absurd here. What part of this is the most absurd in your opinion?

NED RYUN, AMERICAN MAJORITY CEO: Where to start. I mean, honestly, Dr. Ford and her lawyers have been given every opportunity to bring forward her accusations. Even, Ashley they offered to send staff out to California to have an interview with her.

And I think it's time we probably hit a stop button on this. We got to the point, now Democrats seem to think that the FBI is their personal investigation arm. And I know they got that impression when Comey was the head of the FBI but that's not how it works. The FBI does not have jurisdiction. Kavanaugh has already been through six background checks.

Ashley, I've been through a background check by the FBI for top security clearance at the Pentagon. They are extremely thorough. They go anywhere and everywhere and they dig into everything and then they ripple out start asking as many people as possible.

I have to tell you if you've been through six background checks by the FBI, somewhere, someone at some time would have said something about this and not one peep until now. And the second thing, as Edward was just saying this is utterly absurd and flipped everything, including common sense on its head to say Kavanaugh has to actually testify first before his accuser. That's insane.

And, I have to tell you, for this lawyer to try and put up list of demands and hold the Senate hostage with her demands is insane. And I think what Chuck Grassley and Republicans need to do is say, "We gave you 10:00 a.m. deadline."

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: "We are going to continue with our meeting -- the hearing on Monday and if you don't show up that's fine. We will have a vote and move forward with the people's business."

WEBSTER: James, is the judge being treated fairly here?

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think so. I mean, quite an odd spectacle.

WEBSTER: I'm sorry to interrupt. Let me follow that up, a lot of leading Democrats in my mind have already convicted him. Comments likes he committed --

FREEMAN: Right.

WEBSTER: -- attempted rape but GOP happy to put him on the court. You can't say that thing. The guy -- it's all alleged. Where does he get his reputation back? It's the question.

FREEMAN: He has been slammed in the media absolutely. And we should point out it's not just the President tweeting bout the way this was handled by Senator Feinstein, sitting on --

WEBSTER: Right.

FREEMAN: -- the accusation for months, not including it in more than 1000 questions that went to Judge Kavanaugh, not mentioning it during the lengthy hearings on his nomination. This is also caused a lot of what we might call the liberal media to criticize him as well. Senator Feinstein's hometown paper in San Francisco, the chronicle.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: A lot of commentary in the "Los Angeles Times," "The New York Times." So this strategy of delaying and then springing this information has really not served anyone. I think Chairman Grassley and the Judiciary Committee made a reasonable response to say, "OK. We will reopen this process, even though Senator Feinstein you sat on the information for so long. We're going to have a hearing Monday."

Finally the professor has a chance to tell this story and, this spectacle - -

WEBSTER: But under what conditions, you know. You know, how can the accused to go first when he doesn't really understand what the exact accusations are? He should be responding to them.

FREEMAN: And why are her lawyers trying so hard to delay the moment when she can share what she knows?

WEBSTER: Right. Right. I don't know.

FREEMAN: It's beyond bizarre.

WEBSTER: You know, Ned, will we ever get to the bottom of these allegations? I mean, based on the timeline, --

RYUN: No, I don't think so.

WEBSTER: -- the recollections of Dr. Ford?

RYUN: No, i don't think so. I think that's what so pernicious about this is I think it will come down to he said/she said. You know right now there are no corroborating witnesses to what happened over 35 years ago. There's a lot of gaps, there's a lot of inconsistencies. And this really is a vicious smear.

I go back to what Chuck Schumer said before this confirmation really begin, "We will do anything, basically anything and everything to stop this confirmation from happening." Well, they've clearly shown that any shred of decency they have left they decided to go away with that and go after and smear him, what I think a very vicious smear.

But Ashley, you said something that I think is very important. In this country, we have always operated in our legal system but even in society with the presumption of innocence until proven guilty.

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: And now we have this Orwellian view of, you're guilty until you can prove yourself innocent.

WEBSTER: Yes.

RYUN: This is a very vague accusation with a lot of details missing. And now people are saying, "Well, Kavanaugh is guilty." How on earth do we even know what happened?

WEBSTER: Yes.

RYUN: And the sad part is, I don't know if we're ever going to get to the bottom of it.

WEBSTER: And that's my question. I don't think we can.

And James, what about GOP, some the Republican senators that may end up opting out of voting for Brett Kavanaugh? The Bob Corker, who else, we have Jeff Flake, Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, they may just opt not to vote for him?

FREEMAN: Well, that's possible. But I think given that Chairman Grassley has given this hearing, this opportunity for the professor to say her peace.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: I don't understand what the argument would be, unless, the result of Monday and I think it should go forward Monday, unless that result is that she raises issues that the judge doesn't have an answer for. Other than that, if we're at the same place where it's a accusation -- WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: -- but no additional detail, no further evidence, I don't know what their argument would be. And I think the reason this is getting delayed so much is the people who really don't want to vote on this nomination --

WEBSTER: Right.

FREEMAN: -- are Democrats running in Trump states.

WEBSTER: That's right. And that's why they're delaying it.

Ned, very quickly, didn't Anita Hill at least have the FBI investigate Clarence Thomas? And you know, I wouldn't say it was a huge investigation but they were brought in for a small portion of that investigation. Could we not do that here?

RYU&N: They were, again, I don't know if we're really dealing with honest brokers on the other side, Ashley. If we say this, and it's delayed even more days. And then maybe something else will come up. I'm sorry at the end of the day, again I'm highly skeptical of all of this. This really smells to me like the left has a stall delay tactic to try and push this back until, maybe, potentially past the midterms.

And so, what this is really all about, Ashley, the left is terrified of losing the Supreme Court, the balance of it to an originalist like Kavanaugh and taking away their favorite tool for expanding their administrative state. That is what this is all about.

WEBSTER: I mean, can they push ahead and go with this, the Senate Judiciary just go ahead and vote and then get it to the full Senate?

RYUN: Sure. And you know, you don't need to disbelief the professor to also think that it's unreasonable with so little evidence to --

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: -- end his career and this nomination. And to think, regardless of what happened, the process was abused by Democrats here. There is a, way for the Senate to evaluate nominees. They didn't follow it.

WEBSTER: All right. I have to leave it right there. As you can see this is a North Las Wegas V.A. medical Center. That's President Trump, moving to the podium. He's going to be signing a bill, more money for the Veterans Affairs Department.

Let's listen here.

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, thank you very much. Please. It's great to be with you. And thank you to Secretary Wilkie, who is doing an incredible job, I have to say. And also to the great leadership of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Some of those great leaders are with us today.

Today, I'm honored to be at the North Las Vegas V.A. Medical Center to sign into law a historic government funding bill that will renovate our nation's military bases and provide great world-class care to our great veterans. Unless you don't want it. Unless you don't want it.

I want to thank your state's great senator, Dean Heller. He has been so helpful. Dean has really been helpful. He's worked all the way, right from the beginning. And this was very important for him. But for working so hard to get the bill passed and get it put right on my desk, and to pass the groundbreaking V.A. reform. There's never been reform like we've been able to do over the last very short period of time.

Thank you, as well, to Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval for being such a strong advocate for Nevada's veterans. We're also -- thank you, Brian. Thank you, Brian.

We're also very grateful to be joined by Nevada Attorney General Adam Laxalt. Thank you, Adam. Great job. Hear he's doing well.

To every veteran here today, we are eternally grateful for your noble service to our nation. I would like to ask all of the veterans with us now to, please, proudly stand. That's great. That's great.

You're fantastic people. You're really fantastic people. Please. Thank you. You really are.

And we're fighting to make sure that you get the care that you so richly earned. And today's legislation is one more promise that the Trump administration is keeping. And we've done a lot of promises, and we've kept them all. And this is another one for the veterans.

With this funding bill, we've increased the VA's budget to the largest ever. We are delivering the resources needed to fully implement crucial V.A. reforms that, as you know, we've gotten. You know the reforms. We're going to go over them in a minute, but they are some reforms. And to deliver for our great veterans, just the way I said I would constantly on the campaign trail.

You backed me, and I back you. That's the way it works, right? That's the way it's supposed to work in life.

And with our booming economy, which is now, I think we can easily say, the greatest economy maybe we've ever had in our country. Stock markets yesterday, and I believe they're up today, so that means today. But the stock markets yesterday hit the highest they've ever been in the history of our country. And we've broken the record, now, over 100 times. So we keep breaking it, breaking it.

And actually, we have a long way to go. There's tremendous potential.

So with our booming economy, I'm also proud to report that the veteran's unemployment recently achieved its lowest level in more than 20 years. That means a lot of jobs. A lot of jobs are taking place.

Last year, I also signed into law the landmark V.A. Accountability Act. You know all about that. And that was something that was very important to me. Because you couldn't do anything, you couldn't -- if somebody was bad. You got a lot of great people, but you have some bad ones. You couldn't do anything. Now you can do it.

So I want to thank the dedicated Veterans Affairs doctors, nurses, and staff members who join us. Now, we're finally rewarding the many great people at the VA, while also ensuring that those who mistreat our veterans, we had people that really mistreated our veterans, they are now being held accountable. That's why it's called the V.A. Accountability Act. And they are being held, seriously, accountable.

Right, Mr. Secretary? He's had a lot of fun. He's had a lot of fun.

We take care of our good ones, and the others are held accountable. Right? And there was no way you could hold them accountable. They could be sadists. You had some of them, too. It doesn't sound nice.

They could be thieves. They could rob you blind. They could steal money, and you couldn't do anything about it. Now you can do whatever you want. Now you do what's right.

And you have a Secretary that's doing what's right. He's tough and he's smart. It's true.

And I can tell you -- this is always a good sign, General Mattis was not happy when I took him out of the Department of Defense. You know, we were going to have him for a short while. And then we said, "You know, he's doing so good, we're going to keep him here." He wasn't happy, and that's usually a good sign. Isn't it, Governor? When they're not -- if they're happy, that's not a good sign. He wasn't happy. He's still not happy. But that's all right. But you're happy, right?

And I said, "You know, if you have lines where you can't see a doctor for two weeks, three weeks, four weeks, twelve days, eight days, how about one day? No good." I said, "I have an idea. Send them out to a private doctor. We got great doctors, and they'll be taken care of immediately. We'll pay the bill." I thought it was like this great idea.

Well, they thought about it for 40 years. They couldn't get it passed. We got it passed. So we have, now, V.A. Choice. So, now, if a veteran can't get the care they need from the V.A. in a timely fashion, they have the right to go see a private doctor.

Today, for the first time in American history, I am about to sign a bill that will fully and permanently give our great and cherished veterans choice, so you don't have to wait on line for 18 days to take care of a simple -- I mean, we had people waiting on line with a simple problem that, by the time they saw the doctor, they were terminally ill. No more of that. If you have a line, you go see a doctor. You get yourself taken care of. We take care of it.

OK? Good. It was amazing. It was amazing.

You would think that would have been easy to pass. Well, there's a reason it took so many years; it wasn't easy. You have different groups and different people. But in the end, we all came together and we got it done. V.A. Choice.

Here with us today is Vin Putignano, a Vietnam veteran who is a great guy, who lives in Las Vegas. And, now, through the Choice program, he can see the specialist doctors that he needs while still getting his primary care through the V.A. medical centers like this one.
