Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TBJ-3N01-JBHT-D307-00000-00Trump Speaks in Vegas; Trump Defends His Supreme Court Pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh; Google Bias Concern; Trump Best Economic History; Dow, S&P Hit All-Times High; WH Official: Hopeful a Deal with Canada will be Reached by Sept. 30; Sky Auction Starts Today2018-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisTrump Speaks in Vegas; Trump Defends His Supreme Court Pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh; Google Bias Concern; Trump Best Economic History; Dow, S&P Hit All-Times High; WH Official: Hopeful a Deal with Canada will be Reached by Sept. 30; Sky Auction Starts TodayLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes, see you my friend.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I'll take it from here Mr. Cavuto and Mr. President.

CAVUTO: All right.

WEBSTER: In fact breaking right now President Trump will be speaking any minute from now at Veterans Affairs Hospital in Las Vegas. There is the scene. We are waiting for the President. He's speech comes just hours after that huge rally for Republican Senator Dean Heller where the President defended Judge Brett Kavanaugh and touted the strength of our economy and of course the stock market which is doing well again today.

Speaking of that market, we are looking at another record day on Wall Street, the Dow, S&P, hitting all-time highs again today. It could be 101st record for the Dow since election day. And it's up another 83 points. The S&P also up, look at the NASDAQ just slightly lower, but overall another strong day.

And good afternoon, everybody, I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. And welcome, everyone, to "The Intelligence Report."

And as we wait for the President to take that stage in Las Vegas, I want to get to our other top story, President Trump defending his Supreme Court pick Judge Brett Kavanaugh as he calls on the accuser to come forward with evidence so that we can learn more about the alleged sexual assault.

Meanwhile, Dr. Christine Ford, the woman at the center of it the controversy says she is willing to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee but only under her terms. All for the latest on this, let's bring in our Edward Lawrence on Capitol Hill.

And Edward, where do we stand on the issue of Dr. Ford testifying? When and if is that -- when is that going to happen?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, yes. Ashley, all I can say there was 10:00 deadline today and Senator Chuck Grassley set to say if she is going to testify or not. That came and went. The negotiations are ongoing.

Now, Senator Chuck Grassley still talking to committee members at this hour. Also key players like Senator Susan Collins related to how they want to go forward with this. And Ford's attorney has then negotiating with the committee and she said Ford does wants to testify but under certain conditions.

First, she wants to make sure that no lawyers asking questions, only the members of the committee. And Judge Brett Kavanaugh can't be in the room. She also wants Kavanaugh to testify first.

The Senator Chuck Grassley has said that Kavanaugh testifying first is a non-starter. In fact, legal experts say that it is very unusual to have the accused testify before the accuser puts the accusations on -- under oath.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, AMERICAN LAWYER: That is the most absurd, anti-due process, anti-American concept. You testify without having been formally accused under oath?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And President Donald Trump venting his frustration on Twitter saying that this is political stunt by Senator Dianne Feinstein saying she held on to the letter to the very last minute to try and delay the Kavanaugh confirmation. President Trump adding that Democrats don't really want answers to this, they just want to delay this confirmation. Then he tweeted, "If the attack was as bad as she said, charges would have been filed immediately with local law enforcement by her either or her loving parents."

The Democrats for their part or Republicans for their part are sticking with Kavanaugh as their candidate or nominee for the Supreme Court. Democrats saying that a full investigation needs to happen including testimony under oath.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS COONS (D), DELAWARE SENATOR: I do hope that she testifies but I deeply respect her hesitation, given the ways in which her life and her family's life have already been disrupted by attacks, by disrespect, by death threats.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And officially the meeting or a hearing on Monday has not been canceled. Brett Kavanaugh has said that he wants to testify under oath to clear his name. Again he could testify Monday. We'll just have to see how the negotiations end up.

Ashley.

WEBSTER: All right. Edward Lawrence, thank you so much, Edward.

And as we wait for the President I'm joined by assistant editor for "Wall Street Journal" Editorial Page, James Freeman and American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun.

Ned, let me begin with you. I was looking at your notes on this. You said, we really have devolved into the theater of the absurd here. What part of this is the most absurd in your opinion?

NED RYUN, AMERICAN MAJORITY CEO: Where to start. I mean, honestly, Dr. Ford and her lawyers have been given every opportunity to bring forward her accusations. Even, Ashley they offered to send staff out to California to have an interview with her.

And I think it's time we probably hit a stop button on this. We got to the point, now Democrats seem to think that the FBI is their personal investigation arm. And I know they got that impression when Comey was the head of the FBI but that's not how it works. The FBI does not have jurisdiction. Kavanaugh has already been through six background checks.

Ashley, I've been through a background check by the FBI for top security clearance at the Pentagon. They are extremely thorough. They go anywhere and everywhere and they dig into everything and then they ripple out start asking as many people as possible.

I have to tell you if you've been through six background checks by the FBI, somewhere, someone at some time would have said something about this and not one peep until now. And the second thing, as Edward was just saying this is utterly absurd and flipped everything, including common sense on its head to say Kavanaugh has to actually testify first before his accuser. That's insane.

And, I have to tell you, for this lawyer to try and put up list of demands and hold the Senate hostage with her demands is insane. And I think what Chuck Grassley and Republicans need to do is say, "We gave you 10:00 a.m. deadline."

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: "We are going to continue with our meeting -- the hearing on Monday and if you don't show up that's fine. We will have a vote and move forward with the people's business."

WEBSTER: James, is the judge being treated fairly here?

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think so. I mean, quite an odd spectacle.

WEBSTER: I'm sorry to interrupt. Let me follow that up, a lot of leading Democrats in my mind have already convicted him. Comments likes he committed --

FREEMAN: Right.

WEBSTER: -- attempted rape but GOP happy to put him on the court. You can't say that thing. The guy -- it's all alleged. Where does he get his reputation back? It's the question.

FREEMAN: He has been slammed in the media absolutely. And we should point out it's not just the President tweeting bout the way this was handled by Senator Feinstein, sitting on --

WEBSTER: Right.

FREEMAN: -- the accusation for months, not including it in more than 1000 questions that went to Judge Kavanaugh, not mentioning it during the lengthy hearings on his nomination. This is also caused a lot of what we might call the liberal media to criticize him as well. Senator Feinstein's hometown paper in San Francisco, the chronicle.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: A lot of commentary in the "Los Angeles Times," "The New York Times." So this strategy of delaying and then springing this information has really not served anyone. I think Chairman Grassley and the Judiciary Committee made a reasonable response to say, "OK. We will reopen this process, even though Senator Feinstein you sat on the information for so long. We're going to have a hearing Monday."

Finally the professor has a chance to tell this story and, this spectacle - -

WEBSTER: But under what conditions, you know. You know, how can the accused to go first when he doesn't really understand what the exact accusations are? He should be responding to them.

FREEMAN: And why are her lawyers trying so hard to delay the moment when she can share what she knows?

WEBSTER: Right. Right. I don't know.

FREEMAN: It's beyond bizarre.

WEBSTER: You know, Ned, will we ever get to the bottom of these allegations? I mean, based on the timeline, --

RYUN: No, I don't think so.

WEBSTER: -- the recollections of Dr. Ford?

RYUN: No, i don't think so. I think that's what so pernicious about this is I think it will come down to he said/she said. You know right now there are no corroborating witnesses to what happened over 35 years ago. There's a lot of gaps, there's a lot of inconsistencies. And this really is a vicious smear.

I go back to what Chuck Schumer said before this confirmation really begin, "We will do anything, basically anything and everything to stop this confirmation from happening." Well, they've clearly shown that any shred of decency they have left they decided to go away with that and go after and smear him, what I think a very vicious smear.

But Ashley, you said something that I think is very important. In this country, we have always operated in our legal system but even in society with the presumption of innocence until proven guilty.

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: And now we have this Orwellian view of, you're guilty until you can prove yourself innocent.

WEBSTER: Yes.

RYUN: This is a very vague accusation with a lot of details missing. And now people are saying, "Well, Kavanaugh is guilty." How on earth do we even know what happened?

WEBSTER: Yes.

RYUN: And the sad part is, I don't know if we're ever going to get to the bottom of it.

WEBSTER: And that's my question. I don't think we can.

And James, what about GOP, some the Republican senators that may end up opting out of voting for Brett Kavanaugh? The Bob Corker, who else, we have Jeff Flake, Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, they may just opt not to vote for him?

FREEMAN: Well, that's possible. But I think given that Chairman Grassley has given this hearing, this opportunity for the professor to say her peace.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: I don't understand what the argument would be, unless, the result of Monday and I think it should go forward Monday, unless that result is that she raises issues that the judge doesn't have an answer for. Other than that, if we're at the same place where it's a accusation -- WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: -- but no additional detail, no further evidence, I don't know what their argument would be. And I think the reason this is getting delayed so much is the people who really don't want to vote on this nomination --

WEBSTER: Right.

FREEMAN: -- are Democrats running in Trump states.

WEBSTER: That's right. And that's why they're delaying it.

Ned, very quickly, didn't Anita Hill at least have the FBI investigate Clarence Thomas? And you know, I wouldn't say it was a huge investigation but they were brought in for a small portion of that investigation. Could we not do that here?

RYU&N: They were, again, I don't know if we're really dealing with honest brokers on the other side, Ashley. If we say this, and it's delayed even more days. And then maybe something else will come up. I'm sorry at the end of the day, again I'm highly skeptical of all of this. This really smells to me like the left has a stall delay tactic to try and push this back until, maybe, potentially past the midterms.

And so, what this is really all about, Ashley, the left is terrified of losing the Supreme Court, the balance of it to an originalist like Kavanaugh and taking away their favorite tool for expanding their administrative state. That is what this is all about.

WEBSTER: I mean, can they push ahead and go with this, the Senate Judiciary just go ahead and vote and then get it to the full Senate?

RYUN: Sure. And you know, you don't need to disbelief the professor to also think that it's unreasonable with so little evidence to --

WEBSTER: Right.

RYUN: -- end his career and this nomination. And to think, regardless of what happened, the process was abused by Democrats here. There is a, way for the Senate to evaluate nominees. They didn't follow it.

WEBSTER: All right. I have to leave it right there. As you can see this is a North Las Wegas V.A. medical Center. That's President Trump, moving to the podium. He's going to be signing a bill, more money for the Veterans Affairs Department.

Let's listen here.

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, thank you very much. Please. It's great to be with you. And thank you to Secretary Wilkie, who is doing an incredible job, I have to say. And also to the great leadership of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Some of those great leaders are with us today.

Today, I'm honored to be at the North Las Vegas V.A. Medical Center to sign into law a historic government funding bill that will renovate our nation's military bases and provide great world-class care to our great veterans. Unless you don't want it. Unless you don't want it.

I want to thank your state's great senator, Dean Heller. He has been so helpful. Dean has really been helpful. He's worked all the way, right from the beginning. And this was very important for him. But for working so hard to get the bill passed and get it put right on my desk, and to pass the groundbreaking V.A. reform. There's never been reform like we've been able to do over the last very short period of time.

Thank you, as well, to Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval for being such a strong advocate for Nevada's veterans. We're also -- thank you, Brian. Thank you, Brian.

We're also very grateful to be joined by Nevada Attorney General Adam Laxalt. Thank you, Adam. Great job. Hear he's doing well.

To every veteran here today, we are eternally grateful for your noble service to our nation. I would like to ask all of the veterans with us now to, please, proudly stand. That's great. That's great.

You're fantastic people. You're really fantastic people. Please. Thank you. You really are.

And we're fighting to make sure that you get the care that you so richly earned. And today's legislation is one more promise that the Trump administration is keeping. And we've done a lot of promises, and we've kept them all. And this is another one for the veterans.

With this funding bill, we've increased the VA's budget to the largest ever. We are delivering the resources needed to fully implement crucial V.A. reforms that, as you know, we've gotten. You know the reforms. We're going to go over them in a minute, but they are some reforms. And to deliver for our great veterans, just the way I said I would constantly on the campaign trail.

You backed me, and I back you. That's the way it works, right? That's the way it's supposed to work in life.

And with our booming economy, which is now, I think we can easily say, the greatest economy maybe we've ever had in our country. Stock markets yesterday, and I believe they're up today, so that means today. But the stock markets yesterday hit the highest they've ever been in the history of our country. And we've broken the record, now, over 100 times. So we keep breaking it, breaking it.

And actually, we have a long way to go. There's tremendous potential.

So with our booming economy, I'm also proud to report that the veteran's unemployment recently achieved its lowest level in more than 20 years. That means a lot of jobs. A lot of jobs are taking place.

Last year, I also signed into law the landmark V.A. Accountability Act. You know all about that. And that was something that was very important to me. Because you couldn't do anything, you couldn't -- if somebody was bad. You got a lot of great people, but you have some bad ones. You couldn't do anything. Now you can do it.

So I want to thank the dedicated Veterans Affairs doctors, nurses, and staff members who join us. Now, we're finally rewarding the many great people at the VA, while also ensuring that those who mistreat our veterans, we had people that really mistreated our veterans, they are now being held accountable. That's why it's called the V.A. Accountability Act. And they are being held, seriously, accountable.

Right, Mr. Secretary? He's had a lot of fun. He's had a lot of fun.

We take care of our good ones, and the others are held accountable. Right? And there was no way you could hold them accountable. They could be sadists. You had some of them, too. It doesn't sound nice.

They could be thieves. They could rob you blind. They could steal money, and you couldn't do anything about it. Now you can do whatever you want. Now you do what's right.

And you have a Secretary that's doing what's right. He's tough and he's smart. It's true.

And I can tell you -- this is always a good sign, General Mattis was not happy when I took him out of the Department of Defense. You know, we were going to have him for a short while. And then we said, "You know, he's doing so good, we're going to keep him here." He wasn't happy, and that's usually a good sign. Isn't it, Governor? When they're not -- if they're happy, that's not a good sign. He wasn't happy. He's still not happy. But that's all right. But you're happy, right?

In a few months -- and a few months ago, I was very proud to sign into law another tremendous victory for our veterans. Maybe this is the one that we kept talking about and talking about -- 48 years. They couldn't get it approved. It made so much sense. I used to talk about it because I thought I was this great guy that had this great vision. It's called "V.A. Choice."

And I said, "You know, if you have lines where you can't see a doctor for two weeks, three weeks, four weeks, twelve days, eight days, how about one day? No good." I said, "I have an idea. Send them out to a private doctor. We got great doctors, and they'll be taken care of immediately. We'll pay the bill." I thought it was like this great idea.

Well, they thought about it for 40 years. They couldn't get it passed. We got it passed. So we have, now, V.A. Choice. So, now, if a veteran can't get the care they need from the V.A. in a timely fashion, they have the right to go see a private doctor.

Today, for the first time in American history, I am about to sign a bill that will fully and permanently give our great and cherished veterans choice, so you don't have to wait on line for 18 days to take care of a simple -- I mean, we had people waiting on line with a simple problem that, by the time they saw the doctor, they were terminally ill. No more of that. If you have a line, you go see a doctor. You get yourself taken care of. We take care of it.

OK? Good. It was amazing. It was amazing.

You would think that would have been easy to pass. Well, there's a reason it took so many years; it wasn't easy. You have different groups and different people. But in the end, we all came together and we got it done. V.A. Choice.

Here with us today is Vin Putignano, a Vietnam veteran who is a great guy, who lives in Las Vegas. And, now, through the Choice program, he can see the specialist doctors that he needs while still getting his primary care through the V.A. medical centers like this one.

And that's the other thing, there's so many great things that they do that people don't recognize. And you don't have to go out all the time to get what you need, because so much of it is taking place here. We have some tremendously talented people.

I always hear about the incredible level of treatment and talent that the doctors have. You have really incredible doctors and nurses. You had to get to them; that was the problem. But you have some tremendously talented people.

So, Vin, I'd like you, if you would, to say a few words about V.A. Choice, please. Thank you, Vin.

VIN PUTIGNANO, VETERAN: First of all, good morning. Thank you, Mr. President, for those kind words. I wish my mom was here. Because she wouldn't believe you.

Anyway, it's an honor to stand with you --

WEBSTER: As you were watching, this is from a V.A. Medical facility in North Las Vegas, the President just wrapping up talking about signing an appropriations bill and really highlighting the ability for Veterans to have Choice. If they can't get speedy medical care, they can now go to a private doctor. It will be covered by the V.A. He said earlier the President, listen, "You back me on the campaign so I now back you. I made a lot of promises that I would help veterans and especially, the health care." He said, "I'm making good on those promises." And he says, "Look," he also by the way had took time to tout the markets which again are higher today.

He talked about how the economy is booming. And he also talked about V.A. unemployment being at the lowest level in more than 20 years. But the basis for what the President is doing today is helping veterans and the no Choice aspect of health care, a very important one. It's been a big one for a long time.

And the President believes that giving Veterans the ability to not only speed up the process within the Veterans Affairs but also allow veterans to go to private doctors if they can't get their care they need in timely manner. That is very important.

We're hearing the testimony of one particular vet who lives in Vegas with the President standing on there. Of course, we'll go back if the President makes some more comments.

But I still have our guests with us, James and Ned are still with me. Also by the way joining is Fox News Contributor Jehmu Greene.

Jehmu, I'm not going to ask you about Veterans affairs. What I do want to ask you about prior to listening to the President in Vegas, they were talking about the ongoing turmoil surrounding the nomination of U.S. Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh.

Both Ned and James said, "Wait a minute, there's a point here where it's getting ridiculous." I read your notes. You say it's getting ridiculous. But for all the other reasons, you believe that the accuser should be heard and the Republicans are ignoring the allegations being made.

JEHMU GREENE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Absolutely. From the beginning of this nomination there has been a rush to just ram this nomination through. When you look at the hundreds of thousands of documents that Democratic members of the Senate were asking for, that they were denied, but as it relates to this accusation, what is the rush?

And I do find it odd that the 11 Republican men who are on that judiciary committee and unfortunately for the Republicans, they don't have one woman on the judiciary committee? That blows my mind. But for these 11 men, they have not learned anything since we lived through the Anita hill hearings.

And if we could take one step, one step back or even just a pause, take a breath, and understand how hard it is for someone to come forward with allegations like this. How hard it is for someone to basically say, "I'm going to blow up my entire life to tell a story about something that happened to me that was very traumatic." There just does not seem to be much empathy and way too much partisanship when we should be getting to a place of human decency around these allegations.

And to come up with due process, why are they running away from due process? Why are they running away from the FBI investigating this?

WEBSTER: Well every -- so in that, let me bring in Ned.

GREENE: In the same way --

WEBSTER: Let me bring in Ned, let me bring in Ned very quickly because --

GREENE: -- as they did with the Anita Hill accusation.

WEBSTER: But Jehmu, let me just bring in Ned on that point because he says, "Wait a minute, it's the left that has abandoned due process," right?

RYUN: They really have. And Dr. Ford is being given every opportunity to come forward and lay forth her accusations in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee. And, I can't, Ashley, Chuck Grassley has bent over backwards to offer her every opportunity.

GREENE: Absolutely not.

RYUN: And she -- and now we're back -- oh absolutely has. And now we're in this back in forth of a list of demands. I'm sorry, I think the thing that's going to be shameful when this all said and done, if this doesn't turn out to have any veracity, Ashley, then the Democrats would stoop to this level to use this. I think is pernicious because it then removes legitimacy from future allegations.

And we all know, we can all agree. There are men and women who have abused others sexually. This is a serious problem but to use this as a tool to beat somebody over the head for political gain. If this turns out to be just a political gambit, this is disgusting.

WEBSTER: James, I don't think the Republicans can be accused of trying to ram this through?

FREEMAN: No, they followed the process. The -- and by the way these are the duly-elected representatives of the people of this country.

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: The voters chose these senators. They are doing the job. Voters gave them the Constitution gives them. The idea that because they're not a gender that this or that media observer wants but there is somehow not legitimate I think is, is way off target. But the process is what the Constitution gives them. It's their job. It's not the job of the FBI to make a judgment on whether someone is credible. That is the job of the United State Senate and that's what they're doing.

WEBSTER: Last point to you, Jehmu, let me just say this, one point that's being made by Dr. Ford is that she wants Mr. Kavanaugh to go first. But how can he answer those accusations when he doesn't really know what they are in detail? It seems back to front to me.

GREENE: Look, I don't think necessarily think Kavanaugh going first --

WEBSTER: Right.

GREENE: -- to something that her attorneys should stick to. But we have to keep in mind that Republicans, 30 years ago, Orrin Hatch was saying the exact opposite of what he is saying now and what your fellow guests just said. He was calling for the FBI to do an investigation. So what is different now?

FREEMAN: No, what's different is that --

GREENE: What is different is --

FREEMAN: -- it was not a public allegations at that point.

GREENE: -- that they have been trying to ram this through, from the very beginning. And all of the evidence is aligned to that.

WEBSTER: James --

GREENE: And certainly, there's been no bending over backwards. There's been a show up on this one day.

WEBSTER: Absolutely has.

GREENE: A week after this happened. And that's the only opportunity you get.

WEBSTER: Well they gave a deadline, today, Jehmu.

GREENE: That's a one chance.

WEBSTER: And that deadline apparently is come and gone. They are trying to get this thing resolved. Trying to handle it in a timely manner and it's dragging on.

FREEMAN: Yes, I think it also should be pointed out that Clarence Thomas - -

GREENE: That it's a lifetime -- it's a lifetime appointment?

WEBSTER: Yes.

FREEMAN: Clarence Thomas was confirmed --

GREENE: And so yes, this is coming.

FREEMAN: -- with a lifetime appointment because the American people decided. He was unfairly accused. They saw holes in Anita Hill's story. And that put the political pressure, and it's why both parties, members of both parties voted to confirm him.

WEBSTER: We have leave it there, everyone.

GREENE: And --

WEBSTER: We could go for the rest of the day and through the weekend. With James, Ned, Jehmu. Thank you for being here to discuss it. Obviously more to come, thank you very much.

Now this, internal e-mails suggests that some Google employees wanted to alter the search functions to counter President Trump's travel ban. Is this more evidence the Silicon Valley is fighting conservative voices. The intel is coming up on that.

Plus markets in record territory again today, how long can the bull run last? Years, so far. We'll ask the experts, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: The Dow and S&P continuing their run into record territory today as President Trump touts the best U.S. economy ever.

Joining me now Moody's Chief Economist, John Lonski and from Vision 4 Funds Distributors, Heather Zumarraga. Thank you both for being here.

John, let me begin with you, the question is always been how long can this Bull Run go? I've had a number of analysts say recently we're in about the seventh inning, would you agree with that? And I'm not sure that's --

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: I don't know what that means, the seventh inning.

WEBSTER: No.

LONSKI: But as long as --

WEBSTER: Which they would suggest there we're 2/3 of the way through it.

LONSKI: As long as profits grow.

WEBSTER: I guess.

LONSKI: Yes, as long as you have a positive of outlook for profits --

WEBSTER: Yes.

LONSKI: -- equally prices climb higher. And I don't think that this rally is going to be derailed over an extended period of time by higher interest rates. That's very important.

WEBSTER: Right. . LONSKI: I think right now that's still the biggest danger. But I think that danger is going to remain well contained as long as we had inflation expectations stuck forever at two percent.

WEBSTER: But I don't know if that's possible. But, you know, Heather what do you say? We in the seventh inning we still juts in the fourth inning, I don't know if you like this baseball analogies but what do you think?

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, VISION 4 FUNDS DISTRIBUTOR VP: Sure well, we'll be in the first inning if we get some of this trade disputes resolved between NAFTA, and China, and the U.S. as well. And seems like the markets are getting used to trade tensions also and the Federal Reserve has set to hike rates next week. Despite all of this the markets are still setting new records.

WEBSTER: Yes.

ZUMARRAGA: President Trump is saying that the U.S. economy is booming. So perhaps if we get some of the trade disputes resolved, maybe we're in the first inning.

WEBSTER: Well that wouldn't that be something?

ZUMARRAGA: Yes.

WEBSTER: John, what about that? The trade tensions are really been shrugged off by these markets. If in fact we do get deals with, you know, with Mexico, Canada, the biggie China if we can get that all done, are we open up a leg or two?

LONSKI: Yes, the market could care less about the schedule implementation of tariffs with China. They start next week --

WEBSTER: Right.

LONSKI: -- $200 million of goods --

WEBSTER: But then --

LONSKI: -- a 10 percent tariff, does someone who cares, you know? I mean, companies --

ZUMARRAGA: But that's a lot.

WEBSTER: Yes, it is a lot.

LONSKI: Companies -- yes, their profit margins is a lot to suck it in a little bit or they're going to find all --

WEBSTER: But, we, the consumers end up in with --

LONSKI: I think it well. I -- can the consumer afford to pay much more?

WEBSTER: That makes sense.

LONSKI: So you know, we had problems are now with auto sales and with home sales because both autos and housing tend to be overpriced at least from the viewpoint of the consumer.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LONSKI: When the Fed talks about well contained inflation expectations what the Fed is telling you is the consumer is not an idiot. If companies try to rise -- raise prices by much more than two percent or three percent --

WEBSTER: Right.

LONSKI: -- what does the consumer do? They just don't buy.

WEBSTER: You know that's great, and that's a great point.

LONSKI: Disciplining.

WEBSTER: Yes, go ahead Heather.

ZUMARRAGA: Look at Walmart.

WEBSTER: Yes.

ZUMARRAGA: Walmart customers may endure higher prices. Assume Walmart CEO saying that they may have to hike prices on goods from food and beverage down to bicycles and consumer electronics. So across the board but the flip side of that, is Goldman Sachs actually said that the impact of tariffs on rising prices that the threat of inflation just from tariffs alone was only 0.3 of one percent expected. So you know it's a tug-of-war.

You have Walmart saying prices are going to go up. You have Goldman Sachs saying yes they are going to go up but not that much. So will it really have a big impact on consumers in spending this holiday season?

WEBSTER: And getting back to the markets, John, what could really knock this off? For one point they were saying whether the Fed gets over enthusiastic and starts raising rates too quickly? That doesn't seem to be the case? I mean what conceivably, is it just over when it's over?

LONSKI: I think it's the only thing that would knock this market down is suddenly when we find out that we grossly overestimated earnings growth. And that in fact, we begin to become nervous about a possible contraction of earnings. I don't see that happening anytime soon. Ultimately it's the growth of profits that determine the return from equities.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LONSKI: And profits are expected to grow, not only this year not only next year, but into, what, 2020. According to the consensus, they have operating income, S&P 500 up by 10 percent in 2020.

But one warning, there are growing number of economists that talk about a possible recession but you can't have a recession without a shrinkage of profit.

WEBSTER: You're right. You know what, Heather, and Charles Payne said this earlier today. He said this is the most hated bull run in history. No one likes it. It's been going on since 2009.

He says he loves that. And, you know, which speaks to maybe there's still a lot of money on the sideline that could come in.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes, markets climb a wall of worry. So the fact that there is -- are still people on the sidelines waiting for this pullback that just never happens is the reason why markets keep going higher.

I think people are on the sidelines saying, oh we're missing out despite trade tensions and rising interest rates. And that's why we keep heading higher along with strong U.S. growth. And around emerging markets doing very well this week also because the dollar is weakening so that's helping them.

WEBSTER: All right, so that could be the seventh inning. It could the first inning. It doesn't matter we're still in the game as they say.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes.

WEBSTER: Heather and John, we're already out of time, but thank you so much. I appreciate your time today.

ZUMARRAGA: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Let's take a look at shares of Google if we can. There's a story out there about Google today, not particularly flattering. The stock off one percent down and a more than 12 bucks of 1,179, that's alphabetical as the parent company of Google.

A report today shows that some Google employees proposed altering search functions to counter President Trump's travel ban back when that happened. It didn't actually happen. That didn't the -- it wasn't put in place but is it more evidence that big tech is biased against conservatives. That's the question. We're on it next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Internal e-mails from Google show some employees wanted to alter the search results to counter President Trump's travel ban. Now, according to a "Wall Street Journal" report those suggestions never put in place, but it does prompt questions across about political manipulation and stifling of conservative ideas.

Hillary Vaughn has been following this story from Los Angeles.

And Hillary, what more is Google saying about this report?

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, hello, Ashley.

They're saying that they aren't taking any action against any of the employees that were involved in this explosive e-mail chain that shows employees of Google were plotting ways to fight back against the President's travel ban when it was announced by trying to control what users would see when they Google about the topic, in the e-mail chain, first obtained by Fox News', Tucker Carlson tonight, Search Product Market Manager Mackenzie Thomas lays out ideas and suggest terms that they should change, saying they should, "Actively counter prejudiced terms like the words Mexico, Hispanic, and Latino and actively counter Islamophobic terms like Islam, Muslim and Iran."

Thomas writing to a group of Google employees saying, "I know this would require a full on sprint to make happen, but I think this is the sort of super timely and imperative information that we need as we know that this country and Google, would not exist without immigration."

Now Google is framing the e-mail chain as just a brainstorm session among junior level employees. But Google's, Meryl Stone, now the head Consumer Partnership at Google was on that chain.

Also Google's Global Public Policy Manager, Clement wolf, chimed in on the chain asking how partisan should Google be on this issue? Writing, "To the extent of my knowledge we've been breaching precedent if we only gave highlights access to organizations that support a certain view of the world in a time of political conflict. Is that accurate? If so we would be willing to open access to highlights to NGOs that actually support the ban?"

Google gives me the statement in response saying that, "These e-mails were just a brainstorm of ideas, none of which were ever implemented. Our processes and policies would not have allowed for any manipulation of search results to promote political ideologies."

And Ashley, they're telling me that they're taking no action against any of these employees. And no internal memo went out to the company, explaining that this is against company policy.

Ashley.

WEBSTER: Very interesting, Hillary Vaughn, good stuff. Thank you, Hillary, appreciate it.

Well, it certainly doesn't speak well does it to accusations of big tech is biased against conservatives. Here with more reaction, Scott Martin CIO of Kingsview Asset Management.

You know, Scott, OK, so we hear back from just a brainstorming, you know, session never went into effect. But it's certainly leaves the very bitter taste when you start thinking about the way that these e-mails were and worded was -- it's almost like it's us against them.

We've got to make sure, we've got to rush to get this in so that we can combat the policies of the Trump administration. To me it is very damning.

SCOTT MARTN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT CIO: Yes. It's damning and damn them. Ashley, you know, thank you Google for doing this great service for the country, and trying to tell us how to think, right?

I mean what's interesting too though, you know, they're not really good I guess at burying searches, because if you Google internal e-mails, if you Google search that, you find a litany of stories now about how they tried to hide this stuff. So, hey Google take a clue and maybe bury while you're right (ph).

Here's the thing though, Ashley, like you and Hillary talked about, there was very little leadership in this department, right. I mean yes, I get it some underlings, some lower level employee's maybe spouting off and blowing off about Trump and the policies and what not fine. But the fact that you would have management on here kind of saying, "Well, should we break protocol and not doing this or do this?" Just goes to show you they really didn't care and maybe actually even thought about doing it.

WEBSTER: Well, and then of course, this comes on the heels, and I don't know Scott if you seen the video of Google executives seen that in that period of time just after Donald Trump became President, and the role sitting around having this kind of session talking, and it is like a wake, it's like a funeral and what can we do, and you know the country has gone to rack an ruin and democracy has been thrown out of the window. You see that video, and then you hear about what was going on with regard to this particular search. I mean, it's hard not to think that there's some not bias against conservative thought.

MARTIN: Yes, it's upsetting. In Democracy being thrown out the window, when America voted and got --

WEBSTER: Right.

MARTIN: -- the result that they voted for, right? I mean, yes, democracy must be out the window in that case.

And you know, honestly, Ashley, as Google shareholder, it's disappointing both for myself and my clients. Facebook is another one. You know the news feed jiggering that they've done over the years.

WEBSTER: Yes.

MARTIN: I mean, that stuff, you know, obviously was kind of tailored to certain ways. Twitter, Jack Dorsey has talked about how this was not a great, you know place for conservative thought.

WEBSTER: Right.

MARTIN: We own Facebook, by the way, still. I mean, gosh, Ashley, you know Silicon Valley has really shown their stripes here in the last couple of years.

WEBSTER: Right.

MARTIN: And it's not promising with respect to how they feel about D.C., that's for sure.

WEBSTER: No, it certainly doesn't.

All right, as always, Scott, great stuff, you can talk about any subject with a lot of skill, much appreciated. Scott Martin.

MARTIN: I'll try. See you, man.

WEBSTER: In Chicago, Scott, thank you and we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Breaking today, the White House says it is very hopeful that trade deal deal with Canada could be reach by the end of the month.

For the very latest lets go to our very own Blake Burman, at the White House trying to keeping track of all this.

Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Ashley. We've got debrief from a White House official as it relates to pretty much the two main trade discussions going on right now with the United States, as they're trying to rework trade deals, Canada and China. The United States, The Trump administration at this point, much more optimistic with the way forward on Canada than as it relates to China.

Canada, a deal has to, when you weave through all the legal wrangling of this, essentially be worked out by the end of the month. And this White House official who gave us the debrief said, they are optimistic that something will get done.

The main sticking point, though, here is dairy. And here is what this White House official told us, "It really is on Canada to decide speaking about a deal. We got a great deal and I think they should be very happy with a lot of the things with the deal with Mexico and they've got to decide, are they going to kill this deal with them because of their dairy program?"

As you know, President Trump has long complained about the tariff situation with Canada, and dairy. That is the main sticking point going forward with Canada. But the administration feels that something could potentially be worked out with Canada by the end of the month.

As it relates to China though there is a much more long-term view that the administration is taking with the Chinese as there are no official scheduled talks right now, between the United States and China. Though this White House official tells us there is communication, constantly between the two.

Here's what this White House official, though, told us, "I don't know when China will finally commit to make the changes it needs to make. Obviously the I.P.," meaning I.P. theft, "is a big one."

"We're also talking to them about agricultural things. And we're talking to them about real structural changes and I hope it will be soon. I hope it's soon, but these agreements take time."

As for phase three of potential tariffs with China, Ashley, the $267 billion that President Trump has threatened against China, this White House official not assigning a certain date as to when that could potentially come. And I asked that White House official is there anything down the pipeline as it relates to after the 267 billion potentially? This White House official says they do not want to go there just yet.

WEBSTER: No.

BURMAN: Ashley.

WEBSTER: I'm just talking about phase three is a bit kind of disappointing as well. But Blake Burman at the White House, Blake, thank you very much.

BURMAN: Thanks.

WEBSTER: Appreciate that.

Let's take a look at markets for you, on the upside on the Dow again up 66 points, the S&P also just on the up side, the NASDAQ slightly lower. Have more on the markets when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: The takeover battle for British broadcaster Sky will be decided this weekend. British regulators say Comcast and 21st Century Fox, our parent company, will settle their takeover battle for Sky through an auction starting today.

And our Susan Li is here, she's been following this story. Isn't this an unusual way to kind of close out this deal?

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: It's rare.

WEBSTER: Rare.

LI: Rare. Yes. It's only happened three times since 2007 in the U.K. that they've used this auction process --

WEBSTER: Right.

LI: -- to settle any assets. This is the biggest prize ever in the auction process.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: Thirty-five billion dollars and today was the deadline. So here the latest new is, today was the deadline for either Comcast or Fox to withdraw any of their cash bids. No one was going --

WEBSTER: No one has done that. No.

LI: So, Saturday is this going to be three rounds, first round, Fox bids. Second round, Comcast counter-bids.

WEBSTER: It's the way to --

LI: Then third round -- wait, wait, this is important because then you have --

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: -- a seals envelope high drama bid and this is where game theory comes in, right? Because you don't know what the other side is bidding so you don't want to bid too much but you don't want to bid too low, where you don't win the actual auction.

WEBSTER: And then at the end you open the envelop and the Oscar goes to?

LI: Right. And that will be announced on Saturday evening by U.K. regulators and then shareholders of Sky have three weeks to decide who they want to choose. Obviously the higher bid will most likely get the better choice.

WEBSTER: And to confuse all of this so just a little bit more, Disney is buying a large number of assets of 21st Century Fox. So, do they inherently then go on and assume Sky?

LI: OK. So this is what happens --

WEBSTER: If Fox wins the bid.

LI: Its -- yes. So, it's very complicated because of that whole who owns who stays (ph) for who.

WEBSTER: Yes. Right. Right. Right.

LI: As we know, Disney of course winning the bid for Fox assets --

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: -- Fox owns 39 percent of Sky. And then, so, lets say, you know, Comcast wins the bid --

WEBSTER: Right.

LI: --Disney still kind of wins because --

WEBSTER: They have to --

LI: -- they own 39 percent. And if that goes up to a high premium there, you know, if they decide to offload some of those Sky assets which no one says that they will at this point, they actually also get a higher pricing for the assets they already own. Does that make sense?

WEBSTER: It makes sense to me, it's a bit in the weeds, but this is a complicated process. So, where's the highest bid stand right now? Is it Comcast, of what?

LI: Comcast at nine --

WEBSTER: Thirty-five percent?

LI: So, I converted to U.S. dollars for --

WEBSTER: OK.

LI: -- our U.S. audience.

WEBSTER: Very good.

LI: It's at $19, its 14 pounds 75 cents --

WEBSTER: OK.

LI: -- something in that category. That's higher than the $18 and change the Fox has bid, but slightly higher. But we should point out where actual Sky is trading that $21.

So, what that tells you is that the market is anticipating obviously a very competitive bidding process and that price could go much, much higher. But it depends at the end of the day what you think Sky is worth. And from the actions that we've seen, you know, Fox has made several attempts to buy Sky. And the rest of Sky doesn't (INAUDIBLE) own.

WEBSTER: Is it that prized an asset?

LI: It is.

WEBSTER: Consider the price --

LI: Twenty-three million subscribers, right?

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: We talk about this in the UK.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: I mean sports, is probably the crown jewel at --

WEBSTER: From Italy.

LI: -- Sky broadcasting.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: Yet they also have a news division as well.

WEBSTER: Yes.

LI: This is an opportunity for both Disney and Comcast to increase their international footprint which is something they want to do, especially Comcast, which has such a domestic focused business, right?

WEBSTER: So, by Saturday night we should know.

LI: We should know what the bids are.

WEBSTER: What the bids are.

LI: And then the Sky shareholders vote.

WEBSTER: Good job. Complicated story but you made it clear.

LI: Thank you.

WEBSTER: Susan Li thank you so much.

As we head towards the end of this hour we can say the Dow up another 60 points. What a week it's been for the markets, money continuing to come into Wall Street, the Dow at 26,717. Not bad. Can we hang on for the next hour to finish in the green?

And I don't think it's any surprise the Cleveland Browns win their first game in what nearly 639 days. They've gone 19 games out a win. They win and guess what?

Liz Claman isn't in today. Maybe celebrating a bit too much last night, Lauren Simonetti?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Dilly-dilly.

WEBSTER: Dilly-dilly, yes.

SIMONETTI: Ashley Webster. Have a good weekend sir.

WEBSTER: You too.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6012-6MD1-DY0W-43HJ-00000-00Trump’s Plan: Break the Internet to Suppress the Vote;Trump will never leave Twitter. He loves it too much. Now he’s trying to browbeat it into helping him win re-election.2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisTrump’s Plan: Break the Internet to Suppress the VoteTrump will never leave Twitter. He loves it too much. Now he’s trying to browbeat it into helping him win re-election.Spencer AckermanAsawin SuebsaengNew YorkFULL TEXT

The internet, and Twitter in particular, is central to President Donald Trump’s power. His tweets move everything from Pentagon policy on Syria and transgender service to how Republican lawmakers vote on surveillance law. Their frequent falsity is beside the point. It’s the influence that matters.

Now Trump is trying to push a lasting structural change upon the internet, one that internet-freedom advocates fear will entrench a disincentive for any social media company to block disinformation on their platform. And it comes after Twitter, an open sewer for disinformation, took a very meager step to stop Trump from suppressing the vote in November.

In signing an executive order on Thursday, Trump called for “new regulations” with respect to the provision of the 1996 Communications Decency Act permitting internet companies to remove or restrict content they host “that the provider or user considers to be obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, excessively violent, harassing, or otherwise objectionable.” The provision, Section 230, establishes that social-media and other internet content hosts are platforms, not publishers, and therefore not legally liable for what users say, do, or experience online.

Trump’s proposal declared that “a provider should properly lose the limited liability shield” of Section 230 if it’s found to “silence viewpoints that they dislike.” As a means for determining that, it called for “all executive departments and agencies” to review how they were applying the provision and for a rule-making petition to be filed to the Federal Communications Commission within 60 days. Trump’s order also instructed loyalist Attorney General Bill Barr to propose legislation “useful to promote the policy objectives of this order” and advised heads of various government agencies to review the advertising dollars that they were spending on social media platforms.

Collectively, the order suggests social media companies may face penalties—real or potential—for attempting to police misinformation on their platforms. Either, according to longtime observers, is likely to be enough to prompt those companies to revert to their resting state: opening the sluice-gate of misinformation.

For the president’s critics, it all amounts to a jarring sequence: To stay in power, Trump has taken a step toward erasing the already blurred line between what is and isn’t true online.

“Donald Trump is so committed to preventing Americans from voting that he spent weeks lying about vote by mail, and now he is trying to twist Section 230 and the First Amendment to force Twitter to spread these lies,” said Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR), the provision’s co-author.

For years, President Trump has viewed his relationship with social-media giants—particularly Twitter, his favorite online medium—as both adversarial and mutually beneficial. Much in the same way that the president has routinely assailed the credibility and perceived disloyalty of Fox News, but won’t actually ditch the network, he takes a similar attitude toward a major online platform like Twitter, according to two people close to him. He often will complain. But he is extremely unlikely to take the ultimate step and personally abandon his own Twitter account.

Trump sees Twitter as one of his best communications assets. Though he insisted on Thursday that there was “nothing” more he “rather do than get rid of my whole Twitter account,” he claimed he simply could not do so because it was his medium for going around the press corps. He credits the platform, in part, for how he was able to dominate the national conversation during his successful 2016 presidential run. He “does not want to give up something he thinks helps him win,” one of those sources said. That commitment hasn’t stopped him from threatening the company to score political points or because he feels personally aggrieved.

Indeed, Thursday’s executive order has been conceptually in the works for many months. According to two individuals familiar with the process, the Trump White House convened multiple meetings in the summer of 2019, inviting officials from the Justice Department, the FCC, the FTC, and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration to the White House to discuss crafting an executive order that similarly would have targeted social media giants’ legal liability.

Those efforts were largely managed by White House domestic-policy aide James Sherk, a former labor economics analyst at the Heritage Foundation, who had the unenviable task of organizing a protracted drafting process demanded by an irked Trump. The intra-administration sessions caused predictable headaches, with officials unsure of how to reconcile the legal technicalities of the directive with Trump’s demands and fits.

“We didn’t know if this was busy-work to satisfy one of the president’s mood swings, or if we were actually getting something done,” said one former senior Trump administration official.

In one of the early meetings that summer, the White House proposed language to agency officials that read as if the president was, for instance, ordering the FCC to redefine the liability shield of Section 230, the sources recounted. White House officials had to be reminded by agency envoys that Trump wasn’t allowed to do that (though he can ask the NTIA to petition the FCC to conduct an independent review on the matter), and that such language would be quickly, and likely successfully, challenged. Still, many of the agency officials played along, for fear of upsetting the White House.

“Nobody in the room wanted to kill this,” one of the sources familiar with the discussions said. “[But] very few, if any, wanted anything to do with it.”

Thursday’s action is a culmination of that pent up frustration along with years’ worth of right-wing objections that social media “shadowbans” right-wing content. That objection was dismissed by a federal appeals court on Wednesday, which found that conservatives suing Twitter and Facebook could not demonstrate that account deactivation for terms-of-service violations amounted to political suppression.

But the specific issue prompting Trump to act was not any generic grievance. It was his false assertion that voting by mail—an expansion of which is under consideration because of the novel coronavirus that has killed 100,000 Americans in three months—will lead to systematic voter fraud.

Twitter told CNN that the president’s tweets promoted “potentially misleading information about voting processes.” And, indeed, there’s no evidence of meaningful voter-fraud related to mail-in balloting. In fact, five states, including Republican-run Utah, already vote entirely by mail.

“To be absolutely clear, absentee and mail voting in America is secure and election officials are confident in the security measures they have in place. It is critical this year that election officials ensure every American citizen has the option to vote absentee if they want to, and have safe polling place options,” said Wendy Weiser, the vice president for democracy at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University. “This is critical for public health and critical for the health of our democracy. The president’s actions are making it harder for public officials to take the steps that they need to ensure a safe, secure, and healthy election this November.”

Twitter’s solution, however, was not to take down the erroneous tweets or ban Trump’s account for a terms-of-service violation. Rather, it appended a hypertext alert below the tweet urging users to “get the facts about mail-in ballots.”

To Trump, this was “Big Tech... doing everything in their very considerable power to CENSOR in advance of the 2020 election,” as he (naturally) tweeted Wednesday night. And he insisted that rectifying it by executive order would be tantamount to “a Big Day for Social Media and FAIRNESS!”

It’s a familiar distortion for those who dealt with the aftermath of Russia’s disinformation campaign on social media during the 2016 election. One of them, Sen. Mark Warner (D-Va.) pushed for internet companies to provide greater transparency around political ads on their platforms. Warner’s measure sought to bolster the integrity of hosted content while sidestepping suggestions that the companies ought to determine what on their platforms is and isn’t true. He expressed alarm at the “baseless” claim Trump made about censorship and its implications for voter suppression.

“While many of us have raised concerns for several years now about the opaque and inconsistent content moderation practices of large platforms and the ways that Section 230 has been unjustly invoked to protect platforms that facilitate fraud, widespread consumer harms, and civil rights violations, it’s strange to see the president mimic some of those legitimate concerns in support of a baseless claim that he and fellow conservatives are being disadvantaged or censored online,” Warner told The Daily Beast in advance of the executive order’s release.

“The president has openly boasted about his prominence on social media, even while routinely violating the policies of each platform,” Warner continued. “This latest effort to cow platforms into allowing Trump, dark money groups, and right-wing militias to exploit their tools to sow disinformation, engage in targeted harassment, and suppress voter participation is a sad distraction from the legitimate efforts to establish common sense regulations for dominant social media platforms.”

The irony is that Twitter’s tentative step toward confronting deceit on its platform is a departure from social-media firms’ economic logic, in which what matters is the mass collection and commodification of user data, not hosting truthful discourse. That logic explains why Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg criticized Twitter for playing the “arbiter of truth.” That position was also captured in a recently leaked memo from Facebook executive Andy Bosworth that compared ensuring veracity on Facebook to the temptations of JRR Tolkein’s One Ring, a dark power that corrupts the ringbearer.

"That 'dark power' notion is a rationalization meant to deflect attention from the economic imperatives central to the tech firms’ business model," said Shoshana Zuboff, author of The Age of Surveillance Capitalism and a professor emerita at Harvard Business School.

“Their algorithms are tuned to maximize behavioral data intake into their supply chains for computation into behavioral predictions. They are compelled to extract data at scale and scope… that means volumes of as many kinds of data as possible. In this economic logic, there is no room for judging data content. The corporations are radically indifferent to whether data are true or false—it’s all the same to their revenue flows.” Zuboff explained.

Section 230 was written before that economic logic took hold, when the model of the internet was a bulletin board rather than the “bloodstream” of contemporary life, Zuboff continued. And however content-agnostic social media companies portray their algorithms to be, those algorithms do push content on to users, as NBC’s Ben Collins has documented with the spread on Facebook of the QAnon conspiracy theory.

“Mr. Trump wants to confront the power of these companies and how they operate, but instead of fighting for truth, he’s fighting for the right to lie, to inject poison into the body politic,” Zuboff said. “The tech companies and the government are in a larger existential battle right now, like two Death Stars battling each other. Both want to operate outside the rule of law and democratic norms.”

urn:contentItem:5W58-8C21-DXH2-61V1-00000-00Trump's Reckless Talk About "Treason"; More Than Two Months Since Last White House Press Briefing. Aired 11a-12p ET2019-05-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisCNN RELIABLE SOURCES11:00 AM ESTJane Coaston, Susanne Craig, Catherine HadroNEWSDomestic050901CN.V50Trump's Reckless Talk About "Treason"; More Than Two Months Since Last White House Press Briefing. Aired 11a-12p ETBrian Stelter, Oliver Darcy, Irin Carmon, Joe Lockhart

The president is continuing to accuse members of the intelligence committee of treason, an idea that only makes sense if you subscribe to the Sean Hannity cinematic universe. The White House briefing room still isn't getting any use, an unprecedented drought, 69 days, more than two months since Sarah Sanders last held an official press briefing.

[11:00:14] BRIAN STELTER, CNN ANCHOR: Hey, I'm Brian Stelter. It's time for RELIABLE SOURCES. This is our weekly look at the story behind the story, of how the media really works, how the news gets made and how all of us can help make it better.

In this hour, we have breaking news from Alabama, where the state's biggest newspapers making a pretty bold statement about the state's new extreme anti-abortion bill.

Later, we're going to get into the truth about President Trump's wealth and how business beat reporters are leading the way.

Plus, we are keeping track of the administration's briefing room silence, 69 days. Why is it Gene Simmons is the only one standing at the Pentagon podium? Joe Lockhart is here to talk about.

But, first, the new abnormal, and that's involving the T word, treason. The president is continuing to accuse members of the intelligence committee of treason, an idea that only makes sense if you subscribe to the Sean Hannity cinematic universe.

On Friday, Trump tweeted out this conclusive claim that his campaign was spied on, and he said this was treason. He apparently liked the idea so much that he retweeted it, retweeting himself on Saturday.

So, why am I bringing it up now? The news media sighed, shrugged and moved on. It turns out, even cries of treason are not enough to spark breaking news coverage any more. Now, that may be a good thing, or that may be a bad thing. What do you think?

Even on Fox, Laura Ingraham barely took this idea seriously.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Treason means long jail sentences and this was treason.

Harmie (ph), we're almost out of time, but treason? Yes or no?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Well, it could be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STELTER: It could be. Yes or no -0 a yes or no answer for something as serious as this?

Now, I checked out the broadcast networks too, the only coverage of this treason tweet, the only show I could find that mentioned it at all on Friday was a comedy show.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIMMY KIMMEL, COMEDIAN: He loves to say that there's a plot to prevent him from becoming president. Who would have bothered plotting that? Nobody thought he had a chance. It'd be like plotting to make sure Papa John's didn't take home the world's best pizza cup, which not something that was on anyone's mind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STELTER: Hey, for the record, I like Papa John's pizza.

But let's get back to the point. What is the president's rhetoric doing, how is the news media reacting and what is Bill Barr's role in all this? Why does he sound so much like Sean Hannity?

Joining me now to discuss, "New York Magazine's" Irin Carmon, also a CNN contributor, CNN media guru Oliver Darcy, and "Vox" senior political reporter, Jane Coaston.

Thanks, everybody for being here.

Jane, first to you. Is the press right to shrug off the president's extreme wild claims on Twitter these days?

JANE COASTON, SENIOR POLITICS REPORTER, VOX: I think so, because I think that we've seen time and time again that there's a distinct difference between Trump's Twitter feed and the Trump administration, one of those has the power of law behind it. We've seen in court proceedings in which the Trump administration has basically implied that Trump's tweets don't matter, because he doesn't know anything and is just tweeting.

And so, it's a fascinating move from -- I remember 2016, 2017 where we saw real economic turmoil result from Trump tweeting about a business. But now, it's where Trump airs his grievances, it's like Festivus all the time.

STELTER: As if none of it should matter.

COASTON: Right.

STELTER: There's a lot of rhetoric coming from Attorney Bill Barr that is similar to the presidents, also really similar to Sean Hannity.

We saw Barr give two interviews this week, Oliver. One was to Murdoch-owned "The Wall Street Journal", another was to the Murdoch- owned Fox News.

Let's take a look at how similar Bill Barr's language was with one of the biggest stars on Fox.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS HOST: After a near three-year witch hunt, or near three-year witch hunt, was conducted into all things Trump.

WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL: But I think if I had been falsely accused, I'd be comfortable in saying it was a witch hunt.

HANNITY: We have been uncovering what is the biggest abuse of power scandal in American history.

BARR: We should be worried about whether government officials abuse their power.

HANNITY: Democrats now fear of the attorney general. The attorney general will expose their hoax.

BARR: They may be concerned about the outcome of a review of what happened during the election.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STELTER: So there we go, Barr/Hannity, Hannity/Barr.

Oliver, is Sean Hannity essentially the attorney general?

OLIVER DARCY, CNN SENIOR MEDIA REPORTER: Well, if you didn't know any better, Brian, you're watching Fox News, you might almost think that watching the interview that Bill Barr is one of the talking heads on Fox News, defending the president, casting everything as a deep state coup and delegitimizing a lot of the work that the DOJ has done. It's stunning.

It shouldn't be forgotten that this came on Fox News. Bill Barr gave this interview to Fox. He gave the other print interview to "The Wall Street Journal", both Rupert Murdoch-owned entities.

So, I think it's clear what he's trying to do. He's trying to send a message to one person who happens to read "The Wall Street Journal" and happens to watch Fox News quite a bit, and he's using the same rhetoric that Trump uses.

[11:05:09] So, you know, it's stunning. And I think one point to make too, is outside the opinion personalities there, there, some of the people on Fox found it stunning. Chris Wallace basically came on and said that it looked like he was, as the attorney general, trying to defend the president.

STELTER: To protect the president.

DARCY: Yes.

STELTER: And, Irin, I bring all this up because this is a cinematic universe. Either you subscribe to this conspiratorial view of the world or you don't. And most Americans don't, but the ones who do, they are deeply committed to these theories, that there was an attempt to take down President Trump.

IRIN CARMON, CNN CONTRIBUTOR: I have to say, Brian, I'm of the opinion that we should be freaking out when we see the word "treason". I'm of the opinion that if we were to take this administration at its word, we should all be running around like chickens with their heads cut off.

And I actually think -- I mean, Jane, I hear you. There is a disconnect between the Twitter handle and what happens in the administration. But as we know also from the Mueller report, that's also because a lot of the president's administration hasn't been listening to him, right, actually just treats him like some kind of nutty figure at times even though he guides all kinds of things like immigration policy.

But precisely because of the dynamic you're talking about, about Barr not being a challenge to Trump, I think we should take it very seriously. We have the president of the United States tweeting about a treason, while having an attorney general who sees himself as the wing man to the president. And I think that adds up to something deeply disturbing and I know we're all tired and the press can't treat everything like a crisis. But it is a crisis, and we often say that words matter, well, the words that the president of the United States is using matter.

STELTER: Well, let's use the example of something that's started on Twitter and has moved on into the administration action. The headline from "The New York Times" here saying, Trump wants your tales of social media censorship. Another headline from "Vox" saying the White House is doing this to try to get your email address.

What happens this week is the White House came out with this announcement they want to hear if you feel you've been censored on social media.

Oliver, what is this really about?

DARCY: I think this is about a broader cultural war. They know that Americans and the middle of the country, they think they're under attack by elitist institutions. Part of that is the media, the mainstream media, and now they're using big tech companies it seems like, big tech companies like Facebook, like Google, like Twitter. They said these guys are out to get, they're out to censor your ideas, you're under attack, and they're using that, effectively, fearmongering, and now, apparently trying to build up some sort of database, to send updates, and whatnot.

STELTER: Yes, I think 2016 was partly about Trump's attack on the media, this media, 2020, Irin, is about on social media, and an attack big tech.

CARMON: I mean, why choose? Why choose, right? I mean, in both instances, it's Trump working the reps, right? It's making media companies defensive when they're told that they have bias against conservatives. And if we're talking about censorship, to me, that's the concerning thing. The only entity that can infringe on the first amendment is the government.

You have the arm of the federal government, I think we should take this seriously too, pressuring private companies that have a right to moderate their forums, under the law, pressuring them in order to stoke the grievance of your voters, and using the government for that, I do think does infringe on people's First Amendment rights.

STELTER: And, Jane, you cover social media all the time. This is your focus at "Vox". How effective did you think these calls about censorship are?

COASTON: Well, I think they've proven to be very effective, I like to point out, there's a difference between conservatism and the GOP because conservatives are -- you're now hearing some conservatives and a lot of Republicans, making their argument, maybe it's time to regulate Facebook and Twitter. And I like to note, as Irin pointed out, because of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, Facebook and Twitter can kick off whomever they want and moderate your content. That is fine, because, you know, that is in the law, they have those protections.

But now you're seeing folks on the conservative side who generally opposed regulation in a kind of large sweeping way, saying, no, no, no, these companies are too big. It's surprising when you hear conservatives start sounding like Teddy Roosevelt talking about Standard Oil.

STELTER: At the same time, there is real legitimate reason to wonder about these tech companies, and how they enact their standards.

COASTON: That's true.

STELTER: It's not just limited; it's not unique to conservatives or liberals. It affects everybody.

COASTON: Right, exactly, and you're seeing that time and time again, who should get to decide what gets kicked off and what doesn't? Whose content gets monitored?

There have been some instances -- some great reporting in "The Guardian" talking about how African-American activists have their work censored. But then those activists had the FBI show up at their home, which goes far farther than some people getting their tweets deleted or shadow ban.

But it's also reflective of how important these tech companies become in every day life, because you hear from people saying like, why don't you get on Gab or use another social media platform? The response is, no, this is how I reach my family, this is how I want to do this.

[11:10:00] It just feels as if I'm being censored.

Again, not really clarifying what they mean by censored.

STELTER: By censored. COASTON: Because sometimes as people saying, I think this should have gotten more reach than it actually did, which is, you know, that's generally not what censorship is.

STELTER: Yes, whether the algorithm like more.

COASTON: Yes, exactly.

STELTER: In the middle, I have --

CARMON: It would make me have to have fans.

COASTON: Precisely, like no, no, my Instagram fans can't reach me.

DARCY: It's actually an incentive now almost to say that you were suspended or banned, because then you get a whole bunch of Fox News appearances, and your engagement actually shoots up. That's what happened with Diamond and Silk, remember?

STELTER: I see. That's very interesting.

DARCY: One point too is that these are very serious issues like you bring up. The problem is that they're being exploited by bad faith actors to suit their own political agenda. And I think that's what we're seeing, is it would be great if Congress, when it had people in front of the committees, they ask serious questions. Instead they bring Diamond and Silk to come on and mislead the committee and they're citing outlets like the Gateway Pundits, right wing blogs, to make these claims that will fall apart when you actually look at them. That's the problem.

COASTON: Exactly. And you have someone like Senator Ted Cruz who should know better, saying that Section 230 requires platforms to be neutral. It doesn't. Look at the law. There's no requirement that Facebook or Twitter or any means that uses third party information which could be the comments on the Infowars' article. There's no requirement that these platforms be neutral, it's just not in the law.

DARCY: Infowars says, unless it used to say in their own terms of services, that if you do not abide by the rules, we will kick you off and civilization has rules, expect to follow them or face the consequences. This is --

COASTON: Exactly. Precisely, exactly.

STELTER: Let me ask you, quickly, Oliver, about one other story, and that is the headline that you and I published this week on CNN.com about Elizabeth Warren rejecting Fox News, saying she's not going to show up for a town hall, she'd been invited, but she's kind of the only one right now, right? Just her and Kamala Harris have said they are not interested in appearing on Fox.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6019-TB71-DY0W-43FX-00000-00Trump's reported Big Tech executive order would create more problems than it would solve2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisOPINIONTrump's reported Big Tech executive order would create more problems than it would solveKaylee McGheeWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

After his latest spat with Twitter, President Trump has decided that enough is enough: He wants to sign an executive order rolling back Big Tech’s legal immunity.

The executive order, which Trump has suggested he’ll sign on Thursday, would deal largely with a portion of the law known as Section 230, a provision that protects tech companies from being held liable for the content posted on their platforms. Trump’s order would allow federal officials to reconsider Section 230 and its protections, and require the Federal Trade Commission to investigate complaints about political bias on Big Tech platforms.

The merits of Section 230 are certainly worth debate. Companies such as Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube have been allowed to operate under free speech protections while policing their own platforms for speech they deem harmful. So it’s fair to argue that Big Tech wants to have its cake and eat it too.

But Trump’s proposal would make things worse. Giving a government agency power over Big Tech would essentially allow the government to treat Facebook and Twitter like public utilities, which gives the government the right to pre-approve moderation policies, etc. Elizabeth Warren proposed a similar policy during her presidential campaign, and there’s a reason most conservatives spoke out against it. Because no matter the motivation, giving a federal agency the power to regulate Big Tech and the internet would stifle efficiency and creativity, both of which make the internet vital, and it would ultimately result in corruption and inflexibility, as do most bureaucratic regulations.

Trump’s proposed order would also set a dangerous precedent. Regulating Big Tech might give conservatives the advantage right now, but it would come back to bite them later on — because as soon as Trump signs that order, he is giving future presidents, Democratic or Republican, the ability to regulate these platforms as they see fit. And it’s only a matter of time before a Democratic president decides that Big Tech is showing too much favor to conservatives.

There are better solutions to the Big Tech problem. One would be allowing the free market to regulate these platforms, which Jed Rubenfeld explains here. Another would be introducing digital licenses for internet-based companies that would vary based on the size and scope of the company in question — an option Steven Hill explains at length here.

What is clear is that neither of these options should come from the White House. This is the responsibility of Congress since the crux of the complaint lies with Section 230 — a law written and passed by Congress, which must, therefore, be changed by Congress.

Several Republican lawmakers have already proposed their own Section 230 revisions. Trump needs to let them take the lead, rather than signing an executive order out of personal frustration. Because if Trump continues down this road, he might just end up opening a Pandora’s box that we’ll never be able to close.

Photo Caption:President Donald Trump's Twitter feed is photographed on an Apple iPad in New York, Thursday, June 27, 2019. Trump’s next tweet might come with a warning label.
