urn:contentItem:5W88-VRS1-DXH2-634D-00000-00Trump's U.K. Visit Met With Ceremony, Political Battles; Brits To Rally In Opposition Of Trump-May Talks; At Least 55 Democrats Now Favor Impeachment; Couple Arrested In Case Of Missing Connecticut Mom Arraigned; Jared Kushner Interview Triggers New Security Fears Over Russia Approach; Chao's Father Founded Lucrative Shipping Company; Moderates Jeered At California State Democratic Convention; Obama Says U.S. Gun Laws Don't Make Much Sense; 2020 Dems Rail Against NRA, Call For Tough Restrictions; Deputy Saves Sleeping Couple From Rattlesnake2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS @ NIGHT11:00 PM ESTDavid Tafuri, John Taylor, Harmeet Dhillon, Tezlyn FigaroNEWSDomestic060301cb.259Trump's U.K. Visit Met With Ceremony, Political Battles; Brits To Rally In Opposition Of Trump-May Talks; At Least 55 Democrats Now Favor Impeachment; Couple Arrested In Case Of Missing Connecticut Mom Arraigned; Jared Kushner Interview Triggers New Security Fears Over Russia Approach; Chao's Father Founded Lucrative Shipping Company; Moderates Jeered At California State Democratic Convention; Obama Says U.S. Gun Laws Don't Make Much Sense; 2020 Dems Rail Against NRA, Call For Tough Restrictions; Deputy Saves Sleeping Couple From RattlesnakeShannon Bream, Kristin Fisher, Chad Pergram, Trey Gowdy, Trace Gallagher, Doug McKelway, David Spunt, Jessica Tarlov, Lawrence Jones

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Indeed it was.

And that's all the time we have tonight. About 4:00 a.m. here in England. And don't forget to check out my podcast, podcastone.com. Shannon Bream and the "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" team take it all from here. Ms. Shannon.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: She's working 24 hours a day. Thank you for doing it, Laura, and being there.

We begin now with a Fox News alert. Breaking news tonight from London where the president is gearing up for serious business with the outgoing prime minister. His visit has been filled with pomp and circumstance. But what about all those promised protests? Well, stick around for highlights from the president and first lady's dinner with the royal family and all of the scenes of the day.

Plus, Special Counsel Robert Mueller found no criminal activities surrounding the 2016 Trump Tower meeting. But Jared Kushner still facing tough questions about it. And as Democrats threatened to subpoena Mueller to force him to testify. Tray Gowdy joins us to talk about the top questions he has for the former special counsel.

And later, we're taking the polls of progressive lawmakers on impeachment as they return to town. Some top Democrats the House is already laying the groundwork for proceedings to begin. Stick around for that.

Hello and welcome to Fox News @ Night. I'm Shannon Bream in Washington. We begin tonight with correspondent Kristin Fisher as day two of president Trump's official state visit to the U.K. is about to begin. Kristin?

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, tomorrow, President Trump will be getting down to business. His last meeting with outgoing British prime minister, Theresa May. But today, was all about the spectacle of a state dinner with the queen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FISHER (voice-over): From a 41-gun salute welcoming President Trump and the first lady to Buckingham Palace to a string orchestra at a white tie and tiara banquet. The queen rolled out the most red of red carpets for the president's first official state visit, a trip timed to coincide with the 75th anniversary of D-Day.

TRUMP: We thank God for the brave sons of the United Kingdom and the United States who defeated the Nazis and the Nazi regime and liberated millions from tyranny.

QUEEN ELIZABETH, QUEEN OF THE UNITED KINGDOM: After the shared sacrifices of the Second World War, Britain and the United States worked with other allies to build an assembly of international institutions to ensure that the horrors or conflict would never be repeated.

FISHER: A subtle not to NATO and the United Nations, two institutions President Trump loves to criticize. But that was nothing compared to the scathing op-ed penned by London's mayor who said, "Rather than bestowing Trump with a platform of acceptability to the world, we should be speaking out and saying that this behavior is unacceptable and that it poses a grave threat to the values and principles we have fought hard to defend, often together for decades."

Moments before touching down in England, President Trump fired back on Twitter saying, "Sadiq Khan, who by all accounts, has done a terrible job as the mayor of London, has been foolishly nasty to the visiting president of the United States by far the most important ally of the United Kingdom. He is a stone cold loser who should focus on crime in London, not me."

And the focus tomorrow will be on Brexit and trade. The president has been highly critical of how Prime Minister May has handled negotiations to exit the European Union and he's already urging her successor to walk away without a deal and sign a free trade agreement with the United States.

TRUMP: I think there's an opportunity for a very big trade deal at some point in the near future.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FISHER: Now, a large protest is scheduled for tomorrow. They'll be marching from Trafalgar Square to 10 Downing Street which is where President Trump and Prime Minister May will be meeting one last time. Shannon?

BREAM: All right. Kristen Fisher with all the latest in looking ahead to the next day. Thank you very much.

So as activists threaten to ramp up protests against President Trump in London, television personality, Piers Morgan says the opposition is being disrespectful and, in his words, pathetic.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PIERS MORGAN, TELEVISION PERSONALITY: Why is Trump so much more morally reprehensible than the crown prince of Saudi Arabia who executes journalists --

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think it's more of a comment of Donald Trump's that he's egotistical.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: OK. Let's turn to former foreign policy advisor to President Obama's campaign, David Tafuri. And member of the U.K. parliament, Lord John Taylor of Warwick. Great to have you both with us, gentlemen.

DAVID TAFURI, FORMER OBAMA FOREIGN POLICY ADVISER: Thank you.

JOHN TAYLOR, MEMBER OF PARLIAMENT OF THE UNITED KINGDOM: Thank you.

BREAM: Ok. So this is what Reuters says about what's coming tomorrow. They say a giant inflatable blimp depicting Donald Trump as a pouting baby in a diaper will fly outside the British parliament in London on Tuesday ahead of what's expected to be one of the city's largest protests against a foreign leader.

Lord Taylor, what do you make of the situation there in the U.K.?

TAYLOR: Well, I think that protest is childish. Donald Trump is the democratically elected president of the United States of America. America is our strongest ally. We go back a long way. We have a special relationship. We should respect the office. You know, respect the post. His position. Forget the man. He is president. He is owed respect for his position.

BREAM: All right. David, you know that, of course, this is about to be in large part the anniversary of D-Day and how the U.S. and Britain and allies joined together to overcome potential world devastation. And they accomplished a lot in working together.

So why is it that when an American leader goes to Great Britain and it's not just President Trump, but there are, you know, talk of these huge protests when there are other leaders of other -- you know, some would argue more controversial nations like China and Russia. We don't see the same kind of outpouring in the streets.

TAFURI: Well, it's a good point. Look, this visit is much bigger than any presidents, bigger than President Trump, it's bigger than any of our previous presidents. It's about commemorating the brave soldiers from the U.K. and from the U.S. who fought together against Nazi extremism, the 75th anniversary of D-Day. So we should all keep that in mind.

And President Trump brought a little bit of this on himself by getting in these feuds before he came to London, by getting into feud with the mayor of London, by making some comments about Meghan Markle. I hope he can now put that aside and really focus on D-Day.

It's unfortunate that there will be protests with our president going there. No American likes to see that. I don't like to see that. I do think that we need to respect the office of the president. But, of course, the U.K. people have a right to protest against any visitor. You would hope they would protest if Vladimir Putin visited or China -- the head of China visited. There's a lot more to protest for them as you mentioned.

But they have a right to protest. And President Trump is deeply unpopular in the U.K. right now. He's deeply unpopular in Europe. But what he should be doing is sending a message to the people of the U.K. that we will support the U.K. in this difficult time no matter what happens with Brexit.

And one of the ways he can support the U.K. is to do a bilateral trade deal between the U.S. and the U.K., especially if Brexit does happen and the U.K. leaves the E.U. He's mentioned that a little bit, but that should be the focus. Not the stuff with Meghan Markle and the mayor of London.

BREAM: Well, of course, Lord Taylor, you know, the president will say, well, Mayor Khan wrote a nasty piece about me in the paper, it's going to be his characterization of it. And he's going to say, you know, I'm being snubbed by the duchess, Meghan Markle. And he's not one to back down from where he thinks there's been an attack or a fight.

TAFURI: But he needs to be above that, especially because this is about D- Day.

BREAM: OK. Let me bring in Lord Taylor. Let me bring in Lord Taylor.

TAYLOR: Yes, I think he's already shown that he's above that. Because he said he wants to do a trade deal with Britain. Once we leave the European Union. After all, you know, we trade with America. It's our biggest trading partner outside Europe. We want to do more trade with America. And he's already said he wants to do this. And we should allow him to do this.

He is the leader of the free world. Khan is the mayor of London. And I think Trump needs to ignore Khan's nonsense now and focus on the big picture.

BREAM: OK. I want to play something from a woman there is supporting -- I believe her name is Margaret Lamb. She's talking about why she's there in London to support President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARGARET LAMB, TRUMP SUPPORTER FROM HONG KONG: I'm here to support him. Because he support democracy, he support Brexiteer, and we want to be independent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: So, David, you know, the people who voted for Brexit and are supportive of that idea, they have a lot of reasons to like President Trump.

TAFURI: Well, I suppose they do. I mean, he supported Brexit. But still not clear what's going to happen with the U.K. and Brexit. There's no deal yet.

And President Trump may actually accidentally hurt the Brexiteers' cause by being so supportive of it. That's, of course, his choice. But I think the better policy for the U.S. is to say that's an issue for the U.K. And for the people of the U.K. And no matter what happens with Brexit, the U.S. will maintain its very strong relationship with the U.K. We will come to the aid of the U.K. We will do a bilateral deal with the U.K. And, of course, most importantly, we'll maintain our intelligence alliance and our military alliance with the U.K.

BREAM: Yes. And both sides talked about that tonight at this dinner with the queen. A very positive remembrance of our ties that are stronger than, you know, sometimes people would feel they are stressed in situations like this.

David and Lord Taylor, thank you both very much.

TAFURI: Thank you.

TAYLOR: Thank you.

BREAM: All right. This is a Fox News alert. Congress is back to work tonight as some top Democrats are signaling just a matter of time before they formally begin impeachment proceedings. This reports as some Republicans also are plotting a tariff revolt, while the president is overseas.

Our senior Capitol Hill producer, Chad Pergram has been working his sources and joins us now to separate fact from fiction. Great to have you always.

PERGRAM: Thank you for having me, Shannon.

BREAM: OK. So let's start here. We heard a lot more Democrats talking about impeachment, kind of the formalities over the weekend about it. So, where do we stand?

CHAD PERGRAM, FOX NEWS SENIOR CAPITOL HILL PRODUCER: Well, there were about 50 plus who are calling for impeachment. But that's not even a quarter of the House Democratic Caucus. The House Speaker Nancy Pelosi continues to rule that out.

But we do have a little bit of news here tonight. Steny Hoyer, the House majority leader, has noted that next Tuesday, there will be a vote on the House floor on contempt for William Barr, the attorney general, and also for Don McGahn, the former White House counsel.

We've also learned that this is not going to be inherent contempt where Congress goes and enforces it itself where they go to try to arrest somebody or find them. This will be trying to enforce those subpoenas and they will go through the court.

Now, the other thing that we don't have resolved here is that they have put a deadline on for the 6th later this week for the House Oversight Committee to possibly hold Barr in contempt over the census question and also the commerce secretary William Ross -- Wilbur Ross. So that might play out later this month, so possibly two shots there, Shannon.

BREAM: Well, I mean, the A.G. joked with the speaker about the handcuffs and the whole thing. So it looks like they're not going that route. They're going to go another route on this. Not yet.

OK. So President Trump getting a lot of pushback now on the idea of these tariffs, what it could do to the U.S. economy as well.

PERGRAM: Right. We we're hearing some push now that Democrats might try to engineer a vote. Maybe to put some Republicans on the mark and say, are you for the tariffs or not and maybe try to block it.

Now, I talked to Collin Peterson, he is the chairman of the House agriculture committee. He's a conservative Democrat from Minnesota and he says, you know, these tariffs are hurting our farmers, but it really doesn't matter. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PERGRAM: You have a district that elected you, but voted for President Trump here. What is that doing to people who supported President Trump?

REP. COLLIN PETERSON (D-MN): There's Donald Trump.

PERGRAM: Even in spite of all this.

PETERSON: Yes.

PERGRAM: Why?

PETERSON: It's a good question. You'd have to ask them.

PERGRAM: So, are they willing to vote against their pocketbook?

PETERSON: They already have now.

PERGRAM: Explain why they're doing that?

PETERSON: I can't explain it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PERGRAM: Now, Shannon, what this really means here is that Collin Peterson says they're for Trump, they're for him. I said, "Well, wait a minute. Why do they not support Democrats who were on the opposite issue on the tariff issue?" He said, "Well, I think a lot of these conservative farmers just don't like Democrats." And I said, "Why do they like me?" He said, "Well, I'm not normal."

But this is an issue in the south. It's going to be an issue in the 2020 Senate elections. John Cornyn is up for re-election. He represents a state that has some democratic trends there. He says, look, we have a 1,200-mile border with Mexico. He said border security is important but so is trade and that could adversely hit the economy there.

BREAM: OK. So let's now look at big tech because the House Judiciary Committee making some noise today about investigating groups like Apple, Facebook, Google, some of the big ones out there. What's going on with that?

PERGRAM: David Cicilline is democratic congressman from Rhode Island. He chairs the subcommittee that deals with anti-trust. And he said a lot of the laws that were written to deal with these big corporations go back to the age of the railroads. They haven't kept up. And he doesn't think that these firms have the wherewithal nor the willingness to work with Congress and work with other people to try to, you know, assure the marketplace.

So they're going to investigate. This comes as the Department of Justice is also looking at anti-Trust questions for Alphabet, Google, essentially.

And you know what the issue is here? Is that some of these firms, when you -- when you -- when you consider what they're behemoth and sometimes the marketplace takes care of them and you talk to some of the Democrats who want to go through this investigation, they will say the market isn't working and that's why Congress needs to step in. And that's why David Cicilline says it's time for Congress to act, Shannon.

BREAM: It's going to be a major overhaul to the tech laws, as they now exist, as you mentioned, based on where the foundations of them set long before much of this came along, so.

PERGRAM: Absolutely.

BREAM: All right. Chad Pergram, always great to have you.

PERGRAM: Thanks for having me. Good to see you.

BREAM: Thanks for stopping in.

OK. Top White House economic advisor, Kevin Hassett, is leaving his post. President Trump says he'll announce a replacement when he gets back from his state visit to the U.K.

The departure comes amid escalating trade tensions with China and the new threat of tariffs on Mexico. And Hassett says they are not connected and that two years is about the usual stay for someone in his current position.

Well, Democrats say they'll likely subpoena Robert Mueller if he refuses to testify voluntarily. Well, Mueller says his report speaks for itself. So what questions would former oversight chairman Trey Gowdy have for Mueller? I'll ask him when he joins us, next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONATHAN SWAN, AXIOS POLITICAL REPORTER: This is -- we're talking about Russia here. They are a long-term adversary of the United States, decades of hostility, including spying. Does it not set off at least some alarm bell when you see an e-mail saying that the Russian government wants to help --

(CROSSTALK)

JARED KUSHNER, ADVISER TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: Like I -- like said, the e-mail that I got on my iPhone at the time basically said, show up at 4:00. I didn't scroll down. I never would have thought about that --

SWAN: It had Russia in the -- in the subject line.

KUSHNER: Again, I would get about 250 e-mails a day. And so I literally saw, show up at 4:00. I showed up at 4:00. But --

SWAN: Would you call the FBI if it happened again?

KUSHNER: I don't know. It's hard to do hypotheticals. But the reality is, is that we were not given anything that was salacious.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: OK. A tense exchange between Axios Reporter Jonathan Swan and Senior White House Adviser Jared Kushner about an e-mail which set up the Trump Tower meeting. Kushner says he doesn't know if he would alert the FBI if he got a similar e-mail. He said it's hard to do hypotheticals. Well, let's talk about it now with Fox News Contributor, former South Carolina Congressman Trey Gowdy. Great to have you with us, sir.

TREY GOWDY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you for having me.

BREAM: OK. So what do you make of that? I mean, the Mueller report ultimately didn't find to make a finding of collusion or coordination based on that Trump Tower meeting. But you can see there, Jared Kushner is getting some heat for his answers to the question.

GOWDY: Yes. We spent about 10 hours with Jared when I was on the House Intelligence Committee. He's not a professional witness. Here's what I remember distinctly about it. As soon as he got in the meeting, he started looking for a way to get out of the meeting including texting his administrative assistant and saying, hey, can you come up with some excuse for me to leave?

What I'm really looking forward to, Shannon, is Jonathan Swan sitting down with the DNC or Perkins Coie or Fusion FPS and asking them not a hypothetical but actually about getting dirt from Russia. Not about a meeting that didn't take place, that Kushner didn't stay at for 15 minutes but the DNC and Perkins Coie and Fusion GPS actually spending lots of money to get the same Russian dirt. I can't wait to hear him ask that question.

BREAM: Why do you think that question hasn't been asked of some of those players?

GOWDY: It doesn't fit the narrative? They wanted her to win? I don't know. I -- you know, there is some evidence that the very same Russian lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya met with Donald Trump Jr. and Jared Kushner briefly met with Glenn Simpson before and after she met with them. But your viewers wouldn't know that because there's been almost no coverage. What they should know is that lots and lots of money was spent by a political party to hire a foreign national to go dig up Russian dirt.

Not a meeting, not a 15-minute meeting where you get your secretary to get you out of it, but a concerted effort. I think most Americans do equate that. For whatever reason, the D.C. media does not.

BREAM: OK. So we're also having this conversation in the context of this whole bigger story about whether or not the Special Counsel will be compelled to testify. Former now, Special Counsel Robert Mueller. First to the chairman of the House Intel Committee now, Adam Schiff. Here's what he says.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D-CA): I think he has one last service to perform. It's not enough merely to speak for 10 minutes and say I'm not going to answer questions for the Congress to the American people. There are great many things that are not in the report.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Now, we increasingly hear that there are some people on the right who do want Mueller to go testify on the Hill. Rudy Giuliani? One of the lawyers to the President says this, if they allow Congressman Meadows and Jordan and a few of the others there, they will eviscerate him more than they did Michael Cohen. In terms of the politics of it, I would love to have him testify, I think he's afraid to. Trey, what would you ask him?

GOWDY: Well, what I would ask him, did you have enough evidence to indict Donald Trump? Did you not indict him because of the factual deficiency or did you not indict him because he's the President and the Department of Justice has a policy. That'd be the first question. But you can't do it in five minutes. To Rudy Giuliani's frankly absurd point that something constructive would come from the hearing, the Michael Cohen hearing was a disaster.

The same thing will happen with Mueller because you're limiting yourself to five minutes. So, Shannon, you're an attorney, you would want to ask Mueller, was it a factual deficiency or did you not indict him because legally you could not? And then I'm sure you would pivot at that point to which of these fact patterns constitute obstruction. And you would drill down and to whether or not each of those essential elements was met.

And then if you had time left over, you would ask him about Peter Strzok and whether you fired him because he was bias or just the appearance of bias. And that now would kind of segue you into well then, why did you hire so many lawyers that donated to Donald Trump's appointment? So -- Donald Trump's opponent. So you would want to do all of that. You couldn't do it in an hour, much less five minutes.

I hope he doesn't come. I didn't want his report to be made public. Prosecutors don't exonerate people, they don't clear people. They indict or they shut up. He didn't indict so the other option is just to go back into your private life.

BREAM: Well, you sound like you've put together a road map as somebody who has prosecuted a great many cases. And we'll see. I mean, Schiff has said that if he doesn't come willingly, there's a great possibility of a subpoena. We know many of those are tied up and potential political and legal battles moving forward. So, we'll have you come back and talk about those because there's going to be no shortage of news on this.

Former Congressman Trey Gowdy, thank you very much always for your time.

GOWDY: Yes, ma'am, thank you.

BREAM: All right. Breaking news tonight in the missing Connecticut mom case, chilling new surveillance video revealing potential new clues, next.

BREAM: Brand new information tonight about a missing mother of five in Connecticut. Officials releasing arrest warrant after Jennifer Dulos' estranged husband and made this first court appearances. Correspondent Trace Gallagher is on the case for us tonight. Good evening, Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Shannon. Jennifer Dulos went missing in New Canaan, Connecticut and court record say that on the day she disappeared, her estranged husband Fotis Dulos was caught on multiple surveillance cameras about 70 miles away in Hartford getting out of his Ford Raptor and placing several garbage bags into various trash bins.

The Hartford Courant says the bags and some items inside were stained with Jennifer Dulos' blood. The same surveillance video shows the estranged husband's girlfriend, Michelle Troconis leaning out of the passenger window of the Ford and either placing something on the ground or picking something up. Even more damning, when Jennifer Dulos went missing, police searched her New Canaan home and found a large quantity of physical evidence including multiple human blood stains on the garage floor and blood spatter on the walls.

There was also evidence that someone tried to clean it up, quoting here based upon the crime scene processing, investigators came to a consensus that a serious physical assault had occurred at the scene and Jennifer Dulos was the suspected victim. Troconis and Dulos both appeared in court today though neither entered a plea. The two apparently became romantically involved about a year before Jennifer Dulos filed for divorce.

Court documents say the couple has been involved in a bitter custody battle over their five children, ages eight to 13 and that Jennifer Dulos said she was "Terrified for hair families safety especially since discovering the gun since my husband has a history of controlling, volatile, and delusional behavior." She also accused the husband of threatening to kidnap their children and to take them to Greece. Fotis Dulos has pushed back on his wife's allegations, saying she has mental health issues. The girlfriend, Michelle Troconis, is an Argentinian high roller known for interviewing celebrities and opening an upscale Argentine ski resort. She was able to make the $500,000 bail. Fotis Dulos remains behind bars. Shannon?

BREAM: All right. Trace Gallagher live on the West Coast. Thank you very much. Well, the House has finally passed a disaster aid package after the bill failed three times over the past week and a half, now each time an individual lawmaker held up the entire process. Also, tonight, a federal judge has thrown out Democrat's lawsuits against President Trump's emergency border wall funding reallocation, saying the issue is fundamentally politically.

Well, Transportation Department official say Secretary Elaine Chao has been a champion of the American Maritime Industry, but the New York Times is reporting on what some consider uncomfortably close ties between Chao, who's married to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and her families shipping dealings in China. Correspondent Doug McKelway has the story and the push back.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: A spokesman for Transportation Secretary Elain Chao call today's frontpage New York Time's story "a lie." A source close to Senate Majority Leader Mithc McConnel says it's deeply flawed. The paper alleges that Chao and her husband, McConnell, have used their influence and power to gain mutual benefit from her family's business, the Foremost Group, an American shipping company that does millions of dollars of business with China. Its CEO is Angela Chao, Elaine's sister. She replaced their now-retired father, James, seen here at Chao's confirmation hearing.

ELAINE CHAO, SECRETARY OF DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION: I'm especially delighted to introduce my father, Dr. James S.C. Chao.

MCKELWAY: The Times cites this October 2017 e-mail from a U.S. embassy official in China, written to superiors on the eve of Chao's planned visit to Beijing. The body of it is entirely redacted, but the Times quotes people allegedly familiar with the e-mail, including David Ranke, the now retired Deputy Chief Commission in Beijing, who says that Chao asked federal officials to help coordinate travel arrangements for at least one family member and include relatives and meetings with government officials.

Chao never made the trip. Her office tells Fox News it didn't occur for multiple reasons including scheduling and two meetings at the White House. The story alleges that Chao and Leader McConnell received millions of dollars in campaign contributions and gifts from her father. McConnell acknowledge the legal gifts in the Times story, apparently given after the death of Chao's mother. He said, "I'm proud to have the support of my family over the years." One government watchdog with more than 30 years of experience sums up the Times lengthy expose.

THOMAS SCHATZ, CITIZENS AGAINST GOVERNMENT WASTE: It's a giant story about nothing. There's nothing new, there's nothing newsworthy. This story is boring, it's long, and it's really useless.

MCKELWAY: McConnell's former chief of staff tweeted: "Imagine for one moment that Elaine Chao was Elaine Johnson and her family emigrated from England. Do you think the New York Times would be interested in publishing that story?" Shannon?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: All right. Doug McKelway, thank you very much. California is being told to brace for widespread blackouts this summer. That tops tonight's "WESTERN ROUNDUP." One of the state's largest power utilities, PG&E is telling customers, don't count on reliable service during fire season. State regulators recently approved the company's plan to imposing massive blackouts this summer in an effort to prevent wildfires.

An event organizer for Sacramento's Pride Parade asking Sacramento police officers to march in civilian clothes or don't show up -- in an effort to avoid protests from some in the LGBTQ community who say they associated police with negative experiences. The Sacramento Police Department going to bat for gay officers saying, "they have worked hard to earn these uniforms and are proud to wear them."

And get this, the Swedish-based company, Kangaroo, planning to challenge e- scooters in major cities with an alternative mode of transportation, pogo sticks. The company says this is legit, not a joke. Says it's going to launch its first Pogo sticks in Sweden and hopes to branch out into San Francisco as early as late summer. Kangaroo says Pogo sticks are faster than walking and more environmentally friendly than cars and e-scooters. Going to skip that one.

OK. Joe Biden skips the California State Democratic Convention, as the left, including most of his 2020 rivals takes aim at the front runner for being too moderate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Those who have chosen for whatever reason not to be in this room...

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Tezlyn Figaro and Harmeet Dhillon break down the growing divide within the Democratic Party, next.

BREAM: The first major cattle call for 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls and front runner, Joe Biden, was more than 2,000 miles away. And his rivals did not waste the opportunity to go after the former vice president in his absence. Correspondent David Spunt has more on this big event this weekend. Hey, David.

DAVID SPUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, 24 candidates hoping to oust President Trump. The first debate set for the end of this month. These Democrats trying to make a name for themselves, many in California to do so. But the man on top of the pack decided to skip it altogether.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SPUNT: A tough crowd in California, booing at 2020 presidential candidates. John Hickenlooper got an ear full at the California State Democratic Convention.

JOHN HICKENLOOER, FORMER GOVERNOR OF COLORADO: If we want to beat Donald Trump and achieve big, progressive goals, socialism is not the answer. I was reelected.

SPUNT: But Hickenlooper wasn't the only candidate to receive scoffs from the crowd. John Delaney criticized the plan gaining popularity among candidates.

JOHN DELANEY, FORMER UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Medicare for All may sound good, but it's actually not good policy nor is it good politics. I'm telling you.

SPUNT: New York Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, known as an outspoken party progressive took to Twitter telling the White House hopeful: "John Delaney, thank you but please sashay-away." The front runner of the pack, Joe Biden, becoming inescapable subject for candidates.

PETE BUTTIGIEG, MAYOR OF SOUTH BEND: People have seen Democratic and Republican administrations letting them down for basically as long as I've been alive.

SPUNT: Over the weekend, Biden skipped the California event.

SANDERS: As you all know, there is a debate among potential candidates who have spoken to you here in this room and those who have chosen or whatever reason not to be in this room.

SPUNT: The former vice president was in Columbus, Ohio, at a dinner celebrating the human rights campaign.

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This White House has literally, literally a bully pulpit, has callously extending its power over the most vulnerable. Implementing discriminatory policies, like Muslin bans; turning away asylum seekers, putting children in cages.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SPUNT: Joe Biden's absence could be problematic as California is now more of an important primary state. The primary moved to March 3rd, Tuesday. The hope is to make the Golden State more competitive Shannon, in the nominating process. Hard to believe that debate is just a few weeks away in Miami.

BREAM: I know, and we'll be there. And we're taking our show in the road.

SPUNT: Yes.

BREAM: All right. David, thank you so much.

SPUNT: Sure, thanks.

BREAM: OK, progressives, of course, you saw there making the most of Biden's absence taking aim at his more moderate approach. So, let's bring in former Bernie Campaign Staffer Tezlyn Figaro; and the Vice President of the Republican National Lawyers Association Harmeet Dhillon. Ladies, great to have both of you with us tonight.

HARMEET DHILLON, VICE PRESIDENT, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL LAWYERS ASSOCIATION: Thanks, Shannon. Happy to be here.

BREAM: OK. I want to play a little something that Rush Limbaugh had to say about the folks going after Biden while he was not there in California. He did have another commitment that he told them about. But here's Rush's take.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, RADIO HOST: They ripped Biden a new one -- this is within the context of the California State Convention, but wait until it starts happening campaign wide. They don't want to hear about crossing the aisle -- reaching across -- they don't want to hear about that. They want Republicans gone. They want Republicans ended.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Harmeet, and yet he continues polls way ahead the rest of his rivals for now, at least.

DHILLION: Well, outside the crazy town, San Francisco, where I live, actually, I think people are interested in a more moderate message but I actually don't think that the Democrats are going to allow Joe Biden to be the one to carry that forward. They're really pushing him to the left on many issues. And the extremism on display in my hometown over the weekend was shocking. I'm pretty sure I heard the chance of impeachment and the booing up in my home several miles away.

Now, you know, the Democrats are out of touch. We're talking about Socialism, we're talking about Medicare for All, we're talking about raising taxes further in California and open borders. So, this is not actually what America thinks -- even Democrats don't think this outside of San Francisco. And I think it's really a poor prospect for them to be focusing on this type of extremism. The nation is not interested in impeachment and it's just kind of a delusion for them to focus on this as opposed to advancing their legislative agenda. Even Nancy Pelosi got booed for her lack of rigor on this issue.

BREAM: Yes, and we'll, it's interesting, I've read a couple of really good analysis pieces today that talked about the fact that when you go out there and talk to average Democrats across America, they're not down with a lot of the stuff on the left. But right now, those seem to be some of the loudest voices that you're hearing. The Washington Post says this under the headline: "Liberals go after Joe Biden trying to blunt his presidential candidacy and the recent centrist surge on the Democratic Party."

They say this in the piece: "The broadsides, they're -- there in California this weekend --- amounted to the loudest warning yet from the party's left flank that it intends to aggressively challenge the centrist ideas and cautious politics that have gained a foothold. Leftist candidates and activists have concluded they can no longer wait for Biden to fade on his own." I know, Tezlyn, a lot of people thought he gets in, he's got the name recognition, of course, he's going to be at the head of the pack but he doesn't seem to be flagging at all, yet.

TEZLYN FIGARO, FORMER BERNIE SANDERS CAMPAIGN STAFFER: Well, this is my concern, you know, and I was critical with Bernie Sanders when he folded like a lawn chair when he was on the stage with Hillary Clinton, when he said no one wants to hear about your damn e-mails. Anybody can talk about somebody around the corner, but where I'm from it's all about if you're going to talk about it to his face. Let's see if the same candidates have the same energy that they have when it's time for debate time. Let's see if Bernie Sanders challenges Joe Biden instead of just saying like some of us who are not in the room. Call it out, Senator Sanders, don't be afraid. I would say man up, but he's 77. So, grandpa up.

If you have an issue with Joe Biden, speak it. And also, where does he stand on these issues, where do you stand, Senator Sanders? Are you for reparations? Are you not? Are you for fixing the crime bill, are you not? People that I know are not falling for the banana in the tailpipe. You see the division because people are not making clear where they stand. And so, debates, is going to be telling to see where these candidates take their position -- and if he doesn't have the guts, because if he doesn't have the guts to go against old sweet Uncle Joe, he certainly can't take down Trump.

BREAM: Well, I want to ask you both briefly to respond to the same question. Harmeet, I'll start with you; how do you think this first debate is going to play out with? Right now, I think the number is at 23. I'm not sure exactly how many have qualified to get in, but it's going to be a couple of days of variable stages. All right, we lost Harmeet, so Tezlyn, how about you? Let me know what you think about how this is going to go down with all those people on the stage for days.

FIGARO: Yes, I think it's going to be more of the let's all just get along and pretend as if, you know, we don't want to challenge anyone because they're afraid to be able to say: you know, hey, I disagree with you. I have no issue, you know, with people having different positions. This is the Democrats process. So, if this is the time for Democrats to really fight it out. And Republicans will have their opportunity to decide if they vote for a Democratic candidate or not. So, the more that they try to avoid the tough questions, the more they try to just say let's all just get along and refuse to actually have a real competitive fight, they're going to continue to see the same problems with the divide within the base.

BREAM: Tezlyn, you make a great point. We'll see how when they're face- to-face it really goes. Tezlyn Figaro and Harmeet wherever you are in cyberspace, thank you both, great to have you both. All right, President Obama tells audience in Brazil that American gun laws make no sense.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Anybody who buy any weapon anytime, would not much -- if nay --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: OK, he's being fact-checked tonight, though. Jessica Tarlov and Lawrence Jones are here to weigh in with the fact checkers too, next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: Some of you may be aware, our gun laws in the United States don't make much sense. Anybody can buy any weapon at any time without much, if any regulation. They can buy it over the Internet, they can buy a machine gun.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: OK, former President Barack Obama claiming that anybody at any time can buy a gun in America even machine guns. But multiple fact-checkers or calling out the former commander chief on several of those points tonight. So, let's bring in, Fox News Contributor Jessica Tarlov and Lawrence Jones to discuss. Welcome to you both.

JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

BREAM: OK. So, there have been a number of articles out there going point by point about all the gun regulations, the fact that you really can buy machine guns, all these things in the fact checks today. Rolling Stone says this: "Most are strident Second Amendment defenders who are parsing his overall point by making the argument that there are restrictions on what Obama called machine guns," those were his words. "But they know all too well that the type of weapons used in most mass shootings are readily available and they fight to keep laws that allow that truth to remain." So, Lawrence, they say, you're taking stuff out of context. It's about trying to keep dangerous guns on the streets.

LAWRENCE JONES, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Like abusers, people that have been adjudicated as mentally unfit can't get guns. I mean, you can't buy guns over the Internet without going through a federal dealer who hasn't -- go through a federal background check. I mean, there were so many things that were just factually inaccurate. And him, as a former President of the United States, and someone who's been fighting against gun legislation for more gun legislation should know something about this. So, I think they're just trying to muddy the waters. But at the end of the day, you know, most people know this stuff right here, Shannon, and you expect the former president to know the law as well.

BREAM: Well, here's the thing. Daily Wire has this under the headline: "Obama tells multiple lies about guns in the U.S. to a crowd in Brazil says this: "Making blatantly false statements about firearms is somewhat of a hobby for Obama as he often lied about firearms during his presidency as tried to push for far-left gun control." Now, they go through and walk through two fact checks from the Washington Post, "not a conservative outlet." In 2015 and 2016 rating his statements, then the President Obama's statements false on gun issues. I mean, Jessica, he is a very intelligent guy. He knows the difference. I mean, this almost feels like an unforced error to make such broad statements about this issue.

TARLOV: I don't think that it really is for the audience that Barack Obama is speaking to. I'm not talking about the Brazilians that were in the audience but those of us back home who feel similarly that there are too many powerful weapons in the hands of people who shouldn't have them. If you listen to the prime minister of New Zealand for instance, who gave an interview over the weekend about this, said she absolutely doesn't understand how a country that has the most mass shootings of any nation on earth doesn't then turn around and change the laws.

I think what Barack Obama was also speaking to is the fact that we've recently even had two shootings in (INAUDIBLE) and Sutherland Springs, where the people who perpetrated those crimes had committed domestic violence. When you look at what happened in Las Vegas, the fact that person -- the shooter was able to amass dozens of weapons because he didn't have to register those rifles, that's when you get to these conversations about having a national gun registry.

BREAM: But I think if he is going to talk about these things and people are going to have a conversation, you have to deal from a factual basis. I think you can be emotional and think that something needs to be changed and things need to be done. But you know, we took note of what's going on in Chicago which has some of the toughest gun laws in the country and a horrible weekend there, I think we might have some stats on that. I mean, there's a situation where they had their most violent weekend, at least ten people dead, dozens of other people wounded in these attacks. I mean, Lawrence, we can have a conversation at least we have to be truthful about the state of gun laws in this country.

JONES: Yes, especially when you're lying intentionally to the American public. I think that's also concerning. But again, shocker, criminals don't abide by gun laws. I mean, look, I understand, we have to have some national conversation when it comes to a lot of these shootings. But in reality, legislators don't know what to do because, guess what? Criminals are going to always be able to get guns. They're not abiding by the gun laws. So, the conversation needs to be now that we know that we're not going to agree on gun legislation, what do we do to protect our kids? May be putting metal detectors on our schools, securing our buildings like we secure banks, and the president of the United States. That should be where the conversation is going. Instead, we want to go back and forth on what we believe the Second Amendment represents lies.

BREAM: Let me bring Jessica in here for a final word.

TARLOV: Well, obviously, obviously I'm a pollster by training. I'm a big believer in the facts and in using numbers accurately, that's why I said I think that what Obama was trying to get to is the larger conversation here. Chicago is undoubtedly a tragedy. Mayor Lightfoot who was just sworn in has a big task ahead and she campaigned specifically on this. It's important, though, to go back to a 2017 study which showed that over 60 percent of the firearms that are used in these crimes came from out of state. Also, 95 percent of the weapons that are used were not secured by the person who's using them. So, that's to Lawrence point. People are going to commit crimes. We have to look at this holistically and treat the problem at the root.

BREAM: We're going to leave it there.

JONES: The facts matter though.

BREAM: Yes, they do. We both all agree to that.

TARLOV: Yes, that's why I just gave you a bunch of that.

BREAM: OK, we got to leave it there. Jessica and Lawrence, thank you both very much.

TARLOV: Thanks, Shannon.

BREAM: Our "MIDNIGHT HERO" next.

JONES: Thanks, Shannon.

BREAM: All right, check this out. Deputy Adams (INAUDIBLE) with the (INAUDIBLE) County Sheriff's Department in Tennessee was out on patrol when he spotted this couple asleep on a dirt road along with a rattlesnake. Look at it, right by them. All right, he woke them up trying to keep them calm; he told them to stay put.

Well, the guy did probably what I would've done. He gets up and takes off. In the end, everyone was safe. The dash cam tells the story. Deputy (INAUDIBLE), for your composure in the face of danger, you're our "MIDNIGHT HERO." I have so many questions. Most watched, most trusted, most grateful you spent the evening with us. Good night from Washington. I'm Shannon Bream.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TFT-D9K1-JBCN-42B7-00000-00Trump’s USMCA Protects Big Tech2018-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:15ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Trump’s USMCA Protects Big TechKATE PATRICKINSIDESOURCES.COM

One of Silicon Valley’s concerns in the renegotiation of NAFTA was in the area of free speech and content regulation, and the final draft turned out to be good news for Big Tech - - mostly. ‘

According to the new United States-MexicoCanada-Agreement (USMCA), tech compa- nies like Facebook and Google will not be liable or prosecutable for any content they host on their sites, even if that content is false or illegal. There is, however, one exception: the new agreement says the U.S., Mexico and Canada can enact “measures necessary to protect public morals” and hold tech companies liable for content that facilitates sex trafficking, child trafficking and prostitution.

The agreement mimics Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, which several libertarian experts have praised for protecting tech companies from liabilities and lawsuits related to the content curated on their sites. The Electronic Frontier Foundation calls the CDA’s Section 230 the “most important law protecting internet speech.”

That protection ends when it comes to sex trafficking. The new USMCA specifically references the US.’ amendment to the Communications Act of 1934 , passed earlier this year, the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act of 2017 (commonly referred to as FOSTA), which Silicon Valley lobbied against.

FOSTA was the result of an 18-month Senate investigation into Backpage.com, a website notorious for facilitating online sex trafficking and sexual exploitation of children. Thanks to FOSTA, tech companies can be held liable for knowingly running ads for sex trafficking and child sex.

Lisa Thompson, vice president of research and education at the National Center on Sexual Exploitation, said neglecting to hold tech companies liable for this in the new NAFTA agreement would encourage cross-border sex trafficking, which has increased rapidly over the past 10 years, especially at the U.S.-Mexico border.

Simply copy-and-pasting Section 230 language into the new NAFTA agreement, she wrote in an op-ed for The Hill, would “be nothing short of a sex-trafficking apocalypse.”

Silicon Valley - including many tech publications and libertarian voices - decried FOSTA for restricting internet freedom, and Google lobbied earnestly against its passage. The tech industry also lobbied for the new NAFTA agreement to include Section 230 language without caveats. According to a Quartz report, internet and tech companies and associations spent $38 million on lobbying through August this year.

According to two lawyers in an analysis published by Bloomberg, “The safe harbor [of Section 230] has always been a double-edged sword. For platforms, the task of monitoring user content and responding to demands to remove defamatory or otherwise unlawful thirdparty content could easily become so onerous as to be infeasible. On the other hand, for parties aggrieved by unlawful postings, it can be immensely difficult to cause an unresponsive platform to remove even obviously wrongful - even demonstrably illegal - content or speech.”

In an August 2017 letter to congressional staffers, Google lobbyist Stewart Jeffries wrote that FOSTA “has the potential to seriously jeopardize the internet ecosystem” and “undercut[s] one of the foundational statutes for the Internet: Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act.”

During Google’s Q2 2018, Jeffries lobbied the United States Trade Representative (USTR) on behalf of Google on a number of issues related to the NAFTA (now USMCA) renegotiation, like “freedom of expression and free flow of information,” as well as lobbying Congress over “anti-human trafficking” and FOSTA.

Aware of the tech industry’s push, rescued victims of sex trafficking sent a letter to Congress in September asking for the “Section 230-like language” in the new NAFTA agreement to be modi?ed to hold internet and tech companies liable for “knowingly facilitating” sex trafficking.

Beyond Borders FLPAT Canada, a national advocacy organization seeking to end exploitation of children, said Canadian representatives in the NAFTA renegotiation responded to concerns “that the agreement might include a blanket prohibition which would prevent Canada from imposing liability on internet providers for content. We are pleased to see that the agreement would allow Canada to hold internet providers liable for online sexual exploitation of children.”

Beyond Borders ECPAT Canada also applauded FOSTA earlier this year.

While the USMCA is still a huge win for Silicon Valley, the tech industry’s resistance to anti-sex trafficking efforts may only strengthen anti-Big Tech sentiments in Washington as scrutiny of some of the major players

- like Google, Facebook and Twitter intensifies.

EDITOR’S NOTE: Kate Patrick reports technology and ?nance news for InsideSources. She previously reported supply chain, freight, logistics, and procurement news as well as supply chain tech and regulation news for B2B startup Industry Dive.

Patrick

urn:contentItem:5X45-RPD1-DYFF-817X-00000-00Trump's vaping crackdown could help Big Tobacco by ending decade's biggest small-business success story2019-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisAPg. 006Trump's vaping crackdown could help Big Tobacco by ending decade's biggest small-business success storyAndrew Van Dam Washington Post

In the national conversation, vape shops are often punchlines or villains. But in the data, they're something else: a miraculous small-business success story.

Mom-and-pop vape shops are the fastest-growing retail segment of the past decade, as well as the one with the highest share of employees at small businesses. But a government ban on flavored vapes and increased regulation could wipe them out and leave an opening for Big Tobacco and big tech to dominate the fast-growing industry.

Tobacconists - the broader category that includes vape shops - have lapped every other retail segment since 2009 thanks to an explosion of tiny businesses, Labor Department data show.

Two-thirds of vape-shop workers are employed by the 93% of businesses with fewer than 10 employees - a higher rate than for any other retail segment.

Yelp's vast databases, which allow us to break out segments not yet tracked by the government, agree. Since the end of 2012, vape shops have been the fastest-growing large retail segment tracked by the online review site. The shops are concentrated in the West and South, Yelp data show, with Nevada and Oklahoma competing for the title of vapingest state.

The entire industry has come under increased scrutiny in recent weeks as an unidentified lung illness, thought to be vaping related, has killed at least seven people and sickened more than 500. Investigators have focused on black-market products containing THC, the active ingredient in marijuana, but they are casting a wide net.

In response to alarm over those mystery illnesses, as well as to broader concerns about vaping's growing appeal to high school students, the Trump administration has announced plans to ban all flavored vaping liquids, or juices. The federal ban may not kick in for months, but the governors of two large states - Michigan and New York - have announced similar bans. Those will hit much sooner.

Vape shops in those states are reeling. Customers are racing to stock up on flavored liquids while store owners and employees ponder an uncertain future. Vape juice refills, which e-cigarettes heat to the point of vaporization, make up the bulk of these shops' businesses, multiple managers said - and their adult customers overwhelmingly prefer flavored options.

On the surface, Da Vape Escape in Iron Mountain, Michigan, plays to stereotype. Goofy head-shop-meets-heavy-metal imagery festoons its Facebook page, and its website lists faux edgy flavors such as Alien Piss (blue raspberry lemonade) and Your Mom (sweet tangy strawberry yogurt topped with nectarine).

But in this town of about 7,000 residents on the Upper Peninsula, they are a pillar of the community, manager Ryan Brown said. They contribute to local events and even helped rehabilitate the disc golf course. The flavored-juice ban, though, could yank that pillar right out. "It's going to affect our town," he said. "They rely on mom-and-pop stores to keep these mining towns going when the mines are gone. Imagine how much tax revenue they're going to lose."

The impending flavored-juice bans are just the first major hurdle facing the country's thousands upon thousands of mom-and-pop vape shops. In May of next year, the FDA will require approval for vape liquids already on the market, an approval that its site says could cost between $117,000 and $466,000. The date has been moved several times by FDA officials and a court ruling, but vape-shop employees still know it by heart - they say it will mark the vape-pocalypse.

Most agree regulation is necessary, but expensive barriers like these will tilt the balance of the industry toward the big-money players, said Travis Pritchard, manager at Vaporz in Whitesboro, New York. "After the mom and pop stores are essentially flushed out of New York, the only devices you'll find are Juuls," he said. Juul, a svelte device available in many convenience stores and bodegas, is based in San Francisco. Its largest investor is Marlboro maker Altria.

Vape-shop managers like Pritchard and Brown say they got into the industry to help people stop smoking. Cigarette smoking causes more than 480,000 deaths a year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. At vape shops, customers often taper to lower and lower nicotine concentrations, until they're vaping a zero-nicotine product. Eventually, some will quit entirely.

But while adult smokers seem to have benefited from the vaping boom, officials point to a worrying spike in teen use.

"I know the governor is worried about kids," Brown said. "What about my kids? I've got two kids at home. I'm going to lose my job if they ban flavored vape juice."

Vaping

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X41-8061-DXKP-J2NM-00000-00Trump's vaping crackdown could help Juul by ending the decade's biggest small-business success story;Mom-and-pop vape shops were the great small-business success story of the decade. New regulations could wipe them out and allow Big Tobacco and big tech to dominate the fast-growing industry.2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:15ZLexisNexisTrump's vaping crackdown could help Juul by ending the decade's biggest small-business success storyMom-and-pop vape shops were the great small-business success story of the decade. New regulations could wipe them out and allow Big Tobacco and big tech to dominate the fast-growing industry.Andrew Van Dam

In the national conversation, vape shops are often punchlines or villains. But in the data, they are something else: a miraculous small-business success story.

Mom-and-pop vape shops are the fastest-growing retail segment of the past decade, as well as the one with the highest share of employees at small businesses. But a government ban on flavored vapes and increased regulation could wipe them out and leave an opening for Big Tobacco and big tech to dominate the fast-growing industry.

Tobacconists - the broader category that includes vape shops - have lapped every other retail segment since 2009, thanks to an explosion of tiny businesses, Labor Department data show.

Two thirds of vape-shop workers are employed by the 93 percent of businesses with fewer than 10 employees - a higher rate than for any other retail segment.

Yelp's vast databases, which allow us to break out segments not yet tracked by the government, agree. Since the end of 2012, vape shops have been the fastest-growing large retail segment tracked by the online review site. The shops are concentrated in the West and South, Yelp data show, with Nevada and Oklahoma competing for the title of vapingest state.

The entire industry has come under increased scrutiny in recent weeks as an unidentified lung illness, thought to be vaping-related, has killed at least 7 people and sickened more than 500. Investigators have focused on black-market products containing THC, the active ingredient in marijuana, but they are casting a wide net.

In response to alarm over those mystery illnesses, as well as to broader concerns about vaping's growing appeal to high school students, the Trump administration has announced plans to ban all flavored vaping liquids, or juices. The federal ban may not kick in for months, but the governors of two large states - Michigan and New York - have announced similar bans. Those will hit much sooner.

Vape shops in those states are reeling. Customers are racing to stock up on flavored liquids while store owners and employees ponder an uncertain future. Vape juice refills, which e-cigarettes heat to the point of vaporization, make up the bulk of these shops' businesses, multiple managers said - and their adult customers overwhelmingly prefer flavored options.

On the surface, Da Vape Escape in Iron Mountain, Mich., plays to stereotype. Goofy head-shop-meets-heavy-metal imagery festoons its Facebook page, and its website lists faux edgy flavors such as Alien Piss (blue raspberry lemonade) and Your Mom (sweet tangy strawberry yogurt topped with nectarine).

But in this town of about 7,000 residents on the Upper Peninsula, the shops are a pillar of the community, manager Ryan Brown said. They contribute to local events and even helped rehabilitate the disc golf course. The flavored-juice ban, though, could yank that pillar right out. "It's going to affect our town," he said. "They rely on mom-and-pop stores to keep these mining towns going when the mines are gone. Imagine how much tax revenue they're going to lose."

The impending flavored-juice bans are just the first major hurdle facing the country's thousands of mom-and-pop vape shops. In May of next year, the Food and Drug Administration will require approval for vape liquids already on the market, an approval that its site says could cost between $117,000 and $466,000. The date has been moved several times by FDA officials and a court ruling, but vape shop employees still know it by heart - they say it will mark the vape-pocalypse.

Most agree regulation is necessary, but expensive barriers like these will tilt the balance of the industry toward the big-money players, said Travis Pritchard, manager at Vaporz in Whitesboro, N.Y. "After the mom-and-pop stores are essentially flushed out of New York, the only devices you'll find are Juuls," he said. Juul, a svelte device available in many convenience stores and bodegas, is based in San Francisco. Its largest investor is Marlboro maker Altria.

Rules that make running a vape shop more expensive will accelerate a classic cycle in which a few major players muscle out their small-business competition as an industry matures, University of Notre Dame economist Benjamin Pugsley said. "When you have regulations that are increasing the entry cost of any particular industry, that tends to favor the large incumbents," he said.

Vape shops already previewed the process once, in August 2016, when the FDA began regulating e-cigarettes and associated itemsas tobacco products. The change coincided with a sharp drop in vape-shop employment. The industry later resumed its growth, albeit at a slower pace.

Hints of vaping's future may be seen in beer's past. In 1873, when transportation challenges limited competition and regulation was light, there were more than 4,000 breweries in the United States, according to figures from the book "American Breweries II" provided by the Brewers Association.

But the rise of lager-style beers, railroads and refrigeration, combined with expensive technological advancements such as pasteurization and bottling, squeezed out smaller brewers. In 1920, Prohibition dealt a death blow to many of the operations that remained.

"Smaller-scale producers are less likely to be diversified, less likely to have capital reserves, less likely to be able to use influence to move into other markets or find exceptions," said Bart Watson, chief economist at the Brewers Association. "The companies that survived were the ones that were able to rapidly shift markets and weather the storm." He pointed out that Yuengling, for example, entered the ice cream business during the lean years.

Those bigger players swung back into the industry when Prohibition ended, because they were positioned to navigate costly state and local regulations that proliferated in the wake of repeal. It consolidated their advantage. By 1978, there were 89 brewers in the country.

In that same year, regulations finally eased. President Jimmy Carter signed a bill that legalized home brewing. In the years that followed, states relaxed their brewpub bans, Watson said. There were more than 1,500 U.S. breweries by the year 2000, and by 2018 there were 7,450.

There is an important caveat, however. A few enormous corporations still sell six out of every seven U.S. beers, leaving about 7,447 craft brewers to split the remaining 14 percent of the market.

"These regulatory decisions that were made a long time ago have very long historical trajectories," Watson said.

Heavyweights like Anheuser-Busch InBev (41 percent of the market) and Molson Coors (23.5 percent) have also elbowed into the craft beer boom, snapping up smaller brewers and distributing their beverages under myriad craft labels.

We are seeing echoes of that in the vaping industry. Late last year, Altria sought to regain lost ground with a $12.8 billion investment in Juul. It also acquired 45 percent of a Canadian marijuana firm.

Vape-shop managers like Pritchard and Brown say they got into the industry to help people stop smoking. Cigarette smoking causes more than 480,000 deaths a year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. At vape shops, customers often taper to lower and lower nicotine concentrations, until they are vaping a zero-nicotine product. Eventually, some will quit.

But while adult smokers seem to have benefited from the vaping boom, officials point to a worrying spike in teen use. A 2018 survey found 37.3 percent of high school seniors had vaped at some point in the prior year, up from 27.8 percent in 2017. Only 3.6 percent of them reported smoking cigarettes daily.

Brown said age restrictions and better enforcement could keep flavored vape juices out of kids' hands without threatening his mission and livelihood.

"I know the governor is worried about kids," Brown said. "What about my kids? I've got two kids at home. I'm going to lose my job if they ban flavored vape juice."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:603T-V0N1-DY1R-B4TM-00000-00Trump's war against Twitter2020-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisTrump's war against Twitter


U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday signed an executive order that opens the door to a possible cataract of lawsuits against Twitter, Facebook and other tech giants, in a new step in the war he has launched against social media, a major weapon in his election campaign. He accused them of having a "unchecked power to censor, restrict, mold, hide, alter virtually any form of communication."



The President confirmed to reporters at the White House that he had signed it, but the text has not yet been revealed. Trump, who was accompanied by Justice Secretary William Barr, said, "We are here to defend the press freedom of one of the greatest dangers facing American history," he told and accused social media companies of having "unchecked power to censor, restrict, mold, hide, alter virtually any form of communication between private citizens or large public audiences."

He said that "a small and powerful social media monopoly controls a vast public and private communications population in the United States and we know who they are, we don't have to name them, we're going to give them a complete list."

He also noted that Twitter makes "editorial decisions" and is no longer a "neutral platform" but an editor "with a point of view" and has a "political activism." And that you can say the same thing about Facebook, Google and others.

"Imagine if your phone company silenced or edited your conversations. Companies have much greater power and more reach than any phone company in the United States," he added.

The decree is a new step in the President's war against social media, but mostly against Twitter. Trump had given a clue Wednesday night that he would take some action with a tweet: "Big tech companies are doing everything in their power to pre-CENSURE the 2020 election," he wrote. "If this happens, we will no longer have our freedom. I'll never let this happen! They tried in 2016 and didn't lose. Now they're getting absolutely CRAZY. Stay tuned!" The Bloomberg agency issued a draft executive order that Trump would announce. According to the document, the initiative could bring a barrage of lawsuits about social media companies because it lifts certain government protections that these companies have with respect to user posts.

This kind of legal shield is applied based on the alleged "good faith" that companies have to remove or limit the visibility of certain tweets, videos or posts on social networks. But the term "good faith" is not defined by the regulations. The draft would then order the Federal Communications Commission to define that expression, which could open legal gaps so that thousands of users can initiate lawsuits.

According to The New York Times, "the decree, which officials said was still being drafted and subject to change, would make it easier for federal regulators to argue that companies like Facebook, Google, YouTube, and Twitter are suppressing freedom of expression when they mobilize to suspend users or delete posts, among other examples."

The decree, according to Bloomberg, also states that the President will create, through the Department of Justice, a working group of state justice ministers to review misleading practices and review government spending on notices on those platforms.

The decree can open a huge legal battle between Washington and Silicon Valley.

PaulaLugones is a journalist, correspondent for El Clarín in Washington

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:601F-GX21-DYTY-C03C-00000-00Trump's #war on Twitter;The president's spat with Jack Dorsey's empire could turn into a big headache for Big Tech - and might undermine reforms2020-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:16ZLexisNexisBUSINESS AND MONEY;NEWSPg. 6Trump's #war on TwitterThe president's spat with Jack Dorsey's empire could turn into a big headache for Big Tech - and might undermine reformsDANNY FORTSON

s so often with Donald Trump, it started with a tweet: "There is NO WAY (ZERO!) that Mail-In Ballots will be anything less than substantially fraudulent."

" The president was enraged last Tuesday by a plan in California, America's biggest state, to ditch physical voting stations and shift the upcoming presidential ballot to an entirely postal operation to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Trump alleged that ballots would be stolen and forged on an epic scale. "This will be a Rigged Election," he added.

There was little evidence to back up his claims: Justin Levitt of Loyola Law School in Los Angeles analysed more than one billion votes cast between 2000 and 2014.

He found 31 incidents of identity fraud.

Twitter - which for years has allowed its most famous user to rant, rave, bully and bluster uninterrupted - decided, finally, to wade in. The $24bn company slapped "fact-check" links under his tweets. The president and his allies swiftly labelled the move "censorship" - even though it was, in truth, a baby step. His tweets were not removed or edited. Instead, the president's favoured digital bullhorn appended a link in small print encouraging readers to "get the facts" about postal voting.

The following day, Trump signed an executive order telling regulators to strip legal immunity from companies found to have restricted certain voices on their platforms, specifically naming Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and YouTube.

The move threatens to knee-cap the law upon which the modern web - and the empires that dominate it - are built. It sets the stage for an all-out war that experts say may actually delay long-running efforts to hold the Silicon Valley giants to account.

Daniel Gross, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, said the order could be a "Franz Ferdinand moment" (the Austrian archduke whose assassination triggered the First World War) as social media companies go to battle with the government over the future of the internet - and their businesses. Tech trade groups are understood to have filed a federal lawsuit to strike down the order.

Hany Farid, a University of California computer science professor and a critic of the industry, said: "There is a path forward to holding the sector more accountable for the harm [caused by] their services, while encouraging an open and free exchange of ideas. This executive order is not a productive part of that path."

The cornerstone of the web is Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act 1996. The law, passed when less than 10% of America or Britain had internet access, gives blanket immunity to platforms for content posted by users. As terrorism, child sexual abuse, misinformation, propaganda and conspiracies have spread across social media, calls for greater accountability have increasingly focused on either repealing Section 230 or carving it up to so that platforms can indeed be held liable for certain content.

The industry has fought those efforts tooth and nail. Trump has now put Section 230 in the line of fire. He has also exposed fault lines between the tech giants and revealed how politically charged the issue of online expression has become just months before what is sure to be a bitterly fought election.

Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg went on conservative news channel Fox News to bash Jack Dorsey, Twitter's chief executive, saying: "Facebook shouldn't be the arbiter of truth of everything that people say online." To wit, the president posted the exact same Twitter messages on Facebook. Facebook left them up.

It did the same after violent protests broke out over the death in police custody of George Floyd, an unarmed black man. "When the looting starts, the shooting starts," Trump had tweeted. Twitter covered it with a warning about tweets that "glorify violence", next to a button that allowed readers to view the message. Zuckerberg left it up.

The Facebook chief explained: "I believe people should be able to see this for themselves, because ultimately, accountability for those in positions of power can only happen when their speech is scrutinised out in the open."

(Trump later sought to clarify the post, claiming it was a warning against violence rather than a promotion of it.) Zuckerberg's position struck many as inconsistent. Just last month, the 36-yearold boasted of how Facebook had labelled 50 million posts "misinformation" about the coronavirus pandemic. Farid said: "The hypocrisy of his statement ... Two weeks ago, you're bragging about labelling misinformation, and the moment Trump pounces on Twitter, you're like, 'Oh yeah, we don't do that.' " A recent exposé by The Wall Street Journal revealed how Facebook's own research made it clear that its algorithms were increasing social division, but that Zuckerberg chose to kill an effort to improve the quality of discourse because it might hurt growth.

As for the order itself, legal scholars reckon it has little chance of surviving the courts. The order empowers the Federal Communications Commission to assess whether editorial decisions are made in "good faith" or to "stifle viewpoints with which they disagree". The definition of good faith is vague, but if the FCC does determine that a tech company has acted unfairly, it can, in effect, remove the immunity provided by Section 230 - not just for the post in question, but for all content. This, potentially, could expose the companies to lawsuits.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), a non-governmental organisation and ardent defender of Section 230, dubbed Trump's move an "error-filled reading" of the law that was, in fact, "a transparent attempt to retaliate against Twitter for its decision to curate (well, really just to factcheck) his posts".

With or without Trump's intervention, the chipping away at Section 230 has already begun. It is a rare issue where Democrats and Republicans have found a common cause. Farid labelled the law the "ultimate gift" because it provides a level of protection that no other industry enjoys.

A pharmaceuticals company that sells poisonous pills can be successfully sued; social media companies may help foment terrorism or promote fake medicine, but they are virtually impervious - as shown by a growing number of successful defences in court.

The first real dent in Section 230 came in 2018, when Congress passed an act to hold platforms liable for hosting posts used for child sex trafficking. Internet purists warned it would bring about the end of the web as we know it. It was a slippery slope that would kill free speech, they argued. Two years on, the web still exists - and Big Tech is bigger than ever.

Reformers are concerned, though, that Trump's act of political theatre may undermine efforts that have been building in the background. Farid said: "It's the worst possible timing. The Department of Justice was literally days away from releasing suggestions on reforming 230."

The EARN IT Act, which would peel back Section 230 protections related to child sexual abuse, has been gaining momentum in the US Senate.

Farid added: "This in many ways derails those very thoughtful conversations because it introduces this highly partisan component - and that is never going to end well for anybody."

On Friday, Trump took to Twitter again. He wrote: "REVOKE 230!" THANK THE WOLF OF WALL STREET The internet as we know it today has taken shape thanks largely to one man: the Wolf of Wall Street.

Jordan Belfort, the fraudster depicted by Leonardo DiCaprio, below with co-star Margot Robbie, in Martin Scorsese's film, founded Stratton Oakmont. His brokerage sued Prodigy, an internet services provider, for defamation after an anonymous user on message boards accused Belfort of fraud. Stratton won. The court ruled that Prodigy was a publisher that exerted editorial control over content on its pages, and was thus liable. Two congressmen were concerned about the precedent it might set. Senator Ron Wyden and Christopher Cox presented a bill to protect websites from liability for what users might post on their pages. It became Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, suddenly the hottest topic in US legal circles.

The law powered the rise of empires such as Google parent Alphabet and Facebook, which traffic in usergenerated content and have seen growth explode without having to worry about being legally accountable, as newspapers or radio stations are. Wyden, who remains in Congress, said last week that Donald Trump's executive order to potentially roll back Section 230 was "plainly illegal".

There is a path to holding the sector more accountable for harm caused. This is not part of it
